E.3   Angebotskonditionen.   Das Angebot bezieht sich auf den Verkauf von 2.300.000 Aktien, bestehend aus:

   bis zu 2.000.000 neu ausgegebenen, zu dematerialisierenden Aktien aus
    einer Kapitalerhöhung gegen Bareinlage, beschlossen durch den
    Verwaltungsrat der Gesellschaft (der „Verwaltungsrat“) (die „Neuen
    Aktien”); und
   bis zu 300.000 bestehenden, zu dematerialisierenden Aktien im
    Zusammenhang mit einer möglichen Mehrzuteilung (die
    „Mehrzuteilungsaktien” und zusammen mit den Neuen Aktien die
    „Angebotsaktien”).

Das Angebot besteht aus (i) öffentlichen Angeboten in Deutschland und in
Luxemburgsowie (ii) Privatplatzierungen an qualifizierte institutionelle Anleger
außerhalb Deutschlands, Luxemburgs und der Vereinigten Staaten gemäß der
Regulation S („Regulation S”) des Securities Act der Vereinigten Staaten von 1933
in der derzeit geltenden Fassung (der „Securities Act“).

Das Angebot wird durch die Veröffentlichung dieses Prospekts in elektronischer
Form auf der Internetseite der Gesellschaft (www.mybucks.com) und der Börse
Luxemburg (www.bourse.lu) bekanntgegeben werden.

Der Zeitraum, in dem Anleger ihre Kaufangebote für die Angebotsaktien abgeben
können, beginnt voraussichtlich am 13. Mai und endet voraussichtlich am 24. Mai
(der „Angebotszeitraum“). Am letzten Tag des Angebotszeitraums können
Kaufangebote (i) von Privatanlegern (natürlichen Personen) bis 12:00 Uhr
(Mitteleuropäische Sommerzeit) („MESZ“) und (ii) von institutionellen Anlegern bis
14:00 Uhr MESZ abgegeben werden.
Angebotszeitraum

Die Preisspanne innerhalb derer Kaufangebote abgegeben werden können, liegt
zwischen 13,50 € und 16,50 € je Angebotsaktie (die „Preisspanne“).
Preisspanne

                    Angebotsaktien, die im Rahmen des Angebots platziert werden sollen, stehen zum

Datum dieses Prospekts noch nicht fest; sie werden gemeinsam von der Gesellschaft
und dem Sole Global Coordinator am 24. Mai 2016 auf der Grundlage der von
Investoren abgegebenen Angeboten, die im während eines Bookbuilding-Prozesses
erstellten Orderbuch zusammengetragen wurden, festgelegt. Der Angebotspreis und
die endgültige Anzahl der im Rahmen des Angebots platzierten Angebotsaktien
(d.h. das Ergebnis des Angebots) werden voraussichtlich am selben Tag über eine
Ad-hoc-Mitteilung, die in verschiedenen Medien mit Verbreitung im gesamten
Europäischen Wirtschaftsraum („EWR“) und auf der Internetseite der Gesellschaft
(www.mybucks.com)          veröffentlicht    und     bei    der    Luxemburger
Finanzaufsichtsbehörde (Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier)
eingereicht wird, jeweils gemäß Artikel 10 des luxemburgischen Prospektgesetzes,
veröffentlicht.

Die Gesellschaft behält sich das Recht vor, gemeinsam mit dem Sole Global
Coordinator die Gesamtzahl der Angebotsaktien zu erhöhen oder herabzusetzen, das
obere Limit und/oder untere Limit der Preisspanne zu erhöhen oder zu senken
und/oder den Angebotszeitraum zu verlängern oder zu verkürzen. Änderungen der
Anzahl der Angebotsaktien, der Preisspanne oder einer Verlängerung bzw.
Verkürzung des Angebotszeitraums haben keinen Einfluss auf die Gültigkeit bereits
abgegebener Kaufangebote.

Änderung der
Angebotskonditionen

Sollte eine solche Änderung die Veröffentlichung eines Nachtrags zu diesem
Prospekt erforderlich machen, haben Anleger, die ihre Kaufaufträge vor der
Veröffentlichung des Nachtrags abgegeben haben, nach dem luxemburgischen
Prospektgesetz das Recht, diese Kaufaufträge innerhalb von zwei Geschäftstagen
nach der Veröffentlichung des Nachtrags zurückzuziehen, sofern der neue Faktor, der
Fehler oder die Unrichtigkeit, der bzw. die einen Nachtrag zu dem Prospekt
erforderlich machte, aus dem Zeitraum vor dem endgültigen Angebotsschluss und der
Lieferung der Angebotsaktien herrührte. Neben der Rücknahme der vor
Veröffentlichung des Nachtrags abgegebenen Kaufangebote haben Anleger die
Möglichkeit, ihre Aufträge innerhalb von zwei Geschäftstagen nach der
Veröffentlichung des Nachtrags abzuändern oder neue begrenzte oder unbegrenzte
Kaufaufträge zu platzieren. Änderungen der Angebotsbedingungen werden in
elektronischen Medien und, soweit dies nach dem Gesetz erforderlich ist, als Ad-hoc-
Meldung über ein elektronisches Informationssystem, auf der Internetseite der
Gesellschaft und als von der CSSF zu billigender und auf der Internetseite der
Luxemburger Wertpapierbörse (www.bourse.lu) und der Internetseite der
Gesellschaft (www.mybucks.com) zu veröffentlichender Nachtrag zu diesem
Prospekt bekannt gegeben. Anleger, die Kaufangebote abgegeben haben, werden
nicht einzeln benachrichtigt.

Unter bestimmten Umständen kann der Sole Global Coordinator von dem mit der
Gesellschaft am 11. Mai 2016 geschlossenen Übernahmevertrag betreffend das
Angebot (der „Übernahmevertrag“) auch noch nach Aufnahme des Handels der
Aktien am regulierten Markt der Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse zurücktreten.

Die Angebotsaktien werden voraussichtlich am 30. Mai 2016 gegen Zahlung des
Angebotspreises geliefert. Die Angebotsaktien werden den Aktionären in stückeloser
Form zur Verfügung gestellt.

Stabilisierung,
Mehrzuteilung und
Greenshoe-Option

Im Zusammenhang mit der Platzierung der Angebotsaktien handelt der Sole Global
Coordinator als Stabilisierungsmanager und kann in Übereinstimmung mit den
rechtlichen Bestimmungen (§ 20a Abs. 3 Wertpapierhandelsgesetz in Verbindung mit
der Verordnung (EG) Nr. 2273/2003 vom 22. Dezember 2003) Mehrzuteilungen
vornehmen und Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen ergreifen, um den Börsenkurs der Aktien
zu stützen und um dadurch einem etwaigen Verkaufsdruck entgegenzuwirken.

Der Stabilisierungsmanager ist nicht zu Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen verpflichtet. Es
kann daher nicht zugesichert werden, dass Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen ergriffen
werden. Sollten Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen ergriffen werden, können diese jederzeit
ohne Vorankündigung beendet werden. Solche Maßnahmen können ab dem

Zeitpunkt der Aufnahme des Börsenhandels der Aktien am Regulierten Markt der
Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse vorgenommen werden und müssen spätestens am
dreißigsten Kalendertag nach diesem Zeitpunkt beendet sein (der
„Stabilisierungszeitraum”).

Diese Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen können dazu führen, dass der Börsenkurs der
Aktien höher ist, als es ohne solche Maßnahmen der Fall gewesen wäre. Des
Weiteren kann sich vorübergehend ein Börsenkurs auf einem Niveau ergeben, das
nicht von Dauer ist.

Bei möglichen Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen können Anlegern zusätzlich zu den
angebotenen Neuen Aktien bis zu 300.000 Mehrzuteilungsaktien als Teil der
Zuteilung der zu platzierenden Aktien zugeteilt werden. Zum Zwecke einer
möglichen Mehrzuteilung werden dem Sole Global Coordinator bis zu 300.000
bestehende Aktien aus dem Aktienbesitz der Sunblaze Investment in Form eines
Wertpapierdarlehens zur Verfügung gestellt. Dabei wird die Anzahl der Aktien 15 %
der Neuen Aktien nicht übersteigen. Zudem wird die Gesellschaft dem Sole Global
Coordinator eine Option zum Erwerb der geliehenen Aktien zum Angebotspreis
abzüglich der vereinbarten Provisionen gewähren („Mehrzuteilungsoption”), die
von der Gesellschaft, im Fall der Ausübung der Mehrzuteilungsoption, im Wege
einer Kapitalerhöhung aus dem Genehmigten Kapital ausgegeben würden. Die
Mehrzuteilungsoption endet 30 Kalendertage nach der Aufnahme des Handels der
Aktien an der Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse, also am oder um den 25. Juni 2016.

Der Sole Global Coordinator ist als Stabilisierungsmanager berechtigt, die
Mehrzuteilungsoption in dem Maß der ursprünglichen Mehrzuteilung auszuüben.
Dabei ist der Aktienbetrag um die Anzahl der Aktien zu vermindern, die vom Sole
Global Coordinator als Stabilisierungsmanager am Tag der Ausübung der
Mehrzuteilungsoption gehalten werden und von diesem im Zusammenhang mit
Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen erworben wurden.

Die Verpflichtung beschränkt nicht die außerbörsliche Übertragung der Aktien der
Gesellschaft (i) zwischen bestehenden Aktionären oder (ii) von einem bestehenden
Aktionär an eine andere, diesen Aktionär kontrollierende oder mit diesem Aktionär
unter gemeinsamer Kontrolle stehende Person, oder eine andere Person, die dieser
Aktionär kontrolliert, sofern der Übertragungsempfänger mit einer schriftlichen
Bestätigung gegenüber dem Sole Global Coordinator die Verpflichtungen dieses
Aktionärs für die verbleibende Dauer der Lock-up-Vereinbarung übernimmt.

Unter der Annahme (i) eines vollständigen Verkaufs aller Neuen Aktien zu einem
Platzierungspreis zum Mittelwert der Preisspanne, (ii) der vollständigen Ausübung
der Greenshoe-Option und (iii) nach Abzug der maximal erwarteten Kosten des
Angebots, die von der Gesellschaft zu tragen sind, hätte das derartig angepasste
Eigenkapital der Gruppe, also der den Aktionären zurechenbare Nettobuchwert,
zum 31. Dezember 2015 41,0 Mio. € betragen. Dies enstpricht ungefähr 3,3 € pro
Aktie der Gesellschaft (berechnet auf der Basis von 9.998.000 ausstehenden Aktien
der Gesellschaft nach Durchführung des Angebots). Unter den vorstehenden
Annahmen führt das Angebot zu einer unmittelbaren Verwässerung von 11.7 €
(77.8 %) pro Aktie der Gesellschaft für alle Personen, die Angebotsaktien erwerben.

RISK FACTORS

An investment in the shares of MyBucks S.A. (the “Company”, “MyBucks” and, together with its consolidated
subsidiaries, “we,” “us,” “our,” or the “Group,”) is subject to a number of risks. Prospective investors should carefully
consider the risks set forth below and the other information contained in the Prospectus prior to making any investment
decision with respect to the Company’s shares (the “Shares”). Each of the risks highlighted below, alone or together
with additional risks and uncertainties of which we currently are not aware, or that we might currently deem immaterial,
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, if any or
all of these risks were to materialize, the market price of the Shares could fall in which case prospective investors could
lose all or part of their investment.

The order, in which the following risks are presented, does not indicate the likelihood of their occurrence, nor
their likely significance or degree, nor the scope of any potential impairment these risks may cause to our business, fi-
nancial condition and results of operations. The risks mentioned may materialize individually or cumulatively.
Risks Related to Our Business and Our Industry

Worsening global and regional economic conditions, in particular in Africa and Europe, could adversely affect the
demand for our products, increase our customers’ default rates and harm our growth and results of operations.

risk_factor: Worsening global and regional economic conditions, in particular in Africa and Europe, could adversely affect thedemand for our products, increase our customers’ default rates and harm our growth and results of operations.

blobs.text:
Our performance depends on global and regional economic conditions, which have shown significant volatility in
recent years. Our customers are individual consumers. Economic downturns or the worsening of economic conditions
tend to have a disproportionately negative impact on consumer confidence and discretionary consumer spending. There-
fore, any period of economic slowdown or recession in the countries in which we operate may result in a decline in the
demand for our products by potential customers or higher default rates by our existing customers, even if we adjust our
credit scoring models to such new economic conditions.

Although there have been signs of a global economic recovery during the last several years, there can be no assur-
ance that economic conditions will remain favourable for our business, or that demand for our products or default rates by
our customers will remain at current levels. For example, growth in Sub-Saharan Africa has weakened in 2015 after more
than a decade of solid growth. Following the collapse in commodity prices and negative effects of the recent drought on
the predominantly agricultural economies in Sub-Saharan Africa, middle-income countries such as Ghana, South Africa,
and Zambia are facing unfavourable conditions. 23 In particular South Africa, stands on the brink of a recession. 24 In addi-
tion, Zimbabwe which adopted a multicurrency system in 2009 is currently facing a deepening US dollar cash shortage. 25
As a result, the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe Governor recently announced a range of measures, including printing new
bond notes with the same value as US dollars, setting limits to withdrawals from banks and teller machines and reducing
the maximum cash allowed to be taken abroad, which might have a material adverse effect on the Zimbabwean banking
system. Other Sub-Saharan African countries, already struggling with an economic crisis, could also hit a recession or
experience a further deterioration of their economic conditions. And countries with so far stable or growing economies,
such as Kenya, could experience severe downturns in the future, leading to rising inflation, increased unemployment
rates and occurrences of personal insolvencies.

In addition, various concerns remain regarding the ability of certain member states of the EU (each a “EU Mem-
ber State”) and other countries to continue servicing their sovereign debt obligations. The significant economic stagna-
tion in certain countries in the Eurozone, especially Greece, Ireland, Italy, Portugal, Spain, Slovenia and Cyprus, in part
due to the effects of the sovereign debt crisis and corresponding austerity measures in these markets, has added to these
concerns. Due to the continuing economic disparities, in particular between the countries forming the Eurozone, as well
as the implications of the current refugee crisis or the on-going discussion about a potential exit of Great Britain from the
EU (so-called “Brexit”), the risk of a default of one or more countries in the Eurozone remains. This could further desta-
bilize and negatively affect the European economies in which we also operate and - since the extent and impact of such
default are impossible to predict - could also lead to the expulsion or voluntary withdrawal of one or more countries from
the Eurozone or a disorderly break-up of the Eurozone, either of which could significantly disrupt financial markets and
possibly trigger another global recession.

As a result, any adverse changes in the economic conditions of the countries in which we operate or otherwise
participate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We have operated for a limited period of time in the financial services industry, which makes it difficult to evaluate
our future prospects and may increase the risk that we will not be successful.

We may not be able to successfully evaluate the creditworthiness of potential customers. Any increase in customer de-
fault rates may reduce our overall profitability and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial

risk_factor: We may not be able to successfully evaluate the creditworthiness of potential customers. Any increase in customer de-fault rates may reduce our overall profitability and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financialcondition and results of operations.

blobs.text:
We are exposed to the creditworthiness of potential customers. As we are focusing on the low- and middle-income
consumer segment, our customers have, in general, a higher frequency of delinquencies, higher probability of non-
payment and, ultimately higher credit losses than other customers who are served by more traditional banks and credit
providers. To mitigate our credit risk, we operate according to our established credit risk policies, use computer-aided
loan approval algorithms and follow a set of self-imposed ethical and responsible lending principles which are regularly
reviewed. Before making a decision whether to extend credit to a potential customer and in which amount, we perform
due diligence on the information provided by the individual customer, received from third parties, like consumer report-
ing agencies26, financial data analytics tools, such as Yodlee, and credit bureaus 27, as well as various other available in-
formation on the customer. To evaluate this information, we utilize our proprietary credit decisioning and scoring model
system called “Jessie”. It assigns a score or grade to each loan applied for and, in certain jurisdictions, also a correspond-
ing interest rate and loan amount. “Jessie” is based on algorithms that take into account a number of factors, including
behavioural data, transactional data and employment information. In addition, customer details are also verified against
our internal artificial intelligence (“AI”) fraud detection module “Watson” which supplements our “Jessie” credit deci-
sioning and scoring model system.

Although we refine and update our credit policies and scoring algorithms on an on-going basis based on new data
and changing economic conditions, these measures may prove to be insufficient. “Jessie” may also contain programming
and other errors, be otherwise ineffective, or the data provided by potential customers or third-parties may be outdated,
incomplete or inaccurate and we may be unable to verify this information. Third-party data we use for our credit scoring
models may also become unavailable, or too expensive to access, or our access to such data may be limited. We use iden-
tity and fraud checks, analysing data provided by external databases to authenticate each customer’s identity. However,
these checks may fail and fraud may occur. In all such cases, “Jessie’s” ability to accurately evaluate the creditworthiness
of potential customers will be compromised, and the credit score or loan grade assigned to a customer may not reflect
that customer’s actual creditworthiness, resulting in mispriced or misclassified loans, or incorrect approvals, or denials of
loans. Fraudulent activity or significant increases in fraudulent activity could harm our brand as well as our reputation
and also lead to regulatory intervention.

Any failure to correctly assess the creditworthiness of potential customers, due to failure in our evaluation of the
customer or fraud, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

customer or fraud, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Our allowances for anticipated credit losses are determined based upon both objective and subjective factors and may
not be not sufficient to absorb the credit losses actually incurred.

risk_factor: Our allowances for anticipated credit losses are determined based upon both objective and subjective factors and maynot be not sufficient to absorb the credit losses actually incurred.

blobs.text: We face the risk that our customers will fail to repay their loans in full. To mitigate this risk, we constantly mo n-

itor the performance of our loan portfolio and reserve for such losses by establishing allowances for anticipated credit
losses in our financial statements. Each actual credit loss is recognised as a credit impairment charge in our statements
of comprehensive income. As of 31 December 2015, our allowances for anticipated credit losses amounted to €7.4 mil-
lion against a gross loan book of €44.4 million, which represents 16.7% of the value of the loan book. These allowances
for anticipated credit losses may not be adequate to cover our actual credit losses or any future deterioration in the overall
credit quality of our total loan portfolio. We have established an evaluation process, designed to determine the adequacy
of our allowances for anticipated credit losses which uses historical and other objective information (such as the amount
of outstanding loans, current collection patterns and current economic trends) and our subjective assessment, based upon
our experience and judgment. However, actual credit losses are difficult to forecast, especially if such losses stem from
factors beyond our historical experience and control, such as the impact of macroeconomic trends, political events or
adverse events affecting our key jurisdictions. As a result, our actual credit losses could materially exceed the level of
our allowances, which could, in turn, have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

Our current level of interest rate spread may decline in the future. Any material reduction in our interest rate spread

risk_factor: Our current level of interest rate spread may decline in the future. Any material reduction in our interest rate spreadcould reduce our profitability.

blobs.text:
We earn a substantial majority of our revenue from fees and interest payments on the loans we make to our cus-
tomers. Financial institutions and other funding sources (including our shareholders) provide us with the capital to fund
these loans and lines of credit and charge us interest on funds that we draw down. In the event that the spread between
the rate at which we lend to our customers and the rate at which we borrow from our lenders decreases, our financial
results and operating performance will be harmed. The interest rates we charge to our customers and pay to our lenders
could each be affected by a variety of factors, including access to capital based on our business performance, the vol-
ume of loans we make to our customers, competition and regulatory requirements. These interest rates may also be af-
fected by a change over time in the mix of the types of products we sell to our customers. Interest rates are highly sensi-
tive to many macroeconomic factors beyond our control, such as inflation, recession, the state of the credit markets,
changes in market interest rates, global economic disruptions, unemployment and the fiscal and monetary policies of the
federal governments in the markets in which we operate and their agencies. Any material reduction in our interest rate
spread could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Our operations are subject to foreign exchange and interest rate risks.

risk_factor: Our operations are subject to foreign exchange and interest rate risks.

blobs.text:
As we operate internationally, a portion of our net assets, liabilities, sales, expenses and earnings is denominated
in currencies other than Euro. We are, therefore, exposed to foreign exchange rate risks. Despite all precautions, there is
no assurance that the fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates can be compensated. Fluctuations in the values of
the local currencies of the Sub-Saharan African countries in which we operate, such as the South African Rand (“ZAR”),
Kenya Shilling, Malawian Kwacha or the Botswana Pula, in relation to the US dollar, or of the US dollar in relation to
the Euro, which is our reporting currency, have had and could continue to have a significant impact on our financial re-
sults. In addition, we are also exposed to interest rate risk, since our Group companies have predominantly prime linked
debt facilities with banks in local currencies. As a result, the interest rates of our debt facilities may differ and fluctua-
tions in interest rates may affect our interest expense on existing debt and our cost of funding. Any failure to manage our
foreign exchange and interest risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.
Higher inflation rates in the markets in which we operate could significantly affect our margins.

risk_factor: Higher inflation rates in the markets in which we operate could significantly affect our margins.

blobs.text:
As we provide our loans in local currency, our operating margins also depend on the level of inflation in each of
the markets in which we operate. Historically, these level of inflations used to differ significantly across geographies.
While, for example, countries such as Botswana, Poland, Spain and Zimbabwe had low or even negative inflation rates in
March 2016, countries like Malawi, Mozambique and Zambia experienced double-digit inflations rates in the same peri-
od of time. There is a risk that the inflation rate in one or more of the markets in which we operate actually exceed the
level of inflation we assumed when disbursing our respective loans. For example, the respective central bank(s) could
target higher inflation. Foreign and domestic supply or demand shocks, in particular with regard to energy, food or com-
modity prices, or foreign inflation spillovers, could also drive higher inflation, in addition to limiting economic growth. If
inflation increases and we have failed to anticipate this increase while determining our respective interest rates for the
loans disbursed in such market(s), the actual value of our loans to be repaid and of the interest payable thereon would
diminish and may, in the worst case, even become lower than the value of the principal amounts initially lent. In such
event, the margins in our lending business could significantly decline or even become non-existent. Furthermore, claims
costs in our insurance business could increase as a result of inflation (agreed premiums generally can only be adjusted to
inflation in the context of contract renewals and cannot be adjusted under running contracts). If we make incorrect as-
sumptions about future inflation, our premiums and reserves for payment of claims on existing policies could prove inad-
equate. The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

Significant, rapid or unforeseen economic or political changes in the emerging markets, in which we operate, may
harm our business.

risk_factor: Significant, rapid or unforeseen economic or political changes in the emerging markets, in which we operate, mayharm our business.

blobs.text:
We operate in a variety of so-called emerging markets in Sub-Saharan Africa, such as Botswana, Kenya, Malawi,
South Africa and Zimbabwe, and we will also consider expanding our business into other new markets, should opportuni-
ties present themselves. In recent years, certain of the emerging markets, in which we operate, in particular Zimbabwe,
have undergone substantial political, economic and social changes. As is typical of emerging markets, these markets
have, in general, significantly less political or social stability than is generally found in Europe. Additionally, also the le-
gal and judicial systems in some of these markets are less developed than western European countries. As the business,
legal and regulatory infrastructures in these jurisdictions are continuously evolving, in particular the tax and currency leg-
islation in these markets are subject to varying interpretations and changes which can occur frequently. Therefore, doing
business in these markets carries certain inherent risks. Any detrimental changes in, or any deterioration of the political
or economic environment in the emerging markets in which we currently operate, or may operate in the future, could lead
to political and economic instability that may, in particular, lead to hyperinflation, restrictions on foreign ownership, de-
valuation of local currencies or social unrest, all of which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.
e depend on the sustainability of our deduction-at-source scheme for our collections

risk_factor: We depend on the sustainability of our deduction-at-source scheme for our collections.

blobs.text:
We generate a substantial part of our revenue from lending to civil servants or employees of large corporate cus-
tomers, whose loan repayments are conducted via a deduction-at-source mechanism. As of 31 December 2015, the loans
secured by this collection method accounted for 69% of our loan gross loan book (government and private payroll). For
such customers, we sign agreements with the employers, who, in turn, deduct loan instalments on our behalf. This is es-
pecially pertinent in scenarios where there is little or no available credit bureau data, no reliable electronic debit order
means exist, and employees are not able to get access to credit and insurance. In addition, we also use the deduction-at-
source mechanism for our electronic salary- and deductions-verification: Before granting a loan, our cloud-based proprie-
tary customer interface and loan management system “FinCloud”, is programmed to assess (in real time) whether an in-
dividual is employed, and if he or she has existing deductions or financial commitments affected against his or her salary.
This system is meant to prevent our customers from borrowing more than they can afford to repay and what has been
agreed with the employer. As a result, over-borrowed and defaulting customers can be easily identified and excluded
from the application process, leading to a collections rate on deduction-at-source lending of about 95%, which reduces
volatility of our profits, through lower impairments. If one or more countries, in which we use the deduction-at-source
method to collect payments, should decide to amend regulation to restrict or prohibit this method, or if one or more of
these countries or of the large corporate customers we serve should reduce the size of their employees on a large scale,
the number of customers for which we can use this collection method would decline. This could significantly impair our
overall collections rate and, in turn, have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of op-
erations.

We are exposed to liquidity risks and our ability to raise additional capital, both equity and debt, could be limited. If
we do not have access to financing under affordable terms, our business could be harmed and we may not be able to
expand our business.

risk_factor: We are exposed to liquidity risks and our ability to raise additional capital, both equity and debt, could be limited. Ifwe do not have access to financing under affordable terms, our business could be harmed and we may not be able toexpand our business.

blobs.text:
Our business model and growth depend on our cash flow efficiency and cash collection. As a result, we are e x-
posed to liquidity risks. Although our cash inflows and capital resources are sufficient to fund our debt service obliga-
tions and to satisfy our working capital and other liquidity needs as of the date hereof, we cannot guarantee that we will
be able to satisfy our liquidity needs in the future. Lack of liquidity may occur in numerous scenarios. We, for instance,
may experience a lack of liquidity due to an unexpected increase in rates of delinquencies or defaults on provided co n-
sumer loans. Further, as the Company is a holding company that conducts its operational business mainly through its
subsidiaries, its liquidity depends directly on our operating subsidiaries’ distributions of earnings to the Company or oth-
er Group companies. The amount and timing of such distributions will depend on the laws of the operating subsidiaries’
respective jurisdictions and the terms of any relevant intercompany financing arrangements. Any adverse changes to such
laws, including possible restrictions on the repatriation of profits, or terms, or any imposed foreign exchange controls,
based on such laws by one or more countries in which we operate, or the denial or withdrawal of any reserve bank ap-
proval, which may be required under such laws, could prevent the Company from receiving sufficient distributions from
its subsidiaries. If we are unable to meet our cash requirements, our growth in new markets may be adversely affected,
and any decreasing cash inflows from existing operations and/or increasing cash outflows associated with new opera-
tions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

To manage our liquidity risks, we also depend on our ability to privately or publicly raise additional capital, both
equity and debt, to pursue our business objectives and respond to business opportunities, challenges or unforeseen cir-
cumstances. Additionally, to support our future growth, including financing the loans granted to our customers, increas-
ing our marketing expenditures to improve our brand awareness and developing new products or services or further im-
proving existing products and services as well as enhancing our operating infrastructure, enabling our geographical ex-
pansion, and acquiring complementary businesses and technologies. However, such financing might not be available
when we need it, on terms that are acceptable to us, or at all. Our ability to raise capital depends on many factors, some
of which are outside of our control. Some of the factors that could affect our ability to obtain adequate financing include,
but are not necessarily limited to:

Any inability to raise capital, as needed for going forward, could harm our business and prevent us from realizing
business opportunities, growing our business or responding to competitive pressures. If we are unable to arrange new or
alternative methods of financing on favourable terms, we may have to curtail our origination of loans. In addition, we
may fail to comply with the covenants contained in our existing or future credit agreements and other agreements govern-
ing our debt. This could result in a default under these agreements, governing the relevant indebtedness. If such a default
is not cured or waived by the affected creditor, the default could result in the acceleration of debt under our debt agree-
ments. It may also contain cross-acceleration or cross-default provisions that could require us to repurchase or repay our
debt prior to the date it is otherwise due. The realization of any of such risks could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our rapid growth may not be indicative of our future growth and, if we continue to grow rapidly, we may not be able
to manage our growth effectively.

risk_factor: Our rapid growth may not be indicative of our future growth and, if we continue to grow rapidly, we may not be ableto manage our growth effectively.

blobs.text:
We have experienced significant growth. Our revenue grew from €3.2 million in the year ended 30 June 2013 to
€31.3 million in the year ended 30 June 2015. Although we consider ourselves well-positioned to take advantage of the
strong growth prospects of the Sub-Saharan African markets, there can be no assurance that our growth will be sustaina-
ble and that we will continue to experience significant growth or any growth at all. In addition, we anticipate that our
growth rate may decline over time, as we achieve higher market penetration rates in all markets in which we operate. To
the extent that our growth rate slows, our business performance will become increasingly dependent on our ability to, in-
ter alia, use our operating leverage, optimize our credit application process while minimizing our customers’ default risk,
and decrease operating costs in relation to our revenue. We have made and are continuing to make investments in opti-
mizing and localizing our customer experience, our fulfilment and IT infrastructure, including “Jessie” and “FinCloud”,
and the development of mobile applications. However, there is no assurance that these efforts will be sufficient to grow
our revenue or business in total or in relation to the costs we incur. If our revenue growth slows or if our revenue de-
clines, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

In addition, our historical rapid growth has placed, and may continue to place, significant demands on our man-
agement, our operational, and financial resources. In particular, we expect to continue to expend substantial financial and
other resources on:

Against this background, there can be no assurance that we will be able to effectively manage the expansion of
our operations, or that our current personnel, systems, procedures, and controls will be adequate to support our opera-
tions. As our organizational structure is becoming more complex, we will also need to improve our operational, financial
and management controls as well as our reporting systems and procedures.

At present, some countries in which we operate, such as Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, South Africa, and Zimbabwe,
generate a significant share of our revenue. As a result, we are exposed to country-specific risks with respect to such ge-
ographic markets. In such markets, a dissatisfaction with our products, a decrease in customer demand, our failure to suc-
r pro

cessfully market new and existing products, or the failure to further expand our customer base and retain our existing
customer base could have a material adverse effect on our business prospects, financial condition or results of operations.

To reduce our dependency on these regional markets, we plan to expand our product offering into further geogra-
phies. Our expansion strategy, which in part contemplates the fast growth in mobile consumer loan volumes in current
markets and the establishment of operations in new markets, predominately in Sub-Saharan Africa like Zambia (2015),
Namibia and Uganda (2016), is subject to significant risks. In particular, our continued growth will be dependent upon a
number of factors, including our ability:
to develop efficient internal monitoring and control systems;
and other factors, some of which are beyond our control.

There is no guarantee that the intended increase of our market penetration in current, or our expansion into new,
geographic markets will prove to be successful. A number of factors, including political or economic underdevelopment,
poor infrastructure, political instability, crime, difficulties with labour or community relations or other factors could
make such expansion particularly difficult.

If for any of these, or other reasons, our expansion strategy fails, this could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.
We might be unable to successfully integrate or achieve the expected benefits from current and future acquisition

risk_factor: We might be unable to successfully integrate or achieve the expected benefits from current and future acquisitions.

blobs.text:
Our success will depend, in part, on our ability to grow our business. Organic growth, diversification of our prod-
uct portfolio, and geographical expansion are core components of our growth strategy. However, in some circumstances,
we may determine to grow through the acquisition of complementary businesses, loan portfolios or technologies rather
than through internal development. For example, we recently acquired a Pan-African group of companies consisting of
three banks in Malawi, Mozambique and Uganda, one savings and loans company in Ghana, and two non-bank financial
institutions (“NBFIs”) in Kenya and Tanzania (collectively, the “Opportunity Banks”) (see below under “―We are ex-
posed to risks relating to the acquisition of the Opportunity Banks.”) and may continue to opportunistically seize growth
opportunities by pursuing selected acquisitions in the future.

To the extent that we are successful in making acquisitions, we may need to expend substantial amounts of cash,
incur additional debt or assume loss-making divisions. Current and future acquisitions also involve a number of other
transactional risks, including:

   extraordinary or unexpected tax, legal, regulatory, contractual and other costs, including the need to im-
    plement or improve controls, procedures and policies at a business that prior to the acquisition may have
    lacked effective controls, procedures and policies;
   potential write-offs of loans or intangibles or other assets acquired in such transactions that may have an
    adverse effect on our operating results in a given period;
   liability for activities of the acquired company before the acquisition, including patent and trademark in-
    fringement claims, violations of laws, commercial disputes, tax liabilities and other known and unknown
    liabilities; and
   litigation or other claims in connection with the acquired company, including claims from terminated em-
    ployees, customers, former shareholders or other third parties.

Our failure to address these risks or other problems, encountered in connection with our current and future acqui-
sitions and investments, could cause us to fail to realize cost savings, synergies, future earnings or other benefits that we
intend to achieve from these acquisitions and additionally cause us to incur unanticipated liabilities and harm our busi-
ness generally. We cannot guarantee that any current or future acquisition will yield benefits that are sufficient to justify
the expenses we have incurred or will incur in completing such acquisition. Current and future acquisitions could also
result in dilutive issuances of our equity securities, the incurrence of debt, contingent liabilities, amortization expenses or
the write-off of goodwill, any of which could harm our financial condition.

The materialization of any of these risks, alone or in combination, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.
We are exposed to risks relating to the acquisition of the Opportunity Banks.

risk_factor: We are exposed to risks relating to the acquisition of the Opportunity Banks.

blobs.text:
On 27 October 2015, we entered into a share purchase agreement (the “Opportunity SPA”) with Opportunity, Inc. and
two further subsidiaries of Opportunity International, Inc. (“Opportunity International”) to acquire their majority
shareholdings in the Opportunity Banks (the “Acquisition”). By way of the Acquisition, we intend to expand our
geographic reach by adding Ghana, Mozambique, and Tanzania to our African footprint, enhance our competitive
position in Kenya, Malawi, and Uganda, and increase our customer base to more than 1.5 million customers. In addition,
Opportunity International will become a minority shareholder in the Company and be entitled to appoint at least one non-
executive director at level of the Company and at the level of each of the Opportunity Banks.

The Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including regulatory approval by each central bank in
the countries concerned. Should any of these closing conditions not be fulfilled and/or obtained and/or the Opportunity
SPA be terminated otherwise, in part or completely, the Acquisition may fail accordingly. For example, Opportunity In-
ternational as seller is currently pursuing an investigation concerning a potential misconduct of certain individuals of Op-
portunity Bank Uganda’s management, including the current CEO and CFO, which is unrelated to the Acquisition. De-
pending on the result of the investigation, the acquisition of Opportunity Bank Uganda may not occur. As of the date of
the Prospectus, the result of the investigation at Opportunity Bank Uganda, and in turn the closing of the Acquisition for
such bank, remains unclear. For us, any failure of the Acquisition may entail reputational damage and financial disad-
vantages due to, inter alia, the time lost and costs incurred in connection with the Acquisition, and cause a significant
impairment to our growth prospects. In addition, if we have failed to identify significant undisclosed risks or liabilities in
our due diligence regarding the Opportunity Banks for which the Seller has not, or only partially, assumed liability under
the SPA, the price paid as consideration for the Opportunity Banks may be considered too high and we may have to ad-
dress those risks or liabilities in our business operations with the Opportunity Banks.

The realization of any of such risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

The forthcoming integration of the Opportunity Banks may not be successful and expected synergies may not materi-
alize. If we fail to manage the integration effectively, our business and future growth could be harmed.

risk_factor: The forthcoming integration of the Opportunity Banks may not be successful and expected synergies may not materi-alize. If we fail to manage the integration effectively, our business and future growth could be harmed.

blobs.text:
The forthcoming integration of the Opportunity Banks into our business involves risks. The integration might turn
out to be difficult and unpredictable, and we may not be able to integrate the Opportunity Banks into our Group as
planned or only at a higher cost than originally planned. The risks associated with the integration particularly include our
inability:

   to align the products and services of the Opportunity Banks with our offering, and to establish joint opera-
    tional processes for the integrated Group, including back-office functions and systems, such as accounting,
    human resources, internal controls and others;
   to effectively maintain and manage our financial, regulatory and compliance risk management controls and
    procedures; and
   to integrate and retain the management, other key personnel and culture of the acquired business operations
    into our Group.

We expect that the integration of the Opportunity Banks will tie up significant management and financial re-
sources which may have been better utilized developing technology, products and services for our offering or on other
strategic development initiatives. Further, since our experience in banking is limited, the integration may disrupt our on-
going operations, divert management’s attention from their primary responsibilities and our other strategic initiatives,
subject us to additional liabilities, and increase our expenses. In addition, synergy effects may not materialize to the ex-
tent anticipated, if at all, and the costs associated with synergies may be higher than planned.
synergies

tent anticipated, if at all, and the costs associated with synergies may be higher than planned.
       If due to the materialization of any of these risks, alone or in combination, the integration of the Opportunity
Banks fails, or if the integration costs turn out to be higher than originally planned, or if the combined Group’s financial
or operational performance does not develop as expected, or if the expectations on the expansion of our customer base
and geographic reach by way of the Acquisition are not be met, the price paid as consideration for the Opportunity Banks
may be considered too high, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results

for illustrative purposes only and does not reflect the actual or future net assets, financial position or results of opera
tions of our Group upon completion of the Acquisition.

Our total financial position will increase significantly upon completion of the Acquisition. For this reason, pro
forma financial information has been prepared and included elsewhere in the Prospectus. The purpose of the pro forma
financial information is to present the material effects that the Acquisition would have had on our historical combined
consolidated financial statements for the twelve-month period ended 31 December 2015 if the business operations had
been part of our Group since 1 January 2015. The pro forma financial information is based on available information, es-
timates and certain assumptions, and has been prepared for illustrative purposes only. By its nature, the pro forma finan-
cial information describes only a hypothetical situation and since it is based on assumptions, its presentation does not re-
flect the actual or future net assets, financial position and result of operations of our Group upon completion of the Ac-
quisition.

If unexpected difficulties were to arise in the course of the integration of the Opportunity Banks, or if the combined
business fails to develop as expected, we could be forced in the future to recognize impairment losses on the tangible
or intangible assets and/or goodwill of the Opportunity Banks.

risk_factor: If unexpected difficulties were to arise in the course of the integration of the Opportunity Banks, or if the combinedbusiness fails to develop as expected, we could be forced in the future to recognize impairment losses on the tangibleor intangible assets and/or goodwill of the Opportunity Banks.

blobs.text:
According to International Financial Reporting Standard 3 relating to business combinations (“IFRS 3”) and In-
ternational Accounting Standard 36 relating to impairment of assets (“IAS 36”), any potential difference between the
consideration paid for the Opportunity Banks and the fair value of their identified assets and liabilities, including any po-
tential intangible assets that were not recognised before the Acquisition, will be recognised as goodwill and allocated to
the (group of) cash generating unit(s) (each a “CGU”) which is (are) expected to derive benefits from the Acquisition.
Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are tested at least annually, or more frequently if there is an indica-
tion of impairment. For this purpose, a single-step quantitative test is performed at the level of the (group of) CGU(s)
where the carrying amount of such (group of) CGU(s) is compared with their recoverable amount defined as the higher of
the value in use or the fair value less cost of disposal. The excess of the carrying amount over the recoverable amount has
to be recorded as an impairment loss. Tangible and intangible assets with definite lives are not tested annually, but rather
when there are indicators of impairment. As a result, we may be forced to recognize an impairment loss on the tangible
and intangible assets and/or goodwill of the Opportunity Banks in accordance with IFRS 3 and IAS 36 if unexpected dif-
ficulties were to arise in the course of the integration of the Opportunity Banks into our Group, if the Opportunity Banks’
business were to fail to develop as expected or if any other unexpected development were to occur affecting the perfor-
mance or sustainability of the Opportunity Banks’ business. Any occurrence of such impairment losses could have a ma-
terial adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
If we fail to promote and maintain our brand in a cost-effective manner, we may lose market share and our revenu

risk_factor: If we fail to promote and maintain our brand in a cost-effective manner, we may lose market share and our revenuemay decrease.

blobs.text:
We believe that developing and maintaining awareness of our brands “MyBucks”, “GetBucks,” “GetSure” and
“GetBanked” as well as our future brand “Opportunity Bank” in a cost-effective manner is critical to attracting new and
retaining existing customers to our online offering. The successful promotion of our brands will depend largely on the
effectiveness of our marketing efforts and the experience of customers with our products and services. Our efforts to
build our brands have involved significant expense, and it is likely that our future marketing efforts will require us to in-
cur significant additional expense. These brand promotion activities may not result in increased revenue and, even if they

do, any increases may not offset the expenses incurred. If we fail to successfully promote and maintain our brand or if we
incur substantial expenses in an unsuccessful attempt to promote and maintain our brand, we may lose our existing cus-
tomers to our competitors or be unable to attract new customers. The materialization of any of these risks, alone or in
combination, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our success and future growth depend significantly on our successful marketing efforts, and if we are unable to at
tract customers to our online offering, our business and future growth may be harmed.

risk_factor: Our success and future growth depend significantly on our successful marketing efforts, and if we are unable to at-tract customers to our online offering, our business and future growth may be harmed.

blobs.text:
We intend to continue to dedicate significant resources to our marketing efforts, particularly as we continue to
grow our online offering, introduce new products and services, as well as expand into new geographic markets. The suc-
cess of these marketing efforts depends in large part on the success of the marketing channels we use to promote our
online offering. Our marketing channels include social media and the press, online partnerships, search engine optimiza-
tion, search engine marketing, offline partnerships, mail-to-web and radio and television advertising. If any or all of our
current marketing channels become less effective, if we are unable to continue to use any of these channels, if the cost of
using these channels were to significantly increase or if we are not successful in generating new channels, we may not be
able to attract new or retain existing customers in a cost-effective manner or convert potential customers into active cus-
tomers, any of which could impair our ability to grow our business and have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.
Negative publicity due to customer complaints, litigation or other factors, and a negative public perception of our

risk_factor: Negative publicity due to customer complaints, litigation or other factors, and a negative public perception of ourbusiness or our industry in general, could cause demand for our products to significantly decrease.

blobs.text:
Our reputation is very important to attract new and retain existing customers, as well as to cross-selling new prod-
ucts. While we believe that we have a good reputation and that we provide our customers with a superior experience,
there can be no assurance that we will continue to maintain a good relationship with our customers or avoid negative
publicity. Negative publicity about our industry, our company or our management, including the quality and reliability of
our online offering and the effectiveness of our credit decisioning and scoring model system, could adversely affect our
reputation and the confidence in, and the use of, our offering.
Such harm to our reputation can arise due to many reasons, including

In addition, due to our primary engagement in the market for small unsecured consumer loans, we are exposed to
the risk that our operations and products may become subject of an advanced public scrutiny and tightening regulatory
and transparency requirements. In recent years, there has been an increase in the amount of negative media coverage re-
lating to short-term loans of the type we offer. Certain consumer protection bodies, consumer advocacy groups, media
reports, and a number of regulators and elected officials, in particular in Europe, have advocated government action de-
signed to prohibit or place severe restrictions on the activities of short-term consumer lenders such as us, claiming that
interest rates and fees charged to customers are, on an annualised basis, higher than those charged by credit cards issuers
or banks to more creditworthy consumers. If consumers or regulators accept the characterization of this type of loans and
lending practices as unreasonably expensive or abusive toward customers, we may experience restrictions on our ability
to advertise our products and the demand for our products could significantly decrease. Furthermore, negative media
coverage and adverse public statements that allege some form of corporate wrongdoing may make it more difficult for us
to attract and retain qualified employees and management, as well as divert management attention and increase hiring ex-
penses.

Any damage to our reputation arising from negative publicity, or the hardening of a negative perception of our
business or our industry in general, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of
operations.

We are subject to cyber-security risks and any failure to operate, maintain, integrate and scale our network and mo-
bile infrastructure and our other technology could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition

risk_factor: We are subject to cyber-security risks and any failure to operate, maintain, integrate and scale our network and mo-bile infrastructure and our other technology could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial conditionand results of operations.

blobs.text:
Due to the diverse use of automated processes and controls, our IT systems are an essential component of our
business. We are dependent on the smooth functioning of our IT systems, in particular our internet and mobile infrastruc-
ture, which are critical to our business and inherently subject to various operating risks. We need to maintain reliable in-
ternet and mobile networks with the necessary speed, data capacity and security, as well as ensuring timely development
of complementary products. Accordingly, we have improved our current systems continuously, developed new systems,

and introduced comprehensive maintenance schemes for our existing software. We utilize our cloud-based proprietary
customer interface and loan management system “FinCloud”, which provides control and automation of day-to-day busi-
ness. However, due to the automated nature of our platform, all our web-based services are potentially vulnerable to
cyber-security risks such as system failures, denial-of-service attacks, computer viruses, physical or electronic break-ins
and similar disruptions as well as online theft through fraudulent transactions and inappropriate use of access codes, user
IDs, usernames, PINs, and passwords.

While we have incurred no material cyber-attacks or security breaches to date, a number of other companies have
disclosed cyber-attacks and security breaches, some of which have involved intentional attacks. Attacks may be targeted
at us, our customers, or both. Although we devote resources to maintain and regularly upgrade our systems and processes
that are designed to protect the security of our computer systems, software, networks and other technology assets and the
confidentiality, integrity and availability of information belonging to us and our customers, there is no assurance that our
security measures will provide absolute security. Despite our efforts to ensure the integrity of our systems, it is possible
that we may not be able to anticipate or to implement effective preventive measures against all security breaches of these
types, especially because the techniques used change frequently or are not recognized until launched, and because cyber-
attacks can originate from a wide variety of sources, including third parties outside the company such as persons who are
involved with organized crime or associated with external service providers or who may be linked to terrorist organiza-
tions or hostile foreign governments. If an actual or perceived breach of security occurs, customer perception of the effec-
tiveness of our security measures could be harmed which could result in the loss of customers. Actual or anticipated at-
tacks and risks may cause us to incur increased costs, including costs to deploy additional personnel and protection tech-
nologies, train employees, and engage third party experts and consultants.

In addition, the software we use in our daily operations is highly complex and may contain undetected technical
errors that could cause our IT systems to fail. Because each loan that we make involves our proprietary automated ap-
proval process, any failure of our computer systems involving our automated approval process and any technical or other
errors contained in the software pertaining to our automated approval process could compromise our ability to accurately
evaluate potential customers, which would negatively impact our results of operations. Furthermore, any failure of our
computer systems could cause an interruption in operations, affect the security or availability of our websites, prevent
customers from accessing our websites and result in limited capacity, reduced demand, processing delays and loss of cus-
tomers.

The realization of any of these risks, alone or in combination, could have a material adverse effect on our busi-
ness, financial condition and results of operations.

We rely on third-party service providers. Any disruption of service at these third-party providers could interrupt or de
lay our ability to deliver our services to our customers.

risk_factor: We rely on third-party service providers. Any disruption of service at these third-party providers could interrupt or de-lay our ability to deliver our services to our customers.

blobs.text:
We currently serve our customers from two co-located third-party data centres in Johannesburg and Amsterdam
which are operated by third-party providers to ensure redundant capacity. The continuous availability of our service de-
pends on the operations of these facilities, and on a variety of other network service providers. In addition, we depend on
the ability of our third-party facility providers to protect the facilities against damage or interruption from natural disas-
ters, power or telecommunications failures, criminal acts and similar events. If there are any lapses of service or damage
to the facilities, we could experience lengthy interruptions in our service as well as delays and additional expenses in ar-
ranging new facilities and services. Even with current and planned disaster recovery arrangements, our business could be
harmed.

We designed our system infrastructure and procure and own or lease the computer hardware used for our services.
Design and mechanical errors, failure to follow operations protocols and procedures could cause our systems to fail, re-
sulting in interruptions of our platform. Any such interruptions or delays, whether as a result of third-party error, our own
error, natural disasters or security breaches, whether accidental or wilful, could harm our relationships with customers
and cause our revenue to decrease and/or our expenses to increase. Also, in the event of damage or interruption, our in-
surance policies may not adequately compensate us for any losses that we may incur. These factors in turn could further
reduce our revenue and subject us to liability, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial con-
dition and results of operations.

Security breaches of customers’ confidential information that we store may harm our reputation and expose us to lia-
bility.

risk_factor: Security breaches of customers’ confidential information that we store may harm our reputation and expose us to lia-bility.

blobs.text:
Our business involves the storage and transmission of our customers’ proprietary information and other sensitive
data. Any accidental or wilful security breaches or other unauthorised access to such confidential information could ex-
pose us to a risk of loss or misuse of this information, negative publicity, litigation, and potential liability. If security
measures are breached because of third-party action, employee error, malfeasance or otherwise, or if design flaws in our
software are exposed and exploited, and, as a result, a third party obtains unauthorised access to any of our customers’
data, our relationships with our customers will be severely damaged, we could incur significant liability, and authorities
may impose fines and penalties on us.

Because techniques used to obtain unauthorised access or to sabotage systems change frequently and generally are
not recognized until they are launched against a target, we and our third-party service providers may be unable to antici-

nd o
 56

pate these techniques or to implement adequate preventative measures. In addition, many countries have enacted laws
requiring companies to notify individuals of data security breaches involving their personal data. These mandatory dis-
closures regarding a security breach are costly to implement and often lead to widespread negative publicity, which may
cause our customers to lose confidence in the effectiveness of our data security measures. Any security breach, whether
actual or perceived, could harm our reputation and we could lose customers.

The realization of any of these risks, alone or in combination, could have a material adverse effect on our busi-
ness, financial condition and results of operations.
Some aspects of our platform include open source software, and any failure to comply with the terms of one or more

risk_factor: Some aspects of our platform include open source software, and any failure to comply with the terms of one or moreof these open source licenses could negatively affect our business.

blobs.text:
We incorporate open source software into our proprietary platform and into other processes supporting our busi-
ness. Such open source software may include software covered by licenses like the GNU General Public License and the
Apache License. The terms of various open source licenses have not been interpreted by courts, and there is a risk that
such licenses could be construed in a manner that limits our use of the software, inhibits certain aspects of the platform
and negatively affects our business operations.

Some open source licenses contain requirements that we make available source code for modifications or deriva-
tive works we create based upon the type of open source software we use. If portions of our proprietary platform are de-
termined to be subject to an open source license, or if the license terms for the open source software that we incorporate
change, we could be required to publicly release the affected portions of our source code, re-engineer all or a portion of
our platform or change our business activities. In addition to risks related to license requirements, the use of open source
software can lead to greater risks than the use of third-party commercial software, as open source licensors generally do
not provide warranties or controls on the origin of the software. Many of the risks associated with the use of open source
software cannot be eliminated, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.
If we are not able to compete effectively, our results of operations could be harmed.

risk_factor: If we are not able to compete effectively, our results of operations could be harmed.

blobs.text:
The consumer lending industry in which we operate is competitive, fast-growing and evolving, and we believe
that particularly the markets for short-term consumer loans may become even more competitive as the industry consoli-
dates. With respect to customers, we primarily compete with traditional “bricks and mortar” institutions, such as banks,
microfinance institutions (“MFIs”) and credit unions, but also other technology-enabled consumer finance companies,
including FinTech, and small local lending companies called payday lenders that own a limited number of customers and
usually operate in one country only. In addition, we also compete with competitors which offer other forms of short-term
financing such as peer-to-peer loans and credit cards.

Many of our competitors operate with different business models, have different cost structures or participate selec-
tively in different market segments. While we primarily focus on the short-term lending in the low-to-middle income
consumer segment, some of our competitors offer a broader range of financial products and services and/or focus on a
broader customer base. They may ultimately prove more successful or more adaptable to new regulatory, technological
and other developments. Some of our current or potential competitors have significantly more financial, technical, mar-
keting and other resources than we do and may be able to devote greater resources to the development, promotion, sale
and support of their platforms and distribution channels. Our potential competitors may also have longer operating histo-
ries, more extensive customer bases, greater brand recognition and brand loyalty and broader customer and partner rela-
tionships than we have. Many banks and other financial institutions, as well as consumer loan companies that do not cur-
rently offer products or services directed toward our customer base, could begin doing so, or new online lending compa-
nies could enter the markets in which we operate. Additionally, current or potential competitors may acquire one of our
existing competitors or form a strategic alliance with one of our competitors. Our competitors may be better at develop-
ing new products, responding quickly to new technologies and undertaking more extensive marketing campaigns.

If we are unable to compete with such companies and meet the need for innovation in our industry, the demand for
our products and services could stagnate or substantially decline, we could experience reduced revenue or we could fail
to achieve or maintain our market acceptance, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our future growth as
well as on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

To date, we derive a substantial part of our revenue from a single line of business. If we fail to develop and expand
into new business lines, we may not succeed in growing our business and to diversify our revenue streams.

risk_factor: To date, we derive a substantial part of our revenue from a single line of business. If we fail to develop and expandinto new business lines, we may not succeed in growing our business and to diversify our revenue streams.

blobs.text:
Historically, we have focused on the lending products and services which we offer under our GetBucks brand, in
particular short-term consumer and instalment loans. We plan to address additional markets and expand the type of insur-
ance and banking products and services we offer to further grow our business, including taking deposits from customers
or potentially issuing longer term loans. As we aim to become a true virtual bank, we have also recently acquired Oppor-
tunity Banks to significantly increase our customer base, to gain deposit taking licenses for Ghana, Malawi, Mozambique
and Uganda and to combine our products, credit expertise and technology with Opportunity Banks’ network, customer
base and expertise in using financial services. While we intend to broaden the scope of our products and services and our

customer base, there can be no assurance that we will be successful in such efforts. Any failure to successfully address
additional market segments with our products and services, to establish a broader customer base could inhibit our future
growth and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Any failure by us to develop and successfully introduce new and attractive products, could have a material adverse ef-
fect on our business, financial position and results of operations.

risk_factor: Any failure by us to develop and successfully introduce new and attractive products, could have a material adverse ef-fect on our business, financial position and results of operations.

blobs.text:
We operate in the financial services industry which is characterized by rapidly evolving technology and frequent
product introductions. Therefore, the ability to anticipate technological trends and respond to customer needs by develop-
ing innovative solutions and introducing new products in a timely manner is crucial in our business. In recent years, we
have continuously diversified our product portfolio, which now consists of short-term and instalment loans, as well as
insurance and banking products. However, the process of developing new technologies, products or services is complex.
Each modification, new product or service, or any alternative method of conducting business – even when based on the
same processes, systems, and scoring as the existing products and services – is subject to risk and uncertainty and re-
quires significant investment in time and capital, including additional marketing expenses, legal costs and other incre-
mental start-up costs. We may not be able to recover investments we have made in order to develop and bring these new
products, services or processes to the market, and may not have sufficient resources to keep pace with technological de-
velopments. If we fail to keep pace with the evolving technological innovations in our markets, to successfully innovate
and develop new products and services, to deliver a superior customer experience, to adequately predict our customers’
needs, or if our future products and/or services do not achieve adequate acceptance in the market or proof otherwise un-
successful, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
We are subject to management and accounting risks.

risk_factor: We are subject to management and accounting risks.

blobs.text:
We could incur substantial losses and our business operations could be disrupted if we are unable to effectively
identify, manage, monitor and mitigate financial risks, such as credit risk, interest rate risk, liquidity risk, and other mar-
ket-related risk, as well as operational risks related to our business, assets and liabilities. Our risk management policies,
procedures, and techniques may not be sufficient to identify all of the risks we are exposed to, mitigate the risks that we
have identified or identify concentrations of risk or additional risks to which we may become subject in the future. Alt-
hough we have taken up limited insurance coverage to conform to market practice for listed companies, there is no guar-
antee that our insurance policies will adequately cover all material risks we face.

In addition, the preparation of our financial statements requires our management to make estimates, assumptions,
and forecasts regarding the future. These estimates, assumptions, and forecasts may be inaccurate and are inherently sub-
ject to uncertainties. Future developments may deviate significantly from the assumptions made if changes occur in the
business environment and/or business operations. Furthermore, our management is required to use its judgment in the
application of the International Financial Reporting Standards (“IFRS”) in the preparation of our financial statements and
their interpretations are subject to change over time. In case of inadvertent errors in accounting and/or management deci-
sions, or if new rules or interpretations of existing rules require us to change our financial reporting, this could pose a
threat to our business or require us to change or restate our historical financial reporting.

The materialization of any of such risks, alone or in combination, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

The proposed changes in accounting standards, such as IFRS 9, could have a substantial negative impact on ou
capital position.

risk_factor: The proposed changes in accounting standards, such as IFRS 9, could have a substantial negative impact on ourcapital position.

blobs.text:
On 24 July 2014, the International Accounting Standards Board (“IASB”), the international body responsible for
the development of the International Accounting Standards (“IAS”) and IFRS, published the final version of the new
IFRS 9 relating to financial instruments (“IFRS 9”), which will replace the International Accounting Standard 39 relating
to financial instruments (recognition and measurement) (“IAS 39”) as of 1 January 2018. As part of IFRS 9, a new set of
rules for classification will be introduced which could have an impact on the way financial assets are presented and
measured on the face of the balance sheet. In particular, a new, expected-loss impairment model is going to be introduced
that will require more timely recognition of expected credit losses. Specifically, the new IFRS 9 requires entities to ac-
count for expected credit losses from when financial instruments are first recognised and to recognise full lifetime ex-
pected losses on a more timely basis. The implementation of IFRS 9 may have a significant impact on the financial
statements of financial service companies like us. In particular, IFRS 9 could lead to a substantial one-off increase in im-
pairment allowances for certain financial assets. If these estimates prove to be true, they are likely to have a material ad-
verse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the countries in which we operate. Changes in tax legisla-

        Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the countries in which we operate. Changes in tax legis-
lation, administrative practice or case law could have adverse tax consequences for us. Despite a general principle pro-

hibiting retroactive changes, amendments to applicable laws, orders and regulations can be issued or altered with retroac-
tive effect. Additionally, divergent interpretations of tax laws by the tax authorities or the tax courts are possible. These
interpretations may be changed at any time with adverse effects on our taxation. Furthermore, court decisions are often
overruled by the tax authorities by way of issuing non-application decrees. As a result, uncertainties exist with regard to
the taxation rules applicable to us. Deviating views adopted by the tax authorities or the tax courts might lead to a higher
tax burden for us. Additionally, if adverse changes in the tax framework should occur, individually or together, this could
have a material adverse effect on business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our ability to use our deferred tax assets to offset future taxable income may be subject to certain limitations that
could subject our business to higher tax liability.

We may be limited in the portion of loss carryforwards that we can use in the future to offset taxable income for
income tax purposes. As of 31 December 2015, we had loss carry-forwards of €8.3 million, to offset future taxable in-
come. These loss carryforwards will begin expiring in 2019. A lack of future taxable income would adversely affect our
ability to utilize these loss carry-forwards. We assess the available positive and negative evidence to estimate if sufficient
future taxable income will be generated to utilize the existing deferred tax assets. On the basis of this evaluation, a full
valuation allowance has historically been recorded to recognize only deferred tax assets that are more likely than not to
be realized. Our deferred tax assets may expire unutilized or underutilized, which could prevent us from offsetting future
taxable income.

Our services and operations are vulnerable to damage or interruption from tornadoes, earthquakes, fires, floods,
power losses, telecommunications failures, terrorist attacks, acts of war, human errors and similar events. A significant
natural disaster, such as a tornado, earthquake, fire, or flood for which we may not have insurance coverage could have a
