cause consumer confidence to decrease, which could result in a decreased number of loans being made to customers. Any

We have invested heavily in promoting our brands, including our website addresses. The Internet Corporation for
Assigned Names and Numbers (“ICANN”), the entity responsible for administering internet protocol addresses, has in-
troduced, and has proposed the introduction of, additional new domain name suffixes in different formats, many of which

may be more attractive than the formats held by us and which may allow the entrance of new competitors at limited cost.
ICANN may also permit other operators to register websites with addresses similar to ours, causing customer confusion
and dilution of our brands. Any defensive domain registration strategy or attempts to protect our trademarks or brands
could become a large and recurring expense and may not be successful which may have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.
Regulatory and Legal Risks

Because the lending industry is highly regulated, we are subject to various credit acts, consumer protection laws, other
local legal and regulatory requirements, changes of which or interpretations of which by the relevant authorities
could significantly impact our business.

risk_factor: Because the lending industry is highly regulated, we are subject to various credit acts, consumer protection laws, otherlocal legal and regulatory requirements, changes of which or interpretations of which by the relevant authoritiescould significantly impact our business.

blobs.text:
The regulatory environment in which lending institutions operate has become increasingly complex, and follow-
ing the financial and economic crisis in 2008 and 2009, supervisory efforts to enact and apply relevant laws, regulations
and policies have become more intense. Changes in laws or regulations or the regulatory application or judicial interpre-
tation of the laws and regulations applicable to us could adversely affect our ability to operate in the manner in which we
currently conduct business or make it more difficult or costly for us to originate or otherwise make additional loans, or
for us to collect payments on loans by subjecting us to additional licensing, registration and other regulatory requirements
in the future or otherwise. In some cases such changes may even render our current business activities in certain jurisdic-
tions unprofitable and/or impractical to continue. For example, if one or more countries in which we use the deduction-
at-source method to collect payments should decide to amend regulation to restrict or prohibit this method, such as Bot-
swana and Swaziland, who have already discussed or increased regulation on deduction-at-source lending, the number of
customers for which we can use this collection method would decline which could significantly impair our overall debt
collections rate. Any material failure to comply with applicable laws or regulations, or their interpretations and enforce-
ments by regulatory authorities, could result in regulatory actions and lawsuits or subject us to liability, all of which
could damage our reputation and customer relationships, and affect our ability to originate and service loans. Any pro-
ceeding relating to one or more allegations or findings of our violation of such laws could also result in modifications in
our methods of doing business which may impair our ability to collect payments on our loans or to acquire additional
loans or could result in the requirement that we pay damages and/or cancel the balance or other amounts owing under
loans associated with such violation. To the extent it is determined that the loans we make to our customers were not
originated in accordance with all applicable laws, we may also be obliged to repurchase from the customer the applicable
loan.

The materialization of any of such risks, alone or in combination, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

We may fail to successfully manage the diverse sets of regulatory requirements we currently are subject to and ma
face regulatory problems entering into new markets.

risk_factor: We may fail to successfully manage the diverse sets of regulatory requirements we currently are subject to and mayface regulatory problems entering into new markets.

blobs.text:
Our business operations in a wide set of different jurisdictions in Sub-Saharan Africa and Europe with diverse
statutory requirements require careful management of the variety of legal and regulatory challenges, including but not
limited to: (i) license requirements, (ii) maximum interest rate regulations, (iii) digital or distance contracts regulations,
and (iv) consumer protection legislation. These diverse legal frameworks implicate various legal and regulatory risks, in-
cluding, but not limited to, the risks of market entry into new jurisdictions. The legal requirements for launching our
business in new jurisdictions may also vary significantly with some jurisdictions having no registration/license require-
ments, while some jurisdictions requiring licenses, e.g., deposit taking or banking licenses. In addition, the collection of
payments by way of a deduction-at-source mechanism which currently is the core element of our risk management may
not be possible or severely restricted in the new markets we enter. Entering new jurisdictions may also implicate chal-
lenging legal requirements on a local level. In addition, the diversification of our Group would also increase our legal and
compliance costs.

If we fail to successfully manage the diverse sets of regulatory requirements we currently are subject to or comply
with the applicable local legal requirements, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
and results of operations.

Our business operations may be challenged by consumers, consumer protection organizations, courts, or regulatory
agencies in connection with compliance with applicable legal requirements.

risk_factor: Our business operations may be challenged by consumers, consumer protection organizations, courts, or regulatoryagencies in connection with compliance with applicable legal requirements.

blobs.text:
In recent years, consumer loans have come under increased regulatory scrutiny that has resulted in increasingly re-
strictive regulations and legislation that makes offering such loans in certain jurisdictions less profitable or unattractive.
For example, the Directive 2008/48/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2008 on credit agree-
ments for consumers (the “EU Consumer Credit Directive”), which entered into force in May 2008, mandates disclo-
sure of a standardized annual percentage rate (“APR”) figure for all consumer credit products. Due to the nature of our
business model, whereby in most countries in which we operate, small loan amounts are offered for very short periods of
time, the extrapolated APRs may appear to be far higher than standard market APRs offered by other consumer credit
companies and may therefore create an incorrect impression of the actual business relationship between us and our cus-

tomers. The disclosure of high APRs may thus mislead consumers, consumer protection organizations, courts, or regula-
tory agencies in the belief that we are in violation of EU or local consumer protection and consumer credit regulations,
specifically regarding interest rate caps. It is thus possible that legal or regulatory challenges may be brought against us
regarding noncompliance with existing, amended, or new consumer protection or consumer credit laws. Adverse judg-
ments based on such findings could result in legal claims and reputational damage against us.

It is also possible that new or amended statutory requirements may require us to further adapt our practices and
procedures. Certain consumer advocacy groups and regulators have advocated that laws and regulations should be
amended so as to severely limit, if not eliminate, the type of loan products and services we offer. Such proposed legisla-
tion could, among other things, place a cap on the interest or fees that we can charge or a cap on the effective APR that
limits the amount of interest or fees that may be charged, ban or limit loan renewals or extensions, including the rates to
be charged for loan renewals or extensions, require us to offer an extended payment plan, allow for only minimal origina-
tion fees for advances, require changes to our underwriting or collections practices, require short-term lenders to be
bonded or require lenders to report consumer loan activity to databases designed to monitor or restrict consumer borrow-
ing activity or impose “cooling off” periods between the time a loan is paid off and another loan is obtained. For exam-
ple, in South Africa, the National Credit Act No. 34 of 2005, as amended (the “National Credit Act”) prescribes limits
on interest rates for all forms of credit since June 2007. As of May 2016, new limits for maximum interest rates and initi-
ation and servicing fees imposed on credit providers have entered into effect. Statutory interest rate caps have also been
adopted in Poland. The Namibian market has an annual interest rate cap corresponding to the bank prime rate plus 9 per-
centage points. Interest rate caps may be introduced in other regions. We may also in the future become subject to laws
and restrictions related to performing deduction-at-source collections or direct debit transactions from customers’ bank
accounts. Such statutory changes and/or additions may negatively impact our financial position and may require changes
to our business model. It is additionally possible that consumers, consumer protection organizations, courts, or regulatory
agencies challenge our compliance with existing, amended, or new consumer protection laws or initiate related investiga-
tive or judicial proceedings. Adverse judgments based on such findings could result in legal claims and reputational dam-
age against us. For example, our operating subsidiary in South African, GetBucks (Proprietary) Limited (“GetBucks
South Africa”) is currently in dispute with the National Credit Regulator (the “NCR”) which accuses GetBucks South
Africa of various breaches of the National Credit Act. The NCR has made an application with the National Consumer
Tribunal (the “NCT”), an independent adjudicative entity in South Africa, in November 2014 which may result in fines
or even in a temporary or final withdrawal of GetBucks South Africa’s registration as a credit provider in South Africa.
Although GetBucks South Africa, like other South African credit providers facing similar charges, contested this applica-
tion in March 2015 by, inter alia, requesting a declaratory order from the High Court of South Africa declining the valid-
ity and enforceability of certain regulations that were promulgated under the National Credit Act, the hearing has not yet
taken place and it is neither possible to predict the outcome of these proceedings nor of the currently pending decision of
the NCT on the NCR’s application.

All of the above factors may hamper our ability to conduct and expand our operations or force us to relocate exist-
ing operations and may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We may in the future cease business in certain jurisdictions due to regulatory restrictions, and if we are forced to exit
many key jurisdictions due to regulatory restrictions, it could adversely affect our business as a whole.

risk_factor: We may in the future cease business in certain jurisdictions due to regulatory restrictions, and if we are forced to exitmany key jurisdictions due to regulatory restrictions, it could adversely affect our business as a whole.

The adoption of regulatory measures cannot be predicted. Although we believe that our organization and our
IT systems and functions can handle adjustments to new regulatory restrictions, all adjustments to new regulations may
not be financially feasible or justifiable. If regulatory restrictions on our consumer loan products are proposed or enacted
in certain jurisdictions where we operate and the adjustments in our products or operations that are required to comply
with such restrictions are not feasible or financially justifiable, we might be forced to exit the relevant jurisdiction. If we
are forced to exit many key jurisdictions due to such concerns, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to find suitably
attractive additional business opportunities elsewhere. Such a situation may have a material adverse effect on our busi-
ness, financial condition and results of operations.
We may lose required licenses to operate our business or face challenges to maintain or renew such licenses.

risk_factor: We may lose required licenses to operate our business or face challenges to maintain or renew such licenses.

Some jurisdictions, such as Zimbabwe, require us to have licenses to operate our business. Following the closing
of the Acquisition with respect to all Opportunity Banks, these Opportunity Banks will allow us to use further licenses in
Ghana, Malawi, Mozambique and Uganda. These licenses are issued by the relevant local financial services authorities.
Under the applicable local laws, any deposit taking license may be revoked, or restricted, at any time, by the relevant lo-
cal financial services authority for a variety of reasons including, but not limited to, non-compliance with existing or new
regulatory requirements. There can be no assurance that, where a license is required, we will in all scenarios be able to
maintain, or receive renewal of, such license on commercially favourable terms or at all. Any restrictions or revocations
of our licenses could require us to comply with existing or new regulatory requirements of the relevant local financial
services authorities. Accordingly, there is a risk of delay in obtaining, maintaining or renewing a required license, which
may lead to operational delays. The loss of a license or such operational delays could, in turn, have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

The collection, processing, storage, use and disclosure of personal data could give rise to liabilities as a result of gov-
ernmental regulation, conflicting legal requirements or differing views of personal privacy rights.

risk_factor: The collection, processing, storage, use and disclosure of personal data could give rise to liabilities as a result of gov-ernmental regulation, conflicting legal requirements or differing views of personal privacy rights.

blobs.text:
We receive, collect, process, transmit, store and use a large volume of personally identifiable information and oth-
er sensitive data from customers and potential customers. In this regard, we are subject to various local and international
laws and regulations regarding privacy, recording telephone calls and the storing, sharing, use, disclosure and protection
of personally identifiable information and sensitive data. Specifically, personally identifiable information is increasingly
subject to legislation and regulations to protect the privacy of personal information that is collected, processed and
transmitted. Any violations of these laws and regulations may require us to change our business practices or operational
structure, address legal claims and sustain monetary penalties and/or other harms to our business.

The regulatory framework for privacy issues in the Sub-Saharan African and European countries in which we op-
erate and internationally is complex and constantly evolving. The existing and proposed laws and regulations are, or may
be, costly to comply with and could delay or impede the development of new products, the expansion into new markets,
result in negative publicity, increase our operating costs, require significant management time and attention, and subject
us to inquiries or investigations, claims or other remedies, including demands that we modify or cause us to cease exist-
ing business practices or pay fines, penalties or other damages. In addition, the interpretation and application of such laws
is likely to remain uncertain for the foreseeable future, and such laws may be interpreted and applied in a manner incon-
sistent with our current policies and practices or require changes to the features of our platform. Although we continuous-
ly educate our employees on applicable laws and regulations in relation to privacy, data protection and other matters, it
cannot be guaranteed that our employees at any time comply with such laws and regulations. If either we or our third par-
ty service providers are unable to address any privacy concerns, even if unfounded, or to comply with applicable laws
and regulations, it could result in additional costs and liability, damage our reputation and, as a result, have a material ad-
verse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
It may be difficult and costly to protect our intellectual property rights, and we may not be able to ensure their protec

risk_factor: It may be difficult and costly to protect our intellectual property rights, and we may not be able to ensure their protec-tion.

blobs.text:
It ma
tion.

Our ability to lend to our customers depends, in part, on our proprietary technology, including the use of our pro-
prietary credit-scoring software. We may not protect our proprietary technology effectively which may allow competitors
to duplicate our products and adversely affect our ability to compete with them. A third party may attempt to reverse en-
gineer or otherwise obtain and use our proprietary technology without our consent. The pursuit of a claim against a third
party for infringement of our intellectual property could be costly or unattainable, and there can be no guarantee that any
such efforts would be successful.

In addition, our platform may infringe upon claims of third-party intellectual property, and we may face intellec-
tual property challenges from such other parties. We may not be successful in defending against any such challenges or
in obtaining licenses to avoid or resolve any intellectual property disputes. The costs of defending any such claims or liti-
gation could be significant and, if we are unsuccessful, could result in a requirement that we pay significant damages or
licensing fees, which would negatively impact our financial performance. Furthermore, our technology may become ob-
solete, and there is no guarantee that we will be able to successfully develop, obtain or use new technologies to adapt our
platform to compete with other lending platforms as they develop. If we cannot protect our proprietary technology from
intellectual property challenges, or if the platform becomes obsolete, our ability to maintain our platform, make loans or
perform our servicing obligations on the loans could be adversely affected. As a result, this could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

The legal and judicial systems in some of the markets in which we operate are less developed than those of western
European countries.

risk_factor: The legal and judicial systems in some of the markets in which we operate are less developed than those of westernEuropean countries.

blobs.text:
European countries.
        The legal and judicial systems in some of the markets in which we operate are less developed than those of west-
ern European countries. Commercial law, competition law, securities law, anti-bribery law, personal data protection law,
company law, bankruptcy law and other areas of law in such countries are relatively new areas of law to local judges. Re-
lated legal provisions in these jurisdictions have been and continue to be subject to on-going, and at times unpredictable,
changes. Existing laws and regulations in our countries of operation may be applied inconsistently or may be interpreted
in a manner that is restrictive and non-commercial. We may be forced to change our existing customer identification pol-
icies if we receive an unfavourable ruling. Furthermore, it may not be possible, in certain circumstances, to obtain legal
remedies in a timely manner in these countries. The relatively limited experience of a significant number of the magis-
trates practicing in these markets, specifically with regard to capital markets issues, and the existence of a number of is-
sues relating to the independence of the judiciary system may lead to ungrounded decisions or to decisions based on con-
siderations that are not grounded in the law. The enforcement of judgments may also prove difficult, which means that
the enforcement of rights through the respective court systems may be laborious, especially where such judgments may
lead to business closures or job losses. This lack of legal certainty could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.
Failure to comply with anti-money laundering laws could have an adverse effect on our reputation and business.

risk_factor: Failure to comply with anti-money laundering laws could have an adverse effect on our reputation and business.

blobs.text:
We are subject to anti-money laundering laws and related compliance obligations in most of the jurisdictions
in which we operate. We have adopted an anti-money laundering policy and procedures for the Group which are ap-
plied in all the countries in which we operate. In jurisdictions where it is required under local law and in certain other
jurisdictions, we have also adopted local anti-money laundering policies. However, these policies may not prevent
breaches of laws. The country managers in each jurisdiction are responsible for money laundering prevention and
compliance. As the anti-money laundering regulation applicable to banks is normally more restrictive than the reg u-
lation applicable to our business, in most of our countries in which we operate, we often rely on the anti-money
laundering check that was performed by our customer’s bank before a bank account was opened for the customer. If
we or our customers’ banks are not in compliance with relevant anti -money laundering laws, we may be subject to
criminal and civil penalties and other remedial measures. Any penalties, remedial measures or investigation of any
potential violations of anti-money laundering laws by relevant authorities could harm our reputation and may have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Failure to comply with anti-corruption laws, including anti-bribery laws, could have an adverse effect on our reputa-
tion and business.

risk_factor: Failure to comply with anti-corruption laws, including anti-bribery laws, could have an adverse effect on our reputa-tion and business.

blobs.text:
While we are committed to doing business in accordance with applicable anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws, we
face the risk that any of our operating subsidiaries or their respective officers, directors, employees, agents or business
partners may take actions or have interactions with persons that violate such anti-corruption laws, or face allegations that
they have violated such laws. Corruption has also been reported to affect the judicial systems and some of the regulatory
or administrative bodies of the countries in which we operate. While we are currently in the process of developing a for-
mal Group-wide anti-bribery policy. However, these policies may not prevent breaches of law. The effects of corruption
on our operations are difficult to predict. However, under certain circumstances, corruption, particularly where it height-
ens regulatory uncertainty or leads to regulatory changes adverse to our operations or to liability of us or one of our direc-
tors, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We are subject to a diverse set of tax regimes in the jurisdictions in which we operate and changes in such tax regimes
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

risk_factor: We are subject to a diverse set of tax regimes in the jurisdictions in which we operate and changes in such tax regimescould have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

blobs.text:
We currently operate in eleven different countries in Sub-Saharan Africa and Europe and we will operate in three
additional countries upon closing of the Acquisition. As a result, we are subject to diverse sets of tax regimes, depending
on the relevant tax law applicable in each case. Corporate income tax, withholding tax, value added tax or sales taxes and
other taxes levied upon our business are subject to change, either for the future or, under certain circumstances, even for
the past, and can be increased, changed or completely restructured at any time. While we monitor tax changes consistent-
ly and have not faced any significant tax challenges or tax disputes with tax authorities in the past three years, adverse
changes to local tax regimes or challenges to the current tax structures of our business, such as possible restrictions on the
repatriation of earnings. As a result, we may face increases in taxes payable if tax rates increase, or if tax laws or regula-
tions are modified by the competent authorities in an adverse manner. Any additional or increased tax payments could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Risks Related to the Offering and the Shares

The Offering may not take place and investors could therefore loose security commissions already paid and face risks
associated with any short selling of the Shares.

risk_factor: The Offering may not take place and investors could therefore loose security commissions already paid and face risksassociated with any short selling of the Shares.

As of the date of the Prospectus, there can be no assurance that the Offering will take place. The Underwriting
Agreement will provide that the Sole Global Coordinator may terminate the Underwriting Agreement under certain cir-
cumstances. In the case of early termination of the Underwriting Agreement, the Offering will not take place. Claims re-
garding paid commissions and costs incurred in connection with the subscription by an investor will be determined solely
on the basis of the legal relationship between the investor and the institution to which the investor submitted its offer to
purchase. Allotments to investors which have already been made would be invalid. A claim on the part of the investors
for delivery of the Shares will not exist in this case. If an investor has engaged in short sales, the investor bears the risk of
not being able to deliver the Shares in performance of its obligations thereunder.

Following the Offering, our major shareholders will continue to hold a substantial shareholding in the Company a
may be, or get, in the position to exert substantial influence on the Company. The interests pursued by these shar
holders could differ from the interests of our other shareholders.

risk_factor: Following the Offering, our major shareholders will continue to hold a substantial shareholding in the Company andmay be, or get, in the position to exert substantial influence on the Company. The interests pursued by these share-holders could differ from the interests of our other shareholders.

blobs.text:
Following the successful completion of this Offering, our major shareholders will continue to hold a substantial
part of the issued and outstanding share capital of the Company. The interests of these major shareholders may be, or be-
come, different from our interests or those of our other shareholders. Due to their substantial interest in the Company, our
major shareholders may be, or get, in the position to exert substantial influence on the general shareholders’ meeting of
the Company (the “General Meeting”) and, consequently, on matters decided by the General Meeting, including the ap-
pointment of the members of the Company’s board of directors (the “Board”), the distribution of dividends or any pro-

posed capital measure. A concentration of share ownership at shareholder level could delay, postpone or prevent certain
major corporate actions, including a change of control in the Company, and could thus deter mergers, consolidations, ac-
quisitions or other forms of combination that might be advantageous for investors. In addition, our major shareholders
may be, or become, able to block certain corporate measures that require the approval of the General Meeting and may
have the effect of delaying, postponing or preventing certain major corporate actions, including a change of control in the
Company, and could thus prevent mergers, consolidations, acquisitions or other forms of combination that might be ad-
vantageous for investors.

Under the above instances, the interests of our major shareholders could deviate from the interests of our other
shareholders. If our major shareholders’ interests conflict with those of our other shareholders, the consequences may
have a material adverse effect on the value of our Shares and our business, financial condition and results of operations.
The Shares have not been publicly traded, and there is no guarantee that an active and liquid market for our Shares

risk_factor: The Shares have not been publicly traded, and there is no guarantee that an active and liquid market for our Shareswill develop.

blobs.text:
Prior to this Offering, there has been no public market for the Shares. The issue price of the Offered Shares will be
determined by way of a bookbuilding process. Such issue price may not correspond to the price at which the Shares will
be traded on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange after the Offering and may differ from the book value of our consolidated net
assets. In addition, there is no guarantee that, following the listing, liquid trading in the Shares will develop and become
established. As a result, investors may not be in a position to sell their Shares quickly or at the market price if there is no
active trading in our Shares.

Our share price and trading volume may fluctuate significantly, and investors could lose all or part of their invest-
ment.

risk_factor: Our share price and trading volume may fluctuate significantly, and investors could lose all or part of their invest-ment.

blobs.text:
Following this Offering, the price and trading volume of the Shares will be affected primarily by the supply and
demand for the Shares and could fluctuate significantly in response to numerous factors, many of which are beyond our
control, including, but not limited to, fluctuations in actual or projected results of operations, changes in projected earn-
ings or failure to meet securities analysts’ earnings expectations, the absence of analyst coverage on our company,
changes in trading volumes in the Shares, changes in macroeconomic conditions, the activities of competitors, changes in
the market valuations of similar companies, changes in investor and analyst perception in the Company or our industry,
changes in the statutory framework in which we operate and other factors, and can therefore be subject to substantial
fluctuations. In addition, general market conditions and fluctuations of share prices and trading volumes generally could
lead to pricing pressures on the Shares, even though there may not be a reason for this based on our business performance
or earnings outlook. In particular, public perception of the Company as an internet, e-commerce or financial technology
company could result in our share price moving in line with the prices of other shares in companies of this nature, which
have traditionally tended to be more volatile than the share prices of companies operating in other industries. If the price
or the trading volume of the Shares decline as a result of the realization of any or all of these events, investors may be
unable to resell the Shares at or above their purchase price. As a result, investors could lose part or all of their investment
in the Shares.

As a result of becoming a publicly traded company, we will face additional administrative requirements and inc
higher on-going costs.

risk_factor: As a result of becoming a publicly traded company, we will face additional administrative requirements and incurhigher on-going costs.

blobs.text:
higher on-going costs.
        As a public company, we will be subject to the reporting requirements of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange and other
applicable securities laws and regulations in the Federal Republic of Germany (“Germany”) and the Grand Duchy of
Luxembourg (“Luxembourg”). These requirements include periodic financial reporting and other public disclosures of
information, regular calls with securities and industry analysts, and other required disclosures. Compliance with these
rules and regulations will increase our legal and financial compliance costs, make some activities more difficult, time-
consuming or costly, and increase demand on our systems and resources. Among other things, we will be required to
publish ad hoc announcements, file annual reports with respect to our business and operating results and maintain effec-
tive disclosure controls and procedures and internal control over financial reporting. In order to maintain and, if required,
improve our disclosure controls and procedures and internal control over financial reporting to meet this standard, signif-
icant resources and management oversight may be required. As a result, management’s attention may be diverted from
other business concerns, which could harm our business, financial position and results of operations. Although we have
already hired additional employees to comply with these requirements, we may need to hire even more employees in the
future, which will increase our costs and expenses.

In addition, changing laws, regulations and standards relating to corporate governance and public disclosure are
creating uncertainty for public companies, increasing legal and financial compliance costs and making some activities
more time consuming. These laws, regulations and standards are subject to varying interpretations, in many cases due to
their lack of specificity, and, as a result, their application in practice may evolve over time as new guidance is provided
by regulatory and governing bodies. This could result in continuing uncertainty regarding compliance matters and higher
costs necessitated by on-going revisions to disclosure and governance practices. We intend to invest resources to comply
with evolving laws, regulations and standards, and this investment may result in increased general and administrative ex-

penses and a diversion of management’s time and attention from revenue-generating activities to compliance activities. If
our efforts to comply with new laws, regulations and standards differ from the activities intended by regulatory or gov-
erning bodies, regulatory authorities may initiate legal proceedings against us and our business may be harmed.

We also expect that these new rules and regulations will make it more expensive for us as a public company to ob-
tain director and officer liability insurance, and we may be required to accept reduced coverage or incur substantially
higher costs to obtain coverage. These factors could also make it more difficult for us to attract and retain qualified mem-
bers of our Board, particularly to serve on our committees and as qualified executive officers.

The payment of future dividends will depend on a variety of factors, including distributions or transfer of profits from
our operating subsidiaries to us, as well as our financial position and results of operations.

risk_factor: The payment of future dividends will depend on a variety of factors, including distributions or transfer of profits fromour operating subsidiaries to us, as well as our financial position and results of operations.

blobs.text:
our operating subsidiaries to us, as well as our financial position and results of operations.
        Our General Meeting will decide on matters relating to the payment of future dividends. Such decisions are based
on our particular situation at the time, including our earnings, financial and investment needs, and the availability of dis-
tributable balance sheet profit and reserves. Because the Company is a holding company that conducts its operational
business mainly through its subsidiaries, its ability to pay dividends depends directly on our operating subsidiaries’ dis-
tributions of earnings to the Company. The amount and timing of such distributions and repayments will depend on the
laws of the operating subsidiaries’ respective jurisdictions and the terms of any relevant intercompany financing ar-
rangements. Any adverse changes to such laws, including possible restrictions on the repatriation of profits, or terms, or
any foreign exchange controls imposed based on such laws by one or more countries in which we operate, or the denial
or withdrawal of any reserve bank approval which may be required under such laws, could prevent the Company from
receiving sufficient distributions from its subsidiaries to pay dividends. In addition, the Company’s or its operating sub-
sidiaries’ debt financing arrangements contain, or may contain, covenants that place certain restrictions on the Compa-
ny’s ability to pay dividends or its operating subsidiaries’ ability to distribute earnings to the Company under certain cir-
cumstances. Any of these factors, individually or in combination, could restrict the Company’s ability to pay dividends.
Future offerings of debt or equity securities by us may adversely affect the market price of the Shares, and future

risk_factor: Future offerings of debt or equity securities by us may adversely affect the market price of the Shares, and futurecapitalization measures could lead to substantial dilution of our existing shareholders’ interests in the Company.

blobs.text:
We may require additional capital in the future to finance our business operations and growth. In the future, we
may seek to raise capital through offerings of debt securities (potentially including convertible debt securities) or addi-
tional equity securities. An issuance of additional equity securities or securities with a right to convert into equity, such as
convertible debentures and option debentures, could potentially reduce the market price of the Shares and would dilute
the economic and voting rights of existing shareholders if made without granting subscription rights to existing share-
holders. Because the timing and nature of any future offering would depend on market conditions at the time of such an
offering, we cannot predict or estimate the amount, timing or nature of future offerings. In addition, the acquisition of
other companies or investments in companies in exchange for newly issued Shares, as well as the exercise of stock op-
tions by our employees in the context of possible future stock option programs or the issuance of Shares to employees in
the context of possible future employee stock participation programs, could lead to a dilution of the economic and voting
rights of existing shareholders. Our shareholders thus bear the risk that such future offerings could reduce the market
price of our Shares and/or dilute their shareholdings.
Any future sales of Shares by our major shareholders could depress the market price of the Shares.

risk_factor: Any future sales of Shares by our major shareholders could depress the market price of the Shares.

blobs.text:
If following successful completion of this Offering and upon the expiration of the lock-up arrangements as agreed
in the Underwriting Agreement, one or more of our major shareholders effect a sale or sales of a substantial number of
Shares in the stock market, or if the market believes that such sales might occur, the market price of our Shares could de-
cline. This could also impair our ability to raise capital through the sale of additional equity securities.

An investment in the Shares by an investor whose principal currency is not Euro may be affected by exchange rat
fluctuations.

risk_factor: An investment in the Shares by an investor whose principal currency is not Euro may be affected by exchange ratefluctuations.

blobs.text:
The Shares are, and any dividends to be paid in respect of them will be, denominated in Euro. Therefore, an in-
vestment in the Shares by an investor whose principal currency is not Euro exposes such investor to foreign currency ex-
change rate risks. In case of any depreciation of the Euro in relation to such investor’s principal currency, the value of the
investment in the Shares and any dividend distributions or profits realized upon the sale of Shares, if any, will be reduced
in relation to such currency and may be lower than expected. Such investor could also incur additional costs in convert-
ing Euro into another currency. In addition, authorities in the jurisdiction in which the financial activities of a shareholder
may impose or modify currency exchange control with the effect that the relevant shareholder may receive fewer divi-
dends than expected.
Fluctuation of market interest rates may have an adverse effect on the value of the Shares.

risk_factor: Fluctuation of market interest rates may have an adverse effect on the value of the Shares.

blobs.text:
One of the factors that investors may consider in deciding whether to buy or sell the Shares is the expected divi-
dend yield, or the expected dividend payment per Share as a percentage of the Share price. If market interest rates in-
crease, prospective investors may desire a higher rate of return on the Shares and therefore may seek securities paying

higher dividends or interest or offering a higher rate of return than that of the Shares. As a result, market interest rate
fluctuations and other capital market conditions can affect the demand for and market value of the Shares. For instance, if
interest rates rise, the market price of the Shares may decrease, because current stockholders and potential investors will
likely require a higher dividend yield and rate of return on the Shares, as interest-bearing securities, such as bonds, offer
more attractive returns.

THE OFFERING
Subject Matter of the Offering
The Offering relates to the sale of up to 2,300,000 Shares (to be dematerialised), consisting
g of:

   up to 2,000,000 New Shares; and
   up to 300,000 Over-allotment Shares.

The Offering consists of (i) an offer to the public of the Offered Shares in Germany and Luxembourg, and (ii) pri-
vate placements to institutional investors outside Germany, Luxembourg and the United States of America (the “United
States”) in reliance on Regulation S (“Regulation S”) under the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the “Securi-
ties Act”) (the “Offering”).

The capital increase against cash contributions from authorised capital to issue the New Shares is expected to be
resolved by the Board on or about 24 May 2016, which will result in a capital increase of the Company’s share capital of
up to €2.0 million. Assuming that this capital increase is resolved by the Board in the maximum amount, the share capital
of the Company will amount to 11,998,000 and the Offered Shares will total up to 2,000,000. Thus, a maximum of 18.7%
of the Shares (after effectuation of the issuance of all New Shares and full exercise of the Greenshoe Option) will be of-
fered (a maximum of 16.7% without the Over-Allotment Shares).

The Company will receive the proceeds of the Offering resulting from the sale of New Shares and, if and to the
extent the Greenshoe Option is exercised, from the exercise of the Greenshoe Option, in each case after deduction of
payable commissions and expenses.

Hauck & Aufhäuser Privatbankiers KGaA, Kaiserstraße 24, 60311 Frankfurt am Main (“Hauck & Aufhäuser”)
is acting as sole global coordinator and sole bookrunner (“Sole Global Coordinator”) offering the Offered Shares for
sale.

The Offering shall occur through the publication of the Prospectus in electronic form on the website of the Com-
pany (www.mybucks.com) and on the website of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange (www.bourse.lu).
Price Range, Offer Period, Offer Price and Allotment

The price range within which offers to purchase may be submitted is between €13.50 to €16.50 per Offered Share
(the “Price Range”).

The period during which investors may submit purchase orders for the Offered Shares is expected to begin on
13 May 2016 and to end on 24 May 2016 (the “Offer Period”). On the last day of the Offer Period, offers to purchase
may be submitted (i) until 12:00 noon (Central European Summer Time) (“CEST”) for private and retail investors (natu-
ral persons) and at 14:00 CEST for institutional investors. Investors may submit purchase orders at the branch offices of
the Sole Global Coordinator in Germany and Luxembourg (Hauck & Aufhäuser Privatbankiers KGaA, Luxembourg
Branch, 1c, rue Gabriel Lippmann, L-5365 Munsbach, Luxembourg) during the Offer Period. Purchase orders must be of
at least 10 Offered Shares and be denominated in full Euro amounts or Euro cent figures of 25, 50, or 75 cents. There is
no maximum subscription. Multiple purchase orders are permitted. For more information, see “Underwriting—General”.

Subject to the publication of a supplement to the Prospectus, if required, the Company and the Sole Global Coor-
dinator reserve the right to increase or decrease the total number of Offered Shares, to increase or decrease the upper lim-
it and/or the lower limit of the Price range and/or to extend or shorten the Offer Period. Changes in the number of Of-
fered Shares, changes to the Price range or the extension or shortening of the Offer Period will not invalidate any offers
to purchase that have already been submitted. If such change requires the publication of a supplement to the Prospectus,
investors who submitted purchase orders before the supplement is published shall have the right, under the Luxembourg
Prospectus Law, to withdraw these offers to purchase within two business days of the publication of the supplement, pro-
vided that the new factor, mistake or inaccuracy, which required a supplement to the Prospectus, arose before the final
closing of the Offering and the delivery of the Offered Shares. Instead of withdrawing the offers to purchase placed prior
to the publication of the supplement, investors may change their orders or place new limited or unlimited offers to pur-
chase within two business days of the publication of the supplement. To the extent that the terms of the Offering are
changed, such change will be published through an announcement in various media distributed across the entire EEA and
on the Company’s website (www.mybucks.com) and, if required by law, as an ad hoc release via an electronic infor-
mation dissemination system, on the Company’s website and as a supplement to the Prospectus to be approved by the
CSSF and published on the website of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange (www.bourse.lu) and the Company’s website
(www.mybucks.com). Investors who have submitted offers to purchase will not be notified individually. Under certain
conditions, the Sole Global Coordinator may terminate the Underwriting Agreement, even after commencement of trad-
ing (Aufnahme des Handels) of the Shares on the regulated market (General Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange
(Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse). See “Underwriting—Termination/Indemnification”.

After the expiration of the Offer Period, the placement price (the “Offer Price”) and the final number of the Of-
fered Shares placed in the Offering will be set jointly by the Company and the Sole Global Coordinator. The price will be

set on the basis of the purchase orders submitted by investors during the Offer Period that have been collated in the order
book prepared during the bookbuilding process. Price-setting is expected to take place on or about 24 May 2016. These
orders will be evaluated according to the prices offered and the investment horizons of the respective investors. This
method of setting the number of Shares that will be placed at the Offer Price is, in principle, aimed at maximizing pro-
ceeds. Consideration will also be given to whether the Offer Price and the number of Shares to be placed allow for the
reasonable expectation that the share price will demonstrate steady performance in the secondary market given the de-
mand for the Shares noted in the order book. Attention will be paid not only to the prices offered by investors and the
number of investors wanting Shares at a particular price, but also to the composition of the group of shareholders in the
Company that would result at a given price, and expected investor behaviour. For further information regarding allotment
criteria, see “—Allotment Criteria”. The Company will not specifically charge any expenses and taxes related to the offer
to investors.

After the Offer Price has been set, the Offered Shares will be allotted to investors on the basis of the offers to
purchase then available. The Offer Price and the final number of Offered Shares including the final number of New
Shares, placed in the Offering (that is, the result of the Offering) are expected to be published on 24 May 2016 by
means of an ad hoc announcement published in various media distributed across the entire EEA, on the Company’s
website (www.mybucks.com) and filed with the Luxembourg Commission for the Supervision of the Financial Sector
(Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier) (“CSSF”), all in accordance with Article 10 of the Luxembourg
Prospectus Law. Investors who have placed orders to purchase Offering Shares with the Sole Global Coordinator can
obtain information from the Sole Global Coordinator about the Offer Price and the number of Offered Shares allotted to
them on or about 25 May 2016, the business day following the setting of the Offer Price. As commencement of trading
(Handelsaufnahme) of the Shares on the regulated market (General Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frank-
furter Wertpapierbörse) is expected to take place on the business day following the setting of the Offer Price, investors
may not have obtained information about the number of Offered Shares allotted to them at the time of commencement
of trading. Book-entry delivery of the allotted Offered Shares against payment of the Offer Price is expected to take
place on 30 May 2016, two business days after the admission of the Shares to trading on the regulated market (General
Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. Should the placement volume prove insufficient to satisfy all orders placed
at the Offer Price, the Sole Global Coordinator reserves the right to reject orders, or to accept them only in part.
Allotment Criteria

The allotment of Offered Shares will be to institutional investors and retail investors (natural persons) and will be
decided after consultation with the Sole Global Coordinator. The decision ultimately rests with the Company. Allotments
will be made on the basis of the quality of the individual investors and individual orders and other important allotment
criteria to be determined after consultation with the Sole Global Coordinator. The allocation to retail investors (natural
persons) will be compatible with the “Principles for the Allotment of Share Issues to Private Investors” published by the
Commission of Stock Exchange Experts (Börsensachverständigenkommission). ‘Qualified investors’ (qualifizierte
Anleger) under the German Securities Prospectus Act (Wertpapierprospektgesetz), as well as ‘professional clients’ (pro-
fessionelle Kunden) and ‘suitable counterparties’ (geeignete Gegenparteien) as defined under the German Securities
Trading Act (Wertpapierhandelsgesetz), are not viewed as ‘private investors’ (Privatanleger) within the meaning of the
allocation rules.

The Prospectus will be published on the website of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange (www.bourse.lu) and the
Company’s website (www.mybucks.com) after its approval by the CSSF on 12 May 2016. In addition, free copies of the
printed Prospectus will be available at the Company’s offices at 40, avenue Monterey, L-2163 Luxembourg, Grand
Duchy of Luxembourg (tel. +352 2088 2123) during regular business hours.
Information on the Shares
Voting Rights

Each Share carries one vote at the shareholders’ meeting of the Company. There are no restrictions on voting
rights, other than any limitations imposed by law. Voting rights are the same for all shareholders of the company. The
major shareholders of the Company do not have different voting rights.
Dividend and Liquidation Rights

The Offered Shares will entitle their holders to participate in all dividends declared by the Company and carry full
dividend rights for the fiscal year ending 30 June 2016. In the event of the Company’s liquidation, any proceeds will be
distributed to the holders of the Shares in proportion to their interest in the Company’s share capital.
Form and Certification of the Shares

As of the date of the Prospectus, the Shares are ordinary shares in registered form, with a nominal value of €1.00
for each Share. The Shares are currently in the process of being dematerialised pursuant to the Luxembourg law of
6 April 2013 on dematerialised securities (Loi du 6 avril 2013 relative aux titres dématérialisés) (the “Dematerialised
Securities Law”). As of the date of the Prospectus, the Company’s share capital amounts to €9,998,000. The Shares will
be registered with the single securities issuance account with LuxCSD S.A., 42, avenue John F. Kennedy, L-1855 Lux-
embourg, an operator of a securities settlement system within the meaning of the Dematerialised Securities Law and duly
licensed in Luxembourg as professional depository of financial instruments (dépositaire professionnel d'instruments fi-
nanciers) in accordance with article 26 of the Luxembourg law of 5 April 1993 on the financial sector, as amended
(“LuxCSD”). Dematerialised shares are only represented, and the ownership of the shareholder over such shares is only
established by a record in the securities account with LuxCSD. LuxCSD may, however, issue or request the Company to
issue certificates relating to the Shares for the purposes of the international circulation thereof. The Shares will be con-
verted in dematerialised shares following their registration in the securities account of LuxCSD in accordance with the
requirements of the Dematerialised Securities Law, following which the dematerialisation process of the Shares will be
concluded. Until the conversion of the Shares in dematerialised form in accordance with the provisions of the Demateri-
alised Securities Law, the a register of shareholders will be kept and held at all times at the Company’s registered office.
Delivery and Settlement

The delivery of the Offered Shares against payment of the Offer Price by wire transfer is expected to take place on
30 May 2016. The Offered Shares will be made available to the shareholders in book-entry form.
The identification details for the Offered Shares are as follow:
Transferability of the Shares; Lock-up

The Shares will be freely transferable in accordance with the legal requirements for shares in dematerialised
form. Except for the restrictions set forth in the Prospectus under “—Lock-up Agreement, Limitations on Disposal” and
“Underwriting— Selling Restrictions”, there are no prohibitions on disposals or restrictions with respect to the transfer-
ability of the Shares.
Stabilization Measures, Over-Allotments and Greenshoe Option

In connection with the placement of the Offered Shares, the Sole Global Coordinator or its affiliates, acting for the
account of the Sole Global Coordinator, will act as the stabilisation manager and may, as stabilisation manager, and act-
ing in accordance with legal requirements (Section 20a(3) of the German Securities Trading Act (Wertpapierhan-
delsgesetz) in conjunction with Commission Regulation (EC) No. 2273/2003 of 22 December 2003), make over-
allotments and take stabilisation measures to support the market price of the Shares and thereby counteract any selling
pressure.

The stabilisation manager is under no obligation to take any stabilisation measures. Therefore, no assurance can
be provided that any stabilisation measures will be taken. Where stabilisation measures are taken, these may be terminat-
ed at any time without notice. Such measures may be taken from the date of the commencement of trading of the Shares
on the regulated market on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and must be terminated no later
than the thirtieth calendar day after such day (the “Stabilisation Period”).

These measures may result in the market price of the Shares being higher than would otherwise have been the
case. Moreover, the market price may temporarily be at an unsustainable level.

Under the possible stabilisation measures, investors may, in addition to the New Shares being offered, be allocated
up to 300,000 Over-Allotment Shares as part of the allocation of the Shares to be placed. For the purpose of a potential
over-allotment, the Sole Global Coordinator will be provided with up to 300,000 existing Shares from the holdings of
Sunblaze Investment Holdings Inc. (“Sunblaze Investment”) in the form of a securities loan; this number of shares will
not exceed 15% of the New Shares. In addition, the Company will grant the Sole Global Coordinator an option to acquire
the borrowed Shares at the Offer Price less agreed commissions (the “Greenshoe Option”), which would, if the Green-
shoe Option is exercised, be issued by the Company by way of a capital increase from the Authorised Capital. The
Greenshoe Option will terminate 30 calendar days after the commencement of the trading of the Shares on the Frankfurt
Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse), i.e. on or about 25 June 2016.

The stabilisation manager is entitled to exercise the Greenshoe Option to the extent over-allotments of Shares
were initially made; the amount of Shares is to be reduced by the number of Shares held by the stabilisation manager as
of the date on which the Greenshoe Option is exercised and that were acquired by the stabilisation manager in the context
of stabilisation measures.

Once the Stabilisation Period has ended, an announcement will be made within one week in various media outlets
distributed across the entire EEA as to whether stabilisation measures were taken, when price stabilisation started and
finished, and the Price Range within which stabilisation was taken; the latter will be made known for each occasion on
which price stabilisation measures were taken. Exercise of the Greenshoe Option, the timing of its exercise and the num-
ber and type of Shares concerned will also be announced promptly in the same manner.
Lock-up Agreement, Limitations on Disposal

In the Underwriting Agreement, the Company agreed with the Sole Global Coordinator that the Company will not
(i) during the period ending six months after the first day of trading of the Shares on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange
(Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (currently expected to take place on 27 May 2016), and (ii) during a period of additional
six months thereafter, without the prior written consent of the Sole Global Coordinator:
   announce or effect any capital increase from authorised capital;

   submit a proposal for a capital increase to its shareholders for resolution;
   announce its intention to issue, effect or submit a proposal for the issuance of any securities convertible
    into Shares or option rights for Shares; or
   enter into a transaction or perform any action economically similar to those described in the bullet points
    above.

The Company may, however, issue options, warrants and Shares (i) under future employee share purchase and share
option schemes, or (ii) in consideration of all or a portion of the acquisition price of any business acquired by the Com-
pany or for purposes of entering into a joint venture, provided that the Company shall (i) consult with the Sole Global
Coordinator prior to the issuance of the Shares or other securities, and (ii) use its best efforts to negotiate an undertaking
of the recipient of the Shares or such other securities of the Company to comply with certain restrictions on the disposal
of Shares contained in the Underwriting Agreement.

By way of separate lock-up agreements, all existing shareholders of the Company and the members of the Board
and Senior Management undertook (i) for the period ending twelve months after the first day of trading of the Shares on
the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (currently expected to take place on 27 May 2016), and (ii)
for the period of additional six months thereafter, without the prior written consent of the Sole Global Coordinator, not
to:

offer, pledge, allot, sell, contract to sell, sell any option or contract to purchase, purchase any option or
contract to sell, charge, assign, grant any option, right or warrant to purchase, or otherwise transfer or
dispose of, directly or indirectly, any Shares or any securities of the Company, including securities con-
vertible into, substantially similar to or exercisable or exchangeable for, Shares (or any interest therein or
in respect thereof) or any rights arising from or attaching to any such Shares at any time;
enter into any swap or other agreement that transfers, in whole or in part, any of the economic conse-
quences of ownership of Shares; or
enter into any other transaction with the same economic effect as, or agree to do, or announce or other-
wise publicise the intention to do any of the foregoing, whether any such transaction is to be settled by
delivery of Shares or such other securities, in cash or otherwise,

This undertaking shall not restrict the transfer of Shares (i) among existing shareholders, or (ii) by an existing
shareholder to any person controlling such shareholder, under common control with such shareholder or which such
shareholder controls, provided that the recipient of such transfer assumes, by written confirmation to the Sole Global Co-
ordinator, the obligations of such shareholder hereunder for the then remaining term of this undertaking.
Admission to the Frankfurt Stock Exchange and Commencement of Trading

The Company expects to apply for admission of its Shares to trading on the regulated market segment (regulierter
Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (General Standard) on or about 13 May 2016.
The listing approval is expected to be announced on or about 25 May 2016. Trading on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange
(Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) is currently expected to commence on 27 May 2016.
Designated Sponsor

The Sole Global Coordinator has agreed to assume the function of a designated sponsor of the Shares traded on
the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse). Pursuant to the designated sponsor agreement concluded
between the Sole Global Coordinator and the Company, the Sole Global Coordinator will, among other things, place lim-
ited buy and sell orders for the Shares in the electronic trading system of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter
Wertpapierbörse) during regular trading hours. This is intended to achieve greater liquidity in the market for the Shares.
Interests of Parties Participating in the Offering

In connection with the Offering and the admission to trading of the Shares, the Sole Global Coordinator has
formed a contractual relationship with the Company.

The Sole Global Coordinator acts for the Company on the Offering and coordinates the structuring and execution
of the Offering. In addition, the Sole Global Coordinator has been appointed to act as designated sponsor for the Shares
and Banque Internationale à Luxembourg S.A. has been appointed to act as the paying agent and LuxCSD principal agent
(the “LuxCSD Principal Agent”). Upon successful implementation of the Offering, the Sole Global Coordinator will
receive a commission. As a result of this contractual relationship, the Sole Global Coordinator has a financial interest in
the success of the Offering.

The Sole Global Coordinator or its affiliates may, from time to time, in the future have business relations with the
Group (including lending activities) or may perform services for the Group in the ordinary course of business.

The Company has set up a long-term incentive scheme for the benefit of all employees of the Company, including
the executive directors of the Board and the members of the Senior Management, in the aggregate value of €2.5 million
(the “Share Option Plan”), see "Business―Our Business―Employees and Human Ressources―Social Policy and Em-
ployee Benefits". The participants of the Share Option Plan, in particular the relevant members of the Board and the Sen-
ior Management, have a financial interest in the Offering since these benefits are subject to or, as the case may be, influ-
enced by the listing of the Shares on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse).
PROCEEDS OF THE OFFERING AND COSTS OF THE OFFERING AND LISTING

The Company will receive the proceeds of the Offering resulting from the sale of the New Shares and, if and to
the extent the Greenshoe Option is exercised, from the exercise of the Greenshoe Option, in each case after deduction of
payable commissions and expenses. Assuming (i) a placement of all New Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range, and
(ii) full exercise of the Greenshoe Option, the gross proceeds of the Offering will amount to approximately €34.5 million,
all attributable to the Company.

The expenses related to the Offering and the listing of the Company’s entire share capital will be borne by the
Company and are expected to total approximately €2.0 million (excluding the commissions and expenses payable to the
Sole Global Coordinator). Assuming (i) a placement of all New Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range, and (ii) full
exercise of the Greenshoe Option, the commissions and expenses payable to the Sole Global Coordinator will amount to
€1.4 million.

Based on the assumptions set forth above, the total expenses of the Offering and listing of the Shares (including
the commissions and expenses payable to the Sole Global Coordinator) to be borne by the Company are expected to
amount to €3.4 million.

nt to €3.4 million.
 Investors will not be charged expenses by the Company or the Sole Global Coordinator.
REASONS FOR THE OFFERING AND LISTING; USE OF PROCEEDS

We are conducting the Offering in order to gain better access to the capital markets and fund future growth. After
the Offering, we intend to admit the Shares to trading on the regulated market segment (regulierter Markt) of the Frank-
furt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (General Standard).

The Company will receive the proceeds of the Offering resulting from the sale of the New Shares and, if and to
the extent the Greenshoe Option is exercised, from the exercise of the Greenshoe Option, in each case after deduction of
payable commissions and expenses. Assuming a placement of all New Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range, the
Company expects to receive gross proceeds of approximately €30.0 million from the sale of the New Shares; net pro-
ceeds thereof attributable to the Company will amount to approximately €26.8 million. Assuming (i) a placement of all
New Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range, and (ii) full exercise of the Greenshoe Option, the Company expects to
receive gross proceeds of approximately €34.5 million in the Offering; net proceeds thereof attributable to the Company
will amount to approximately €31.1 million.
We intend to use the net proceeds we receive from the Offering to

   finance the Acquisition and recapitalize the Opportunity Banks with an amount of about €13.0 million;
   refinance existing debt, in particular loans from shareholders and related parties with an amount of about
    €14.0 million; and
   realize growth opportunities, in particular to increase our loan book and enter into new markets with any
    remainder of the net proceeds.
DIVIDEND POLICY; RESULTS AND DIVIDENDS PER SHARE; USE OF PROFITS
General Provisions Relating to Profit Allocation and Dividend Payments

There are no fixed dates on which a shareholder is entitled to receive a dividend. The Company may declare and
pay dividends in accordance with the Luxembourg law of 10 August 1915 on commercial companies, as amended (the
“Luxembourg Company Law”). Dividends may be declared by the General Meeting upon approval of the annual ac-
counts for the immediately preceding financial year.

The Company may declare andpay dividends in accordance with the Luxembourg law of 10 August 1915 on commercial companies, as amended (the“Luxembourg Company Law”). Dividends may be declared by the General Meeting upon approval of the annual ac-counts for the immediately preceding financial year.

blobs.text:
The Articles of Association also provide that the Board has the power to decide on and distribute interim divi-
dends (including by way of staggered payments) by way of a cash dividend or by way of a dividend in kind, in accord-
ance with the provisions applicable to commercial companies as set forth, in particular, in Article 72-2 of the Luxem-
bourg Company Law.

rg Company Law.
  Dividends may be declared or paid in any currency as well as in kind including by way of issuance of Shares.

The amount of a dividend declared by the General Meeting upon approval of the annual accounts may not exceed
the amount of the profits at the end of the last financial year plus any profits carried forward and any amounts drawn
from reserves which are available for that purpose, minus any losses carried forward and sums to be placed in reserve in
accordance with the law or the Articles of Association. Interim dividends may be declared and paid by the Board out of
available net profits, premium or other available reserves subject to complying with conditions required by law subject to
such dividend not exceeding the amount available for distribution which shall not exceed total profits made since the end
of the last financial year for which the annual accounts have been approved, plus any profits carried forward and sums
drawn from reserves available for this purpose, less losses carried forward and any sums to be placed to reserve pursuant
to the requirements of the law or the Articles of Association of the Company.

If the Company declares to pay dividends to its shareholders, each shareholder is entitled to receive a dividend in
proportion to the amount of capital held by it in the Company. Dividend payments that have not been claimed within five
years after the date on which they become due revert back to the Company according to Article 2277 of the Luxembourg
Civil Code. There are no specific dividend restrictions or procedures for non-resident shareholders.
Dividend Policy and Earnings per Share

In the past, the Company did not pay any dividends. Following the Offering, we currently intend to retain all
available funds and any future earnings to support operations and to finance the growth and development of our business
and do not intend to pay dividends in the foreseeable future. Any future determination to pay dividends will be made in
accordance with applicable laws, and will depend upon, among other factors, our results of operations, financial condi-
tion, contractual restrictions including by terms of any existing and future financing agreements and capital requirements.
Our future ability to pay dividends may be limited by the terms of any existing and future debt or preferred securities.
CAPITALIZATION AND INDEBTEDNESS; STATEMENT ON WORKING CAPITAL

The following tables set forth the Group’s actual capitalization and indebtedness (i) as of 31 March 2016, as well
as adjustments for (ii) effects of the capital increase and the Offering, and (iii) the Group’s total capitalization and in-
debtedness to reflect the adjustments described in (ii). Investors should read these tables only in conjunction with the in-
formation set forth in “Selected Financial and Other Information”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
Condition and Results of Operations”, and the audited financial statements of the Company which are included elsewhere
in the Prospectus, including the notes thereto.

No Contingent Liabilities or Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
We currently do not have any contingent liabilities or off-balance sheet arrangements.
Statement on Working Capital

The Company is of the opinion that the Group is in a position to meet the payment obligations that become du
within at least the next twelve months from the date of the Prospectus.

sets less all non-current and current liabilities) attributable to shareholders, amounted to €9.9 million as of 31 December
2015, and would amount to €1.0 per Share based on 9,998,000 outstanding Shares immediately prior to the Offering.

After giving effect to the issuance of the New Shares in the context of the Offering, assuming an Offer Price of
€15.0 at the mid-point of the Price Range and full exercise of the Greenshoe Option, and after subtracting the maximum
estimated costs of the Offering to be borne by the Company in the amount of €3.4 million, the equity attributable to the
Company’s shareholders would have been €41.0 million as of 31 December 2015, or €3.3 per Share. That would corre-
spond to a direct dilution of €11.7, corresponding to 77.8%, per Share for the parties acquiring the Offered Shares, based
on 12,298,000 outstanding Shares following the completion of the Offering (assuming a placement of all New Shares and
full exercise of the Greenshoe Option).

SELECTED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION

The selected financial and other information contained in the following tables has been extracted or derived,
without material differences, from the audited combined financial statements of the Company as of and for the years end-
ed 30 June 2015, 2014, and 2013 prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the EU, and the audited interim com-
bined consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the six-month period ended 31 December 2015
prepared in accordance with IAS 34 as adopted by the EU, all included elsewhere in the Prospectus.

Where financial and other information in the following tables is labelled “audited”, this means that it has been
extracted without material adjustments from the audited financial statements mentioned above. The label “unaudited” is
used in the following tables to indicate financial and other information that has not been extracted from the audited fi-
nancial statements mentioned above, but has been extracted without material adjustments from the Company’s account-
ing or controlling records, or is based on calculations of these figures. All of the financial and other information present-
ed in the text and tables below are shown in thousands of Euro (€ thousand), except as otherwise stated. Rounding ad-
justments to the nearest whole number have been made, therefore figures shown as totals may not be exact arithmetic
aggregations of the figures that precede them.

The following selected financial and other information should be read together with the section “Management’s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, the consolidated financial statements in-
cluding the related notes contained in the Prospectus and additional financial information contained elsewhere in the
Prospectus.

Other Financial and Operating Data

As other financial and operating data, we have included certain Non-IFRS financial measures. We believe that the
following other financial and operating data are meaningful supplemental information for measuring the operating and
financial performance of the Group’s business for the Company’s management and investors. We believe that these other
financial and operating data are useful measures in evaluating the Group’s financial performance, because a number of
companies, in particular companies in the FinTech business, also publish these figures as key performance indicators.
However, these performance measures are not recognized as line items under IFRS and should not be considered as sub-
stitutes for figures on net assets, result before taxes, net earnings, cash flow from operating activities or other income
statement, cash flow or balance sheet data, as determined in accordance with IFRS, or as indicators of profitability or li-
quidity. These performance measures do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available for the
Group’s cash requirements, nor whether any such measure is indicative of the Group’s historical operating results. These
performance measures are not meant to be indicative of future results. Because not all companies calculate these perfor-
mance measures in the same way, our presentation of these performance measures is not necessarily comparable with
similarly-titled measures used by other companies.
The following table presents a summary of certain other financial and operating data for the periods presented:

Segment Information

We introduced segment reporting in 2016, having identified three reportable segments based on geographical lo-
cation of the markets served by our operations. We offer similar products and services in each of our reportable seg-
ments. We primarily use net profit after tax to assess the performance of our operating segments. For this purpose, we
monitor the loans disbursed to our customers on a monthly basis.
The following tables set forth revenue and profits/(losses), respectively, by segment for the periods indicated.

(1)
      Includes our holding entity in Mauritius. Our operating entities in this segment offer lending products to customers and support for the Group.
(2)
      Includes our financing entity in Austria. Our operating entities in Poland and Spain offer lending products to customers.
