MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
                    RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

The following management’s discussion and analysis should be read together with the section “Selected Consoli-
dated Financial Data and Group Data”, the financial statements including the related notes contained elsewhere in the
Prospectus and additional financial information contained elsewhere in the Prospectus.

The following management’s discussion and analysis is based upon financial and other information contained in
the audited combined financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014, and 2013
prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the EU, and the audited interim combined consolidated financial
statements of the Company as of and for the six-month period ended 31 December 2015 prepared in accordance with
IAS 34 as adopted by the EU, all included elsewhere in the Prospectus.

Where financial and other information in the following tables is labelled “audited”, this means that it has been
extracted without material adjustments from the audited financial statements mentioned above. The label “unaudited” is
used in the following tables to indicate financial and other information that has not been extracted from the audited fi-
nancial statements mentioned above, but has been extracted without material adjustments from the Company’s account-
ing or controlling records, or is based on calculations of these figures. All of the financial and other information pre-
sented in the text and tables below are shown in thousands of Euro (€ thousand), except as otherwise stated. Rounding
adjustments to the nearest whole number have been made, therefore figures shown as totals may not be exact arithmetic
aggregations of the figures that precede them.

Our historical results are not necessarily indicative of the results that should be expected in the future, and our
interim results are not necessarily indicative of the results that should be expected for the full year or any other period.
Overview

We are a FinTech company based in Luxembourg that embraces technology as a means to provide small unse-
cured short-term consumer loans and other financial products and services to the low and middle-income consumer
segment, predominantly in emerging markets of Sub-Saharan Africa. We aim to ensure that our Group offers fast, sim-
ple and trustworthy products and services through technology – when compared to traditional non-technology driven
methods, to our customers and we seek to work towards enhancing our customers’ experience with our innovative finan-
cial products and services. Founded in 2011, we have expanded our operations to now include nine Sub-Saharan African
countries, namely Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe, as
well as more recently, two European countries, namely Poland and Spain. From our inception up until 31 December
2015, we disbursed in excess of 600,000 loans in an aggregated volume of €140 million, and since the deployment of
our advanced credit decisioning and scoring model in November 2015 until today, our self-learning algorithms have
made more than 1,500,000 predictions, utilising a large number of traditional and alternative data points. This is why we
consider ourselves to be an innovative provider of online and mobile financial consumer products and services in the
Sub-Saharan African region.

industry: small unse-cured short-term consumer loans and other financial products and services

blobs.text:
Our broad portfolio includes banking, lending, and insurance products, and is supported by financial services
such as mobile banking, credit reports with credit education features as well as financial budgeting, and emergency cov-
er through insurance. However, we do not offer all these products and services in all jurisdictions at this stage. We offer
our products and services under the following three brands:

   GetBucks: Under our GetBucks brand, we offer our customers short-term single payment loans and in-
    stalment loans as well as additional value added services such as a credit report and a budgeting tool.
   GetSure: Under our GetSure brand, we provide insurance cover, primarily for credit life, funeral costs, le-
    gal fees and medical cover.
   GetBanked: We will, under our GetBanked brand, also offer savings accounts, mobile transacting, trans-
    action cards and comprehensive financial solutions for customers, which entail a personal financial dash-
    board that provides our customers with access to, and information about, their banking, credit and insur-
    ance portfolios.

Cognisant of the growing trend of people’s lives becoming more technologically driven through more devices
than ever before, our vision is to break the paradigm of customers having to visit a location to access services. Our solu-
tions are created with the aim of leveraging our technology applications and empowering our customers to access finan-
cial solutions through various online channels with mobile devices anywhere and at any time, avoiding the need for a
network of physical branches or sales locations. As a result, we are able to serve our customers in geographically remote
areas of the markets in which we operate. However, in regions where the market penetration of mobile technology is still
low, we also offer light branch or kiosk infrastructure to support virtual channels, and use these branches to assist cus-
tomers from an educational point of view.

tomers from an educational point of view.
       By “banking” customers using our proprietary software, we are able to better understand our customers’ needs,
spending habits and transaction history, allowing us to manage their requirements whilst allowing for improvement of
our risk-scoring criteria, collections efficiency and overall customer management. “FinCloud”, our cloud-based proprie-
usto

tary customer interface and loan management system, enables us to manage credit risk, our loan book portfolios, and ef-
ficiently serve our customers securely, via the internet, mobile phone and telephone, in real time (for details see “Our
Business―Information Technology”). In the six-month period ended 31 December 2015, we experienced a customer re-
tention rate (i.e. customers who have purchased at least two of our products in their customer lifetime) of more than
59%, which demonstrates that our technology platform and customer management is convenient and trustworthy.

In the six-month period ended 31 December 2015, our business has grown significantly and we achieved loan is-
sues of €38.3 million (six-month period ended 31 December 2014: €27.2 million) and generated revenue of €20.8 mil-
lion (six-month period ended 31 December 2014: €13.4 million), an operating profit of €7.9 million (six-month period
ended 31 December 2014: €4.3 million) and a profit after tax of €2.5 million (six-month period ended 31 December
2014: €1.1 million). This corresponds to a growth in loans issued as of 2015 to 2014 of 56.4%, and in a growth in reve-
nue as of 2015 to 2014 of 55.7%. As of 31 December 2015, we had 384 employees (2014: 247).

In addition, we recently entered into a share purchase agreement with subsidiaries of Opportunity International,
a microfinance organization headquartered in Chicago, United States (for details see “―Our Business―Material Con-
tracts―Share Purchase Agreement regarding the Opportunity Banks” and “The Acquisition of the Opportunity Banks
and the Future Group”). We acquired majority shareholdings in a Pan-African group of companies consisting of three
banks in Malawi, Mozambique and Uganda, one savings and loans company in Ghana, and two non-bank financial in-
stitutions (“NBFIs”) in Kenya and Tanzania. By way of the Acquisition, we intend to expand our geographic reach by
adding Ghana, Mozambique, and Tanzania to our African footprint, enhance our competitive position in Kenya, Ma-
lawi, and Uganda, and increase our customer base to more than 1.5 million customers. We believe that the Acquisition
– which aims to combine our products, credit expertise and technology with Opportunity International’s network, cus-
tomer base and expertise in using financial services – will serve our growth strategy to ‘bank’ the large number of po-
tential customers, in particular in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Key Factors Affecting Results

Our results of operation have been, and will continue to be, affected by a number of events and actions, some of
which are beyond our control. We believe that the specific factors discussed below have affected our results in the pe-
riods for which financial information is presented in the Prospectus and will continue to affect our results in the future.
Loan Amounts Issued and Movements in Interest Income

key_factor_affecting_results: Loan Amounts Issued and Movements in Interest Income

blobs.text:
We generate substantially most of our revenue from the interest income earned on our loans. Our results, there-
fore, are affected by loan amounts issued and the interest income we generate with our loans.

Provided we maintain a strict and prudent credit policy, an increase in loan amounts issued has historically had a
positive impact on our results of operations. During the relevant periods covered herein, our business has undergone sig-
nificant expansion, with loan amounts issued increasing to €65.7 million in the year ended 30 June 2015 from €25.6 mil-
lion in the year ended 30 June 2014 and €10.7 million in the year ended 30 June 2013. In the six-month period ended
31 December 2015, loan amounts issued grew to €38.2 million from €27.3 million in the six-month period ended
31 December 2014. The significant increase in loan amounts issued is attributable to the rapid expansion of our business
both within existing jurisdictions and in new jurisdictions. For example, we operated in ten jurisdictions as of 31 De-
cember 2015, compared to four jurisdictions as of 1 January 2013. In the six-month period ended 31 December 2015, we
achieved loan issues of €38.3 million (2014: €27.3 million) and generated revenue of €20.8 million (2014: €13.4 mil-
lion). This corresponds to a growth in loans issued as of 2015 to 2014 of 56.4%, and in a growth in revenue as of 2015 to
2014 of 55.7%.

An increase in interest income will generally have a positive impact on our results of operations, provided such
increase does not lead to an offsetting reduction in loan amounts issued. In the six-month period ended 31 December
2015, the interest income generated from our loan products was €16.8 million, compared to €10.7 million in the six-
month period ended 31 December 2014. A decrease in interest income, whether caused by increased competition in the
markets in which we operate, interest rate caps set by regulatory authorities or a combination of these or any other fac-
tors, may have either a negative or positive impact on our results of operations, to the extent such decrease is not offset
by greater cost efficiencies or a change in product portfolio.

The diversification of our loan portfolio provides further protection against movements in interest income. As of
31 December 2015, our instalment loans comprised 85.7% of our loan portfolio, and we expect this proportion to grow
due to our intention to gradually roll-out such sort of loans in the countries where we currently do not offer them, as well
as to the fact that amounts issued under our instalment loans typically stay on our balance sheet longer than amounts is-
sued under our single payment loans. In markets where there are legislative pressures to impose interest caps on short-
term loan products or otherwise limit short-term lending, either of which occurrences would negatively impact the prof-
itability of our single payment loans, we would be in a position to shift our portfolio to a greater extent into our instal-
ment loans, while at the same time continuing to service the needs of our existing customer base.
Loan Portfolio Performance as Level of Bad Debt

key_factor_affecting_results: Loan Portfolio Performance as Level of Bad Debt

blobs.text:
The ability to collect loan payments on a timely basis and recover debts that are overdue has a direct impact on
the performance of our loan portfolio and on the level of net impairment charges taken during a reporting period.

The collection of loan payments on a timely basis depends, in part, on the strength of our credit approval process,
including the effectiveness of our proprietary credit decisioning and scoring model system called “Jessie”, as well as on
changes to our lending rules, such as restrictions on lending based on the age and past credit history of potential custom-
ers. We use an automated system to register, identify and process the applications of customers and a unique scoring sys-
tem for assessing the creditworthiness of loan applicants. Our credit approval process enables us to be flexible and react
quickly to changes in the markets in which we operate.

Defaulted payments are managed from the first day of a missed instalment. From an operational point of view,
the process is initiated with instant SMS and e-mail communication to the customer, addressing the failed status of their
loan instalment. Thereafter, we follow up with a telephonic interaction in order to determine the cause, and ideally to
provide a solution for the missed payment. The failed instalment will be followed up on a continual basis until it reaches
90 days overdue. After reaching 90 days overdue, the case then enters an external debt collection process whereby a
third party attempts to collect the full amount of the outstanding loan. If this external debt collection process proves un-
successful, the account is then retracted and the proposed debt sold off to third party debt collectors at a rate of between
10% and 20% in currency unit, or written off, depending on the size and age of the debt.

From an accounting point of view, on the first day past due an impairment charge is accounted for an amount
based on the estimated recoverability. Non-performing loans are provided for under the impairment line on the income
statement and requires a robust model to determine the true impaired value of the book. The current validated model is
based on IAS 39. In 2018, with the mandatory application of IFRS 9, the Group will adapt its model to step from the
current incurred loss model to an expected loss model. This will produce more accurate numbers from a risk manage-
ment point of view and might as well have impact on the reported financial performance.
The following table provides an overview on the ageing analysis of our loan receivables as of 31 December 2015:

As a result of our non-performing loan management, we have managed to achieve a bad debt impairment rate
(provision and write offs on average loan portfolio) of 19.1% for the six-month period ended 31 December 2015 and
21.5% for the year ended 30 June 2015. Our bad debt impairment rate is calculated by adding to the balance “impair-
ment on loan book” the write-offs and dividing by the sum of gross loan book and write-offs, for the period indicated.
Gross loan book is calculated by adding back the balance “impairment on loan book” to the loan book for the period in-
dicated.
Changes in the Regulatory Framework

We operate in a complex regulatory environment currently spanning jurisdictions in relation to consumer loans,
consumer rights protection, debt collection and personal data processing, among other areas. Changes in the regulatory
environment may have a significant impact on our operations. Certain jurisdictions where we operate, such as South Af-
rica where the National Credit Act prescribes limits on interest rates for all forms of credit since June 2007, have im-
posed, or are considering imposing, caps on interest rates, which, depending on the level of such caps, may have either a
positive or negative effect on our operations. Generally, a less restrictive, or relatively higher cap, could have a positive
impact on our results to the extent it prompts competitors to exit the market. In contrast, a more restrictive interest cap in
a given market may limit our ability to profitably offer short-term single payment loans and may compel us to introduce
or expand the use of longer-term products, which are generally riskier and less flexible to change than shorter-term
products. Nevertheless, if a more restrictive cap is introduced, but limited to loans of relatively small amounts, this could
have a positive impact on the results of those companies, such as ourselves, which have sophisticated IT and credit scor-
ing systems in place.
Refinancing

Our revenue has grown strongly in the last three years. Our credit portfolio has grown accordingly and we plan to
continue our rapid growth through geographic expansion and the introduction of new loan products with longer payment
terms in more of the markets in which we operate. The expansion of our credit portfolio and especially the diversifica-
tion into credit products with longer payment terms is more capital intensive than short term consumer loans.

Refinancing of our quickly growing credit portfolio has sometimes been challenging in the past, as traditional
banks have been reluctant to provide financing to other lenders. As a result, we have particularly relied on

   bank borrowings, especially the credit facility agreement as of 29 May 2015 between GetBucks Limited
    (Mauritius) (“GetBucks Mauritius”), as borrower, and TLG Africa Limited, the African investment vehi-
    cle of TLG Capital, as lender (the “Facility Agreement”);
   loans from our shareholders; and
   to a limited extent, on the bond markets for financing our business, in particular through the issuance of a
    single tranche of about €5.2 million 11.0% fixed rate notes due 3 February 2017 (the “2017 Notes”)
    through our Austrian finance subsidiary, GetBucks Invest GmbH (“GetBucks Invest”), on 3 February
    2014.

Historically, our strong geographic expansion and growth path has been impacted by the availability of debt capi-
tal. We expect that the proceeds of the Offering will help us maintain further growth in our credit volumes in line with
our geographic and overall expansion plans. For more information on our refinancing, see “―Liquidity and Capital Re-
sources”.
Changes to Economic Environment, in particular in Sub-Saharan Africa

key_factor_affecting_results: Changes to Economic Environment, in particular in Sub-Saharan Africa

blobs.text:
We are active in the market for unsecured short-term consumer loans and other financial products and services,
predominantly in Sub-Saharan Africa and selected European countries. Since we particularly focus on the low and mid-
dle-income consumer segment, economic downturns or the worsening of economic conditions, in particular when lead-
ing to hyperinflation or a devaluation of currencies, may have a disproportionately negative impact on the average con-
sumer profile of our customers, which can have an effect on our scoring models, rejection rates and overall risk profile
in a country. We have, in the past, been able to successfully adapt our business model to economic developments in the
countries we operate in. However, we cannot rule out that this may change.
Basis of Financial Presentation

The audited combined financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014, and
2013, and the audited interim combined consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the six-month
period ended 31 December 2015, all included elsewhere in the Prospectus, each including combined statements of finan-
cial position, combined statements of profit and loss and comprehensive income, combined statements of cash flow,
combined statements of changes in equity and notes to the combined financial statements, have been prepared in accord-
ance with IFRS and IAS 34, respectively, as adopted by the EU, on a historical cost basis and are presented in Euros.
The combined financial statements represent the Group’s first financial statements in accordance with IFRS, as adopted
by the EU. The Group was formed when GetBucks Mauritius, representing all African operations, and GetBucks South
Africa, representing all South African operations, were both contributed to the Company (formerly MyBucks S.à r.l.) by
the existing shareholders of the two companies on 14 December 2015.

GetBucks Mauritius and GetBucks South Africa have each issued consolidated financial statements in accordance
with IFRS as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014 and 2013. The results and balance sheets of the two sub-
groups were incorporated as if both sub-groups had always been combined. Consequently, the audited combined finan-
cial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014, and 2013 and the audited interim
combined consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the six-month period ended 31 December
2015 reflect both sub-groups full period’s results, even though the business combination occurred on 14 December 2015.
In addition, the corresponding figures for the previous periods reflect the combined results of both entities, even though
the transaction did not occur until the 14 December 2015. This reflects the view that the transaction involves two entities
controlled by the same controlling party – the financial statements reflect the figures from the perspective of that party,
and they reflect the period over which that party has had control. When incorporating the results, sub-group incorporated
any profit and loss impact of consolidation adjustments picked up as part of the predecessor accounting. The combina-
tion of entities under common control were recorded in the combined financial statements of the Group at predecessor
book values. These historic combined financial statements of the Group were drawn up on the basis of the values pre-
sented in the consolidated financial statements of GetBucks Mauritius and GetBucks South Africa, adjusted for consoli-
dation adjustments.

For more information on the preparation of the combined financial statements see note 1.2 in the audited com-
bined financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014, and 2013.

Revenue

Revenue increased by €7,460 thousand, or 55.7%, from €13,389 thousand in the six-month period ended 31 De-

ically in new markets such as Poland and Zambia.

ments was primarily due to our geographical expansion and the fact both Spain and Swaziland were relatively new oper-

amounting to €24,682 thousand, from €28,469 thousand as of 31 December 2014 to €44,420 thousand as of

ber 2014 to €73 thousand in the six-month period ended 31 December 2015. This increase in other income was due to an

ed 31 December 2014 to €9,057 thousand in the six-month period ended 31 December 2015. This increase in operating

cember 2014 to €7,911 thousand in the six-month period ended 31 December 2015. This increase in operating profit was

Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure about Market Risk

We are exposed to various market risks associated with our revenue, loan portfolio, assets, liabilities and opera-
tions, including credit risk, concentration risk, liquidity risk, operational risks, currency risk, reputational risk, capital
management risk, regulatory risk and interest rate risk. The most important risks for our Group are credit risk, liquidity
risk and market risk. Market risk includes currency risk and interest rate risk.

The objective of our risk management is to manage and control risk exposures within acceptable parameters,
while optimizing the return on such risk. The risk management policies are designed to identify and analyse these risks,
to set appropriate limits and controls, and to monitor the risk through reliable and up-to-date information systems. Risk
management is carried out by management, under policies approved by the Board. The Board approves principles for
overall risk management as well as policies covering specific areas.
Liquidity risk

iquidity risk
     Liquidity risk is the risk that operations cannot be funded and financial commitments cannot be met timeously

and cost effectively. Liquidity risk management deals with the overall profile of the statement of financial position, the
funding requirements of the Group and cash flows. In quantifying the liquidity risk, future cash flow projections are
simulated and necessary arrangements are put in place in order to ensure that all future cash flow commitments are met.
Market risk

Market risk is the risk that changes in the market prices, such as interest rates and foreign exchange rates will af-
fect the fair value and future cash flows of a financial instrument. Market risk arises from open positions in interest rates
and foreign currencies, both which are exposed to general and specific market movements and changes in the level of
volatility. The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable
parameters, while optimising the return on risk.

Overall responsibility for managing market risk rests with the directors. Management is responsible for the de-
velopment of detailed risk management policies (subject to review by the directors) and for the day to day implementa-
tion of those policies.

The Group policy is to only hedge open positions on hard currencies. Due to the volatility in some of the African
countries currencies, hedging is either not available or prohibitively expensive. In such countries, the focus is to obtain
local funding in local currency.
Interest rate risk

Cash flow interest rate risk is the risk that the future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of
changes in market interest rates. Fair value interest rate risk is the risk that the value of a financial instrument will fluc-
tuate because of changes in market interest rates.

The Group’s main interest rate risk arises from long-term borrowings which are issued at fixed and variable rates.
These expose the Group to cash flow interest rate risk which is partially offset by having a short term loan portfolio as
main asset in the Group. Increasing refinancing cost can be potentially covered by price changes in new lending (to the
extent the relevant lending rates are governed by a formula linked to prime) whereby the spread between lending interest
and borrowing interest is comparably high.

The Group manages its interest rate risk through placing excess funds in interest bearing call accounts. The
Group has also placed hard currency debt borrowings in bank deposits which is used as security for local currency fund-
ing lines where the Group earns interest on these deposited fund.
Credit risk

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to
meet its contractual obligations and arises principally from the Group’s loans and advances to customers. For risk man-
agement reporting purposes, the Group considers and consolidates all elements of credit risk exposure (such as individu-
al obligor default risk, employer default risk and country risk).

The provision of unsecured loans to formally employed individuals is the main activity of the Group’s business.
As such, exposure to credit risk and the management of this risk is a key consideration.

Customer credit risk is mitigated by the utilisation of payroll collection models. Employment of customers by
vetted employers effectively serve as security for loans provided to such customers, since the employer recovers the loan
instalment directly from the customer’s salary.

This deduction-at-source lending model is used throughout the Group with the exception of CashCorp (Proprie-
tary) Limited (Botswana), GetBucks Spain SL (Spain) and GetBucks Poland sp. z o.o. (Poland). These entities provide
direct lending to customers.
Credit risk

   The Group is exposed to credit risk via loans to its subsidiaries.
   The Group provides funding to its subsidiaries to grow their loan book.
   The Group subsidiaries provide loans to customers employed by employers that have been vetted by the
    Group.
   The Group has also provided borrowed hard currency funds as security for local currency funding from
    local banks for its subsidiaries. This exposes the Company to the credit risk profile of its subsidiaries.
    This is mitigated through the credit and liquidity risk management process of the Group as disclosed in
    this note.

All cash and cash equivalent assets are placed with reputable banks. If the banks credit rating recedes the risk will
be assessed and action taken. The Group analyses the return versus risk in these instances as some banks may offer a
higher return with a significant risk component. The Group utilises hard currency deposits as security to borrow local

up util
  100

currency funding to limit foreign exchange losses. The Group has access to its cash assets at all times via this back to
back funding model.

In terms of the Group’s derivative position, the Group selects well-regulated, reputable and financially sound
firms in the United Kingdom. The Group chose the United Kingdom due to a strong regulatory and supervisory frame-
work which providers need to comply with.

In extending loans to related parties, shareholders and third parties the Group completes a full credit assessment.
The Group reviews the annual financial statements, operations, legal and tax status of the borrower. The Group also lim-
its the tenor and size of the debt in which it never poses a material risk to the Group. All loans are interest-bearing and
recorded at fair value at initial recognition.
Foreign exchange risk

Foreign exchange risk arises when future commercial transactions or recognised assets or liabilities are denomi-
nated in a currency that is not the entity’s functional currency.

Our management has set up a policy to require Group companies to manage their foreign exchange risk against
their functional currency.

unctional currency.
 The Group has made use of several methods to limit its various exposures:

   Forward cover contracts to match its exposure to the Euro in relation to the US dollar.
   Hard Currency Bank Deposits used as security for local currency funding lines.
   Repayment of intercompany loans to reduce losses by replacing intercompany funding with local cur-
    rency funding lines.

The Group has investments in subsidiaries, whose net assets are exposed to foreign currency translation risk. Cur-
rency exposure arising from the net assets of the Group’s subsidiaries is managed primarily through borrowings denom-
inated in the relevant foreign currencies.

In the new financial year the Group’s focus is to close the open loans. New local currency funding lines will ena-
ble the Group to replace intercompany loans with local funding.
Concentration risk

Concentration risk is the risk of loss arising from an excessive concentration of exposure to a single Counterpar-
ty, an industry, a product or geographic region. The Group’s credit risk portfolio is well diversified. The Group’s man-
agement approach relies on reporting of concentration risk along key dimensions and portfolio limits.

Concentration risk limits are used within the Group to ensure that funding diversification is maintained across
products, geographic regions and counterparties.
African Group

Critical Accounting Policies

The preparation of the combined financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015,
2014 and 2013 in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the EU requires management to make estimates and assumptions
that affect the application of accounting policies and the amounts presented in these combined financial statements and
its related disclosures. Use of available information and the application of judgement is inherent in the formation of es-
timates. Actual results in the future could differ from these estimates which may be material to the combined financial
statements.

In preparing the audited interim combined consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the six-
month period ended 31 December 2015, the significant judgements made by management in applying the accounting
policies and the key sources of estimation uncertainty were the same as those that were applied to the audited combined

financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014, and 2013, with the exception of
changes in estimates that are required in determining the provision for income taxes.
Following is
s a summary of the Group’s critical accounting policies.
Impairment
Other receivables and loans

At each reporting date the Group assesses all financial assets, other than those at fair value through profit or loss,
to determine whether there is objective evidence that a financial asset or group of financial assets has been impaired.

Management performs impairment testing on the recoverability of loans and receivables to establish if an im-
pairment loss or gain should be recognised on the estimated future cash flows from these financial assets. Management
looks at current profitability and liquidity as well as cash flows and forecasts to determine if other receivables and loans
with an entity will be recoverable.
Non-financial assets
Impairment testing of non-financial assets

The recoverable amounts of cash-generating units and individual assets have been determined based on the higher
of value-in-use calculations and fair values less costs to sell. These calculations require the use of estimates and assump-
tions. It is reasonably possible that the assumption may change which may then impact our estimations and may then re-
quire a material adjustment to the carrying value of goodwill, tangible and intangible assets.
Impairment of non-financial assets

The Company assesses at each end of the reporting period whether there is any indication that an asset may be
impaired. If any such indication exists, the Company estimates the recoverable amount of the asset.

If there is any indication that an asset may be impaired, the recoverable amount is estimated for the individual as-
set. If it is not possible to estimate the recoverable amount of the individual asset, the recoverable amount of the cash-
generating unit to which the asset belongs is determined.

The recoverable amount of an asset or a cash-generating unit is the higher of its fair value less costs to sell and its
value in use.

If the recoverable amount of an asset is less than its carrying amount, the carrying amount of the asset is reduced
to its recoverable amount. That reduction is an impairment loss.

An impairment loss of assets carried at cost less any accumulated depreciation or amortisation is recognised im-
mediately in profit or loss.

Goodwill acquired in a business combination is, from the acquisition date, allocated to each of the cash-
generating units, or companies of cash-generating units, that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the combina-
tion, irrespective of whether other assets or liabilities of the acquiree are assigned to those units or companies of units.
Financial assets

At each reporting date the Group assesses all financial assets, other than those at fair value through profit or loss,
to determine whether there is objective evidence that a financial asset or group of financial assets have been impaired.

An emergence period concept is applied to ensure that only impairments that exist at the reporting date are cap-
tured. The emergence period is defined as the time lapse between the occurrence of a trigger event (unidentified impair-
ment) and the impairment being identified at an individual account level (identified impairment).

A financial asset or a group of financial assets are impaired and impairment losses are incurred only if there is ob-
jective evidence of impairment as a result of one or more events that occurred after the initial recognition of the asset (a
‘loss event’) and that loss event (or events) has an impact on the estimated future cash flows of the financial asset or
group of financial assets that can be reliably estimated.
Criteria that are used by the Group in determining whether there is objective evidence of impairment include:

     high probability of insolvency.
If there is objective evidence that an impairment loss on loans and receivables has been incurred, the amount of

the loss is measured as the difference between the asset's carrying amount and the present value of estimated future cash
flows (excluding future credit losses that have not been incurred) discounted at the financial asset's original effective in-
terest rate. The carrying amount of the loan is reduced through the use of an allowance for credit losses account and the
loss is recognised as a credit impairment charge in profit or loss.

If the Group determines that no objective evidence of impairment exists for an individually assessed loan, wheth-
er significant or not, it includes the loan in a group of financial loans with similar credit risk characteristics and collec-
tively assesses for impairment. Loans that are individually assessed for impairment and for which an impairment loss is
recognised are not included in a collective assessment for impairment.

Impairment of groups of loans that are assessed collectively is recognised where there is objective evidence that a
loss event has occurred after the initial recognition of the group of loans but before the reporting date. In order to pro-
vide for latent losses in a group of loans that have not yet been identified as specifically impaired, a credit impairment
for incurred but not reported losses is recognised based on historic loss patterns and estimated emergence periods (time
period between the loss trigger events and the date on which the Group identifies the losses). Groups of loans are also
impaired when adverse economic conditions develop after initial recognition, which may impact future cash flows. The
carrying amount of groups of loans is reduced through the use of an allowance for credit losses account and the loss is
recognised as a credit impairment charge in profit or loss.

All significant counterparty relationships are reviewed periodically. Evidence of impairment may include indica-
tions that the debtors or a group of debtors is experiencing significant financial difficulty, default or delinquency in in-
terest or principal payments, the probability that they will enter bankruptcy or other financial reorganisation, and where
observable data indicate that there is a measurable decrease in the estimated future cash flows, such as changes in arrears
or economic conditions that correlate with defaults.

Impaired loans are defined as loans that are one day past the due date calculated on a cumulative basis by refer-
ence to the original contractual instalment due dates and are further categorised into the following categories:

   Non-performing loans are designated into this category when the loan becomes past due.
   Partial performing loans are past due but have had at least a partial performance by reference to the origi-
    nal contractual instalment due date within the last 2 months.
   Performing loans are loans that are not past due and are within contract term.

The impairment of non-performing loans takes into account past loss experience adjusted for changes in econom-
ic conditions and the nature and level of risk exposure since the recording of the historic losses.

The Group adopts a formulaic approach to its impaired loans. On non-performing loans a progressively higher
percentage loss rate is applied the longer a customer’s loan is past due and are grouped into aged categories as per note 3
of our combined financial statements included elsewhere in the Prospectus.

The Group assesses the probability of default by making reference to historical collection data. The historical col-
lection data are reviewed quarterly to reduce the difference between the impairment allowance estimate and actual loss
experience.

Rehabilitated loans are non-performing loans where an outstanding amount has been collected whether partial or
in full. Rehabilitated loans are monitored separately and are treated as either performing loans or non¬performing loans
based on proven subsequent performance history.
Impairment losses are recognised in profit or loss.
Subsequent to impairment, the effects of discounting unwind over time as interest income.

If, in a subsequent period, the amount of the impairment loss decreases and the decrease can be related objective-
ly to an event occurring after the impairment was recognised (such as an improvement in the customers’ credit rating),
the reversal of the previously recognised impairment loss is recognised in the combined statement of profit and loss and
other comprehensive income.

The reversal shall not result in a carrying amount of the financial asset that exceeds what the amortised cost
would have been had the impairment not been recognised at the date the impairment is reversed. The amount of the re-
versal shall be recognised in the combined statement of profit and loss and other comprehensive income. Impaired loans
(and the related impairment allowance) are written off at the impaired loans earliest of when they are past due for 24
months or when there is no likelihood of recalling future payments.

      Impaired loans (and the related impairment allowance) are written off at the earliest of when they are past due for
