about 95%.

Proprietary credit decisioning and scoring technology allowing scalability. We have made significant in-
vestments into the development of our own proprietary technology as we believe it provides a competitive
advantage. With our team of more than 20 dedicated IT professionals, we have created, in particular, an
advanced credit decisioning and scoring model system called “Jessie” that assigns to each loan application
a certain credit score or loan grade and a corresponding interest rate and maximum loan amount. “Jessie”
provides us with significant visibility and predictability in assessing the creditworthiness of our customers
and allows us to implement highly efficient and rigorous risk and credit management procedures. It is
based on highly granular algorithms that take into account a number of factors, including behavioural data,
transactional data and employment information. “Jessie” has already made more than 1,500,000 predic-
tions, since its latest deployment with a large number of APIs and AI features in November 2015 until to-
day. In addition, we have developed our cloud-based proprietary software solution called “FinCloud” that
is both an interface to our customers as well as to our internal loan management system. “FinCloud” ena-
bles us to access our customers’ bank statements and bank accounts at application date to better assess cre-
ditworthiness and assist the collection process. “FinCloud”, together with “Jessie”, provides the core tech-
nology platform for our products and services. Our ability to analyse and process big data volumes, utilis-
ing a tested and refined technology platform, has enabled us to grow our business significantly over the last
years while still operating with a default rate of 7.4% as of 31 December 2015. Our technology platform is
regularly improved and upgraded to avoid capacity constraints so that it scales with the needs of our busi-
ness and is easily adaptable to the specific needs of individual markets. As a result, our automated opera-
tions provide a significant time and cost advantage over traditional banks that typically run on legacy sys-
tems that are inflexible and slow to evolve. Our technology platform reduces the need for physical infra-
structure and lowers our costs, providing us with significant operating leverage, particularly when we are
able to further grow our business.

competitive_strength: Proprietary credit decisioning and scoring technology allowing scalability.

blobs.text:
   Strong focus on a convenient product and services offering with a high proportion of repeat customers.
    We place great emphasis on our customer relations. Our entire portfolio of products and services is de-
    signed to satisfy customer needs for simplicity, convenience and transparency. We aim to provide our cus-
    tomers easy online access to funding and other financial services, to offer transparent fee and interest struc-
    tures. In particular, our credit report and budgeting tool on our unique customised dashboard assist our cus-
    tomers with their financial planning and helps to improve credit behaviour and debt service discipline
    which, in turn, transforms existing customers into repeat customers, providing them access to better interest
    rates on lending services based on our “trust level” system. Our high proportion of repeat customers is one
    of the pillars of our business model. In the six-month period ended 31 December 2015, we experienced a
    customer retention rate (i.e. customers who have purchased at least two of our products in their customer
    lifetime) of more than 59%, which allows us to cross-sell new products and services, such as insurance
    products, and leverage existing credit score databases to reduce the costs associated with new customer ac-
    quisition. We have developed a customer service team delivering increasingly convenient remote customer
    support in local languages across the markets in which we operate. We continuously work to improve cus-
    tomer satisfaction by creating personal contact with customers through telephone calls, SMS, e-mails and
    chats to discuss product options, address customer queries, inform customers of their payment due dates to
    encourage on-time payment, discuss options for repayments as well as assist customers with their applica-
    tions. In addition, we focus on the quality of our call centre interaction and monitor customer satisfaction
    which is an on-going part of our quality control process. We believe that the quality of our customer ser-
    vice is one of the reasons why our customers keep coming back to us for additional products.
   Improved access to funding through deposit-taking licences. Shortly, we will improve our access to fund-
    ing by acquiring deposit taking licenses in various jurisdictions. These licenses will enable us to further ex-
    pand our business activities and reduce our costs of funding for our operations since we intend to expand
    our deposit taking business and offer a broader range of financial products and services. Our recent Acqui-
    sition – if consummated in its entirety – will provide us with access to further deposit-taking licenses in
    Ghana, Malawi, Mozambique and Uganda as well as access to a customer base of more than 1.3 million
    customers (as of 31 August 2015) which we expect will further reduce our costs of funding provided that
    we are able to pursue a restructuring and reorganisation of the Opportunity Banks as anticipated. Such ac-
    quisitions will also allow us to enhance our distribution capabilities through more diversified distribution
    channels for our products and services and, as a result, facilitate the further growth of our business opera-
    tions.
   Experienced management team with proven track record. Our senior management team has comprehen-
    sive and long-standing experience in microfinance in emerging markets, in particular in Sub-Saharan Afri-
    ca, with an average of over 15 years of relevant industry experience spanning the entire microfinance and

competitive_strength: Strong focus on a convenient product and services offering with a high proportion of repeat customers.
Improved access to funding through deposit-taking licences.
Experienced management team with proven track record.

blobs.text:
online lending value chain. David van Niekerk, one of our founders and our CEO, has been recognized as a
veteran in microfinance and has been involved in the industry for more than 19 years. He was one of the
first entrepreneurs to bring these financial products and services to Sub-Saharan African markets when he
founded South African based Blue Financial Services Limited (“Blue Financial Services”), a pan-African
microfinance company, in 2001, which got listed in 2006, and for which he served as CEO and Chairman
until the end of July 2010. Our management’s operational expertise has recently been strengthened by ad-
ditional management members who bring a strong focus in accounting, capital markets, finance, mergers
and acquisitions, corporate governance and risk management, thereby adding excellence to the team. We
believe their in-depth knowledge and significant experience of our interdisciplinary management team in
both the microfinance industry, and the markets in which we operate constitute a significant competitive
advantage in this period of rapid change in the banking industry, and provides extensive execution capabil-
ity for us to adapt and further pursue our growth.
Our Strategy

Through our vision in becoming a leading virtual bank, we strive to grow our business sustainably by focusing on
organic growth, further geographic expansion, product diversification and cross selling.
The following is a summary of the strategy we employ in furtherance of these objectives:

   Explore new markets through organic expansion and acquisitions. We have established a strong track
    record of growth, while diversifying our business across product categories and regions. While currently
    being active in nine African and two European countries, we monitor business development opportunities
    in other countries as well. We believe that the scalability of our business model and the high level of relia-
    bility and performance of our proprietary technology platform will allow us to penetrate new markets at
    much lower cost than traditional models. Through a holistic approach we intend to present customers with
    an all-inclusive package, historically only obtainable at high costs through “bricks and mortar” financial in-
    stitutions. Our customers can be serviced immediately and effectively by online products. New products
    are introduced continuously through our existing customer base fuelling growth. We believe this approach
    gives us a significant advantage compared to our competitors. We aim to leverage our existing expertise to
    invest in countries, in particular in Sub-Saharan Africa but also worldwide, where we believe to have an at-
    tractive customer base and high growth potential for our online lending business. For example, we just re-
    cently acquired the Opportunity Banks to substantially expand our geographic reach by adding Ghana,
    Mozambique, and Tanzania to our African footprint, enhance our competitive position in Kenya, Malawi,
    and Uganda, and increase our customer base to more than 1.5 million customers. We will continue to pur-
    sue attractive business opportunities by launching operations in selective emerging markets worldwide, or
    to opportunistically seize growth opportunities by pursuing selected acquisitions, over the next few years.
   Maintain and expand our customer base. We expect the transition from offline to online banking to con-
    tinue, and we aim to capitalize on this trend. By continuously developing our online offering, including our
    customer interaction tools, such as the credit report and the financial budgeting tool on our customised
    dashboard, providing our customers control of their financial status at a glance, we also seek to create an
    engaging customer experience that we believe will help us both to retain our existing customers and to at-
    tract new customers. We focus on the growing number of low and middle-income consumers who use al-
    ternative financial services because of their limited access to more traditional consumer credit or other fi-
    nancial products and services from banks, credit card companies and other lenders. While we served more
    than 175,000 customers from inception until 31 December 2015, such customers nevertheless represent on-
    ly about 0.1% of the total population in the ten countries we served (amounting to approximately 236.8
    million people in 2014)48. We believe that in particular the large percentage of people in our countries of
    operation who have no or just limited access to traditional banking products and services represents an op-
    portunity to significantly expand our customer base by leveraging our well-known brands and our localized
    offerings. We aim to further increase our market share in the countries we operate and to drive awareness
    for our brand through focused and localised marketing campaigns, relying on both traditional and digital
    marketing strategies. We will also actively evaluate opportunities to further partner with corporations and
    governments to implement our deduction-at-source collection scheme. Through the expansion and diversi-
    fication of our existing product portfolio, marketing and enhancements in customer service, we also intend
    to expand our products to small and medium entrepreneurs, as they are often in need of financial resources
    but have also been declined by traditional banks.
   Diversify our product offering and intensify cross-selling. We plan to continue our innovative approach,
    offering convenient online services as well as transparent and competitive financial products to customers

key_element_strategy: Explore new markets through organic expansion and acquisitions.
Maintain and expand our customer base.
Diversify our product offering and intensify cross-selling.

geographies in which we operate. With our customised dashboard we have developed a multi-functional
mobile application which we intend to make accessible in all countries in which we operate to unify our
current mobile offerings. Through this application, we intend to leverage our existing proprietary database
to introduce new products and services, including new lending products which require higher amounts of
funding such as longer term loans, but also eventually offer third-party financing services (including lend-
ing through crowd-funding). Supported by the Acquisition, we will intensify the development and intro-
duction of new banking products and services, such as savings, mobile transactions, transactional cards,
and remittances, to capture the entire revenue value chain for each customer. We also plan to roll-out our
insurance products to those markets where we do not already offer them to enhance our cross-selling func-
tionality on the back of our historically high customer retention rate (more than 59% in the six-month peri-
od ended 31 December 2015), thus extending each customer’s lifetime value. With regard to our insurance
products, which we currently only sell as agents on behalf of external insurance companies, we are also
considering to selectively act as an underwriter in the future. We also consider to broaden our insurance
portfolio by offering new products such as covers for agricultural catastrophe, income protection, and edu-
cation provider, as well as crop insurance. Finally, we intend to expand our product range even further by
adding deposit taking services for our customers. We will start deposit taking activities in the near future
under the deposit taking licences of GetBucks Zimbabwe and of the Opportunity Banks we recently ac-
quired by way of the Acquisition.
History and Key Milestones

We commenced our business operations in 2011. Over the last five years, our Group has steadily grown in terms
of revenue by continuously expanding our geographic presence as well as our customer base. Within the scope of our ex-
pansions in Africa and to Southern and Eastern Europe, we have tested and refined our product portfolio, increased our
operational efficiency in terms of new market entries, developed and optimised our loan approval technology, and im-
proved our legal and regulatory compliance processes.
The following is a description of the major milestones in our Group's history:

   In 2011, GetBucks Mauritius was incorporated as holding company of the Group and we commenced busi-
    ness in South Africa via a licence agreement with GetBucks South Africa.
   Between 2011 and 2015, we expanded gradually to various other Sub-Saharan African markets, including
    Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.
   In 2014 and 2015, we expanded our operations to Poland and Spain, establishing a base for further oppor-
    tunistic growth in Europe and thereby tested and refined our product portfolio in other geographic regions
    as well.
   In July 2015, our local subsidiary in Zimbabwe, GetBucks Zimbabwe, was licenced by the Reserve Bank
    of Zimbabwe (“RBZ”) to operate as a deposit taking microfinance institution.
   In October 2015, we entered into a share purchase agreement with subsidiaries of Opportunity International
    to acquire the Opportunity Banks. Thereby, we intend to expand our geographic reach to Ghana, Tanzania,
    Mozambique as well as enhance our competitive position in Malawi, Kenya and Uganda.
   In December 2015, MyBucks S.A., Luxembourg, became the ultimate holding company of our Group.
   In January 2016, GetBucks Zimbabwe was listed on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange in order to facilitate
    our business operations in Zimbabwe. In addition, we also commenced our operations in Namibia and
    Uganda.
Our Business
Products and Services
Overview

Our broad portfolio of virtual banking products includes lending, insurance and banking, and is supported by ser-
vices such as mobile banking, credit reports with credit education features, financial budgeting, and emergency cover
through insurance. However, we do not yet offer all these products and services in all jurisdictions.

Our products and services are designed to be intuitive and easy for customers to use. Through our proprietary
technology platform, they can be accessed through online channels (web and mobile) as well as internet service points.
The credit assessment of our proprietary credit decisioning and scoring technology combines an ever increasing number
of traditional and alternative data points which translate to a total of 45 features to enable fast and automated disburse-
ment of loans within fifteen minutes of approval after a multitude of financial background checks and profiling through
APIs which we use to link our platform to third party tools, websites and other applications.

We currently offer our products and services under the three brands: GetBucks, GetSure and GetBanked. The fol-
lowing chart provides an overview about our three lines of business:

GetBucks – Our Lending Solution.

Under our brand GetBucks, we offer unsecured single payment and instalment loans to individuals that are in the
low and middle-income segment, yet gainfully employed:

   Single payment loans. Our single payment loans are short term, unsecured loans provided in principal
    amounts of between approximately €30 and €500 for terms between 1 and 6 months. We offer our single
    payment loans in all of our countries of operation, mainly to employees of large corporations. In the year
    ended 30 June 2015, our single payment loans accounted for about 14.3% of our revenue from lending.
   Instalment loans. Our instalment loans are longer-term, unsecured loans in amounts of between approxi-
    mately €300 and €5,000 for terms between 6 and 60 months. Instalment loans generally require repayment
    of portions of the outstanding principal balance in multiple monthly instalments. Our instalment loans also
    allow customers to settle existing loan amounts and increase the number of instalments in increments of
    their choosing, up to the provided loan limit. The customer may repay the outstanding loan balance in full
    at any time or make required minimum payments in accordance with the terms of the loan agreement. Cur-
    rently, we offer our instalment loans only in Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia
    and Zimbabwe, mainly to government employees where a secure deduction method, such as our deduction-
    at-source scheme, is in place to ensure successful collection. However, part of our strategy is to roll-out our
    offering of instalment loans in all countries in which we operate. In the year ended 30 June 2015, our in-
    stalment loans accounted for about 85.7% of our revenue from lending.

All loans are disbursed either via electronic funds transfer to an applicant’s bank account or via a mobile wallet.
From the date of our inception until 31 December 2015, the average size of our disbursed loans amounted to approxi-
mately €230 for each loan. In the same period, our disbursed loans had an average term of 6 months.

To supplement our loan offering, we also developed an interactive “ecosystem” which assists our customers to
qualify for longer-term instalment loans and to fulfil their credit obligations. The system consists of our unique, custom-
ised dashboard, which is available to our customers at any time and any place where there is internet access. The dash-
board intends to give our customers a quick, simple and transparent overview about their savings balances and targets,
personal credit available, and trust levels, and offers access to a personalized credit report and a budgeting tool:

   Credit report. Our customised credit report is a tool that keeps our customers informed of their current
    credit score and credit profile. Accessing information from the local credit bureaus, it provides continuous
    feedback on credit score movement, gives tips on how to improve a personal credit score and provides fi-
    nancial understanding and education based on spending habits. If a customer has requested credit from an-
    other lender, the App will automatically provide an overview of what can be further borrowed from My-
    Bucks, and at what rate. In addition, the App which monitors the credit report database will also provide a
    notification to the customer in the event that an unauthorised credit check is performed, enabling the cus-
    tomer to issue a fraud notification immediately. We currently offer our credit report to our customers in
    Botswana, Kenya, South Africa and Spain.
   Budgeting tool. Our budgeting tool assists customers in tracking their spending, and uses push notifica-
    tions to alert a customer if they are exceeding their personal budget. Electronic bank account scraping

technology allows customers to have access to our budgeting tool. This tool provides customers with real
time information about spending activity on their bank account. It helps customers to understand about
how to budget, as well as how to borrow for the right reasons. Spending limit alerts are pushed to custom-
ers via an App. Within the App, our customers can categorise and set limits on their spending themselves.
Customers get notified in real time if they are exceeding their budget.

In the year ended 30 June 2015, we generated revenue of €29.8 million under our GetBucks brand. As of 31 De-
cember 2015, we had more than 150,000 customers and an aggregate loan book of €37.0 million.
GetSure – Our Insurance Solution.

Under our brand GetSure, we offer (currently only as an agent on behalf of external insurance companies and only
in selected countries) a variety of insurance solutions to complement our lending offering:

Credit cover. Our credit cover is designed to protect a customer in terms of its debt obligations in the event
of death, disability, dreaded disease or retrenchment. Our credit cover is offered to customers in Botswana,
Kenya, Malawi, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.
Legal cover. Our legal cover is designed to cover a customer and immediate family members in the event
of legal service requirements. Our legal cover is available in Botswana, South Africa and Zimbabwe.
Funeral cover. Our funeral cover is designed to cover funeral benefits. Our funeral cover is available in
Botswana, Malawi, South Africa and Zimbabwe.
Medical cover. Our medical cover is an innovative product that covers day-to-day medical expenses as
well as hospitalisation and dread diseases. Our medical cover is offered to our customers in Botswana and
South Africa.

We service our customers through a fully integrated front-end website (getsuregroup.com) and aim to process all
claims made under our insurance covers within one hour. In the year ended 30 June 2015, we derived 78% of our insur-
ance revenue from our credit life cover. In the same period, our funeral and legal cover accounted for 13% and 10% of
our insurance revenue, respectively. As part of our growth strategy, we intend to expand our insurance offering to all
countries in which we operate. In addition, we are currently considering to selectively act as underwriter in the future.

In the year ended 30 June 2015, we generated revenue of €1.5 million under our GetSure brand. As of 31 Decem-
ber 2015, we had more than 135,000 policy holders and more than 210,000 policies.
GetBanked – Our Banking Solution.

Following the acquisition of the Opportunity Banks, we will, under our brand GetBanked, continue to leverage
our technology platform in order to reach rural areas in the countries in which we operate and reduce the cost of entry in-
to the financial services space for our customers. This allows us to service a wider market, catering for customers who do
not have access to traditional banking facilities at lower cost. Our technology infrastructure allows our customers to in-
teract with our virtual banking platform, which offers products like savings accounts, mobile transactions and transac-
tional cards, at any time and any place and enables our customers’ access to banking facilities, thus servicing our custom-
ers’ life cycle holistically and conveniently. We believe that banking customers through the use of our technology plat-
form enable us to better understand our customers’ needs, based on their spending habits and transaction history, allow-
ing us to manage our customers’ requirements, whilst allowing for improvement of their risk-scoring criteria, collections
efficiency and overall customer management. In future, we are also considering offering our customers an even broader
variety of banking products and services, and particularly, the possibility of making remittances.
Processes
Credit Application

We use a comprehensive credit analysis process to provide financial resources as single payment loans or instal-
ment loans to our customers quickly and efficiently. In principle, our technology platform allows for fast and automated
disbursements of loans within 15 minutes of approval, subject to the complete provision of information by our customer,
the availability of relevant third-party information, different disbursement mechanisms and geographical locations.
Our credit application process follows the described order from the first loan application to loan repayment:

   Registration and customer verification. We provide a new or existing customer with various channels in
    order to access new funds as well as administer them via a self-service portal. These channels include our
    website, mobile applications as well as Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (“USSD”)49 functionali-

49
 Unstructured Supplementary Service Data is a protocol used by GSM cellular telephones to communicate with the service provider’s computers.
USSD can be used for Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) browsing, prepaid call-back service, mobile-money services, location-based content ser-
                                                                        123

ty. Customers are required to register on our website and provide us with their details, including details
    about their person, address, employment status, banking activities, affordability as well as their closest
    relatives. Once we have obtained this information, our system commences customer verification and risk
    classification via a credit bureau, in accordance with the applicable national law (e.g., the National Credit
    Act in South Africa), which then informs their affordability. In addition, customer details are also verified
    against our internal AI fraud detection module “Watson” which supplements our “Jessie” credit decision-
    ing and scoring model system. Once customers have passed all required checks, they are placed into a risk
    classification as per our trust level rules. Customers can then apply for additional credit depending on their
    trust level, and the offers associated with that trust level. There are also other variables within the system
    that will affect their trust level moving it either up or down, such as good repayment behaviour. We ensure
    that customers are kept informed for the duration of the loan process by triggering the appropriate commu-
    nication using digital channels such as SMS, e-mail or push notifications.
   Loan Application. Our customers can select the value of their loan up to a certain amount. However, prior
    to a credit application, customers are required to electronically sign their credit agreement displaying loan
    details, containing the amount, repayment amount, costs, interest rate as well as the terms and conditions
    for the agreement. Customers are also required to submit bank statements in order for us to verify their in-
    come, unless they are comfortable to opt into using Yodlee, a secure API, which provides fast, efficient,
    secure online account verification. The customer will then enter a One Time Pin (OTP) which serves as a
    final verification. Upon submission, the application is queued for a vetting process where the following de-
    tails are validated: their employer, their bank statements (where a physical bank statement submitted, or
    Yodlee is utilised), bank account details (an automated check using a bank interface) as well as affordabil-
    ity details. For an application to be successful, the customer must satisfy several criteria that we establish
    and adapt as needed, including requirements in respect of gender, age, marital status and credit history, and
    an absence of overdue borrowings in the past. The exact criteria and specific requirements to meet each cri-
    teria vary slightly among our different countries. Once all these have been validated the credit agreement is
    approved, and the loan amount to the customer scheduled for payment. We ensure that customers are kept
    informed for the duration of the loan process by triggering the appropriate communication using digital
    channels such as SMS, e-mail or push notifications.
   Payment. Payments are expedited via a bank interface. Our finance department is responsible for this func-
    tion and two levels of authorisation are required in order to approve the payment that will be released to the
    customer’s bank account via electronic funds transfer (EFT) or as mobile payments. We ensure that cus-
    tomers are kept informed for the duration of the payment process by triggering the appropriate communica-
    tion using digital channels such as SMS, e-mail or push notifications.
   Collections. Collections are managed using a single gateway and is system driven and automated negating
    the need for intervention by our employees. Payment instructions are loaded two days prior to the custom-
    er’s repayment date in order to schedule the deduction with the different banks. Successful receipts from
    the gateway are automatically receipted against the customer’s account. Failed receipts received from the
    gateway are flagged accordingly and then managed using a separate process by specialists in our collec-
    tions department, adept at handling accounts in arrears. We keep customers informed for the duration of
    the collections process by triggering the appropriate communication using digital channels such as SMS, e-
    mail or push notifications.

vices, menu-based information services, and as part of configuring the phone on the network. Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) is a
standard developed by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) to describe the protocols for second-generation (2G) digital cellu-
lar networks used by mobile phones.
The following chart provides an overview of the different steps in our application process:
Customer Identification

In order to identify our customers to make an informed credit decision, we make use of credit bureau data, bank
statements as well as Yodlee, a secure API, which provides fast, efficient, secure online account verification.
Credit Scoring

Scoring and credit policies are centrally steered by our risk team. We measure and monitor the performance of
each credit portfolio’s actual risk key performance indicators on different aggregation levels at daily, weekly, and month-
ly cycles. We have developed what we believe to be a high level of expertise in our markets with our proprietary credit
scoring databases that give us invaluable insight into customer behaviour.

We operate with a relatively high rejection rate for loan applications (36% as of 31 December 2015). The reasons
for the relatively high assessment of our proprietary credit-scoring rate are scoring and optimised risk guidelines in order
to minimise the rate of loans that customers cannot pay back. Minimising this “credit loss rate” allows us to enhance the
process of further building up our customer base, as it is not only important for us to reduce our operating expenses, of
which credit losses are a large portion, but also to retain repeat customers. This can only be achieved if we reject applica-
tions that indicate a high chance of eventual loan default. In some instances we also initially deny a loan application for a
certain amount of money, but approve a loan application for the same customer for a lower amount.

These decisions are prepared by our proprietary credit decisioning and scoring model system “Jessie” that assigns
each loan applied for a score or grade and, in certain jurisdictions, also a corresponding interest rate and loan amount.
“Jessie” is based on advanced machine learning credit scoring algorithm that allows us to create a customer default and
risk profile for every single customer any time they request a loan. The algorithm thereby takes into account a number of
factors, including behavioural data, transactional data and employment information. In order to strengthen credit score-
cards, we train our algorithm and various structured data sources, including our own customer database, credit bureau da-
ta and collection companies’ databases. We recently also started expanding our models to include alternative data sources
that include transactional level data and unstructured data, such as customer behavioural patterns captured from our
online channels. We continuously improve “Jessie” with additional application programming interfaces (“APIs”) and ar-
tificial intelligence (AI) features to update and enhance its self-learning credit scoring algorithms. Since its latest de-
ployment in November 2015 until today, “Jessie” has made more than 1,500,000 predictions.
Delivery

Our MyBucks app has been added to the Google Play Store, Apple Store and Microsoft Store to optimise custom-
er dashboard access via mobile channels. All functionality, as available on the web and mobile portals are offered via the
app. This, in combination with the benefits of mobile access has resulted in a significant uptake of the app. In order to
develop virtual offerings and educate customers, we have placed self-help stations at service outlets in certain countries.
Online assistants supervise these self-help stations, and assist customers with the electronic application process, ultimate-
ly enabling them to interact with us on their own.

Subject to different disbursement mechanisms and geographical locations, we aim to deliver loans to our custom-
ers via electronic funds transfer (EFT), as well as mobile payments, as quickly as 15 minutes after loan approval.
Collection and Disposal

Collections form a fundamental aspect of our business. We tailor collection methods in accordance to the market
in which we operate, which is mainly based on the technology available, the regulatory and legal framework, and the ex-
pected customer risk.
The collection methods we use include:

   Deduction-at-source. Deduction-at-source is a method that is ideally used with large corporations and
    government entities. We sign agreements with the employers of our customers who are employees of such
    corporations or entities, who in turn deduct loan instalments on our behalf. This is especially pertinent in
    scenarios where there is little or no available credit bureau data, no reliable electronic debit order means
    exist, and employees are not able to get access to credit and insurance. Although a legacy collection meth-
    od, there have been advances and positive improvements to the system, with the aim being to prevent over-
    indebtedness. One such example, which is extensively used by us, is electronic salary and deductions veri-
    fication: before granting a loan, “FinCloud”, our proprietary customer interface and loan management sys-
    tem, can (in real time) assess whether an individual is employed, and if he or she has existing deductions or
    financial commitments affected against his or her salary. This system prevents customers from borrowing
    more than they can afford to repay and what has been agreed with the employer, and as a result, borrowing
    limits can be set and managed quite effectively. This method mitigates the risk of bad debt impairments
    significantly. Loan books that utilise the deduction-at-source scheme typically have the lowest non-
    performing loan ratios, as the risk exposure resides with the employer.
   Direct customer deduction. This is also a “pull” methodology where we make use of technologies such as
    electronic debit orders, debit order tracking and card deductions. By employing these technologies, risk is
    significantly mitigated in the loan granting process. This solution is mainly used in markets that have a
    more sophisticated technological infrastructure, and is supplemented by additional risk mitigation process-
    es like electronic identification verification, bank account validation and checking of electronic credit bu-
    reau information.
   Push payments. In certain environments and in instances where specific MyBucks products are used, a
    high degree of trust is placed in the customer to pay loan instalments. This methodology is mainly applied
    in scenarios where deduction-at-source schemes or direct customer deductions are not available or feasible,
    and where customers have progressed to a high trust level with us.
Non-performing Loan Management

Defaulted payments are managed from the first day of a missed instalment. From an operational point of view, the
process is initiated with instant SMS and e-mail communication to the customer, addressing the failed status of their loan
instalment. Thereafter, we follow up with a telephonic interaction in order to determine the cause, and ideally to provide
a solution for the missed payment. The failed instalment will be followed up on a continual basis until it reaches 90 days
overdue. After reaching 90 days overdue, the case then enters an external debt collection process whereby a third party
attempts to collect the full amount of the outstanding loan. If this external debt collection process proves unsuccessful,
the account is then retracted and the proposed debt sold off to third party debt collectors at a rate of between 10% and
20% in currency unit, or written off, depending on the size and age of the debt.

For more information on the impairment on loans, see "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Posi-
tion and Results of Operations―Key Factors affecting our Results of Operations― Loan Portfolio Performance as Lev-
el of Bad Debt" and “Risk Factors― Risks Related to Our Business and Our Industry―The proposed changes in ac-
counting standards, such as IFRS 9, could have a substantial negative impact on our capital position.”.
Information Technology

We power financial products and services using our proprietary digital technology platform. For this purpose, we
have a Group-level IT department which develops and maintains the necessary IT infrastructure for our business, mean-
ing the IT platforms, technologies and solutions necessary for our websites through which we provide our services and
products to our customers. As of December 2015, our IT department had 17 full-time equivalents specialists which are
mainly located in Pretoria, South Africa. In addition, we also have a database of additional consultants available on a
contingency basis to assist on bespoke projects as necessary.

Our IT network is configured with multiple layers of security to isolate our databases from unauthorised access.
We use sophisticated security protocols for communication among applications and we encrypt private information, such
as an applicant’s social security number. All of our public and private APIs and websites use Secure Sockets Layer. We

and p
 126

also use 256 Bit SHA password encryption and Java Web Token to manage session authentication. Dimension Data’s In-
ternet Solutions handles physical access management to our network. We also make use of firewalls to ensure that our
network is secure.

We do not own data centres. Instead, our systems infrastructure is deployed on a private cloud hosted in co-located
redundant tier 1 data centres managed by third-party service providers in Johannesburg, South Africa, and Amsterdam,
The Netherlands. We believe that we have enough physical capacity to support our operations for the foreseeable future.
We have multiple layers of redundancy to ensure reliability of network service and with 99.8% uptime in the past. We
also have a working data redundancy model with comprehensive backups of our databases and software made nightly. To
date there have been no major disruptions in the operation of our websites or third party cloud servers.
Research and Development
Software Development and IT Solutions

As part of our research and development activities, we have developed and utilized proprietary and custom-
designed technologies and in-house IT solutions, such as our cloud-based proprietary customer interface and loan man-
agement system “FinCloud”, which is designed to be both powerful enough to handle the large volumes of data required
to evaluate customer applications and flexible enough to capitalize on changing customer preferences, market trends and
regulatory changes. Furthermore, the information gathered from our loan management system allows us to focus on cus-
tomers, whether existing or potential, who we believe are more likely to provide us with better credit performance. Using
this approach, we are able to build a valuable list of customers who use the credit products offered, and to whom we can
market our new product offerings. In addition, we have also fully integrated third party platforms such as several gov-
ernment platforms into our systems to ensure seamless customer and internal processes.

We have also developed and periodically improved custom loan processing and debt collection systems that are
based on Microsoft.Net technologies. The systems which we use share a common code, which is the same across our
countries of operation. This ensures that our websites always have a modern look and functionality whether viewed on
desktops or on mobile web. This has historically allowed us to launch our business in a new country in approximately
three weeks, and to launch businesses in several countries in parallel. Coupled with remote data centres management, we
have been able to quickly replicate our business model in new markets and expect to be able to do so in the future.
Artificial Intelligence

Recently, we also established a data science development team (the “Data Science Team”) with six full-time
equivalent specialists as part of our vision to realise data as a business asset from which value can be extracted in the
form of better-informed decision making. Achieving this vision rests on two pillars: a big data strategy where the amount
of unstructured operational data being collected is drastically increased, and then building state-of-the-art AI models to
unlock the value encapsulated in this data through advanced analysis and data mining. The big data infrastructure is built
on an Apache Cassandra NoSQL50 warehouse running on a local cloud platform, with Apache Spark51 used for distribut-
ed data processing and analytics.

A number of cost saving operational improvements have been possible through the use of highly sophisticated
AI predictive models designed and developed internally by our Data Science team. Thereby, the team thereby focuses
mainly on two areas: fraud detection and prevention, i.e. the development of our internal AI fraud detection module
called “Watson” which supplements our credit decisioning and scoring model called “Jessie”. “Jessie” is a self-learning
system that continuously evaluates customer behavioural patterns from historical loans to very accurately predict the
probability of a default by a customer, for a particular time and for a particular product. “Jessie” does not approve or de-
cline loan applications but rather influence the product offering of a customer based on an adjustable loan term specific
risk appetite, which allows us to better measure and manage the combined risk of our loan book.
Customer Portfolio
Overview

As of 31 December 2015, we had more than 175,000 active customers and former customers who received one or
more loans in the past. Our customer base comprises a wide cross-section of our markets’ populations. In 2015, we expe-
rienced about 60% male and 40% female.

50
   Apache Cassandra is an open source distributed database management system designed to handle large amounts of data across many commodity
servers, providing high availability with no single point of failure. Cassandra offers support for clusters spanning multiple datacentres, with asynchro-
nous masterless replication allowing low latency operations for all customers. A ‘non SQL’ (NoSQL) database provides a mechanism for storage and
retrieval of data which is modelled in means other than the tabular relations used in relational databases.

51
     Apache Spark is an open source cluster computing framework run by the Apache Software Foundation.
Customer Service

We have a customer service division with nine full-time equivalent employees delivering remote customer support
in more than seven local languages across the jurisdictions in which we operate. We have a centralized customer service
department that adheres to standard operating procedures and best practice. We believe our high quality customer service
is a core competitive advantage. The customer service division makes use of the following communications channels:
telephone calls, e-mails as well as online chats on our website. The responsibility of the customer service division is to
improve the customer service experience, and enable all new customers to engage with us regarding product options,
queries, and payment due dates. It also encourages customers to pay on-time, discuss options for late payments and per-
form back office tasks, such as assisting customers to make manual payments, finalize their applications, and detect
fraud.

We monitor key performance indicators in the customer service division in order to achieve consistent perfor-
mance and improve our customer service and motivate our employees to strive for efficiency by rewarding them for ex-
cellence, efficiency, performance and quality.
Customer Retention and Repeat Customers

In order to develop and retain the customer and motivate the repeated use of our financial products and services,
we operate a trust level system. This is a loyalty system which develops the customer from level 1 to level 7 by demon-
strating positive credit behaviour, completing compulsory and optional surveys and most importantly, repayment of his
or her loan. The future loan amount and rate is determined by the ranking received. The system was designed to enhance
customer retention through discounts and perks based on positive customer behaviour, as well as the provision of addi-
tional customer information. This in turn, not only improves financial literacy, but also positively impacts collections.

This is complemented by our credit report, which assists in the education of the customer by improving his or her
understanding of how he or she is perceived and ranked by credit agencies on how to improve his or her standing through
improved credit behaviour. This has optimised the loan application and qualification process, allowing us – as we believe
– to leapfrog competitors who do not offer such credit reports.

In addition to our pure lending products, we have introduced a budgeting tool, which allows our customers to bet-
ter understand their income and expenses, as well as credit health reports, which provides them access to their credit re-
port together with advice on how to improve their credit rating.

We consider our relationship with our employees to be good and have not been party to any relevant significant

Human Resources

We employ local talent in all the countries in which we operate. To ensure a mutually beneficial and constructive
relationship, our recruitment approach is to realise a balance of skills, experience and a culture fit.

Our Human Resource support function is distributed in each territory where we operate. However, employee pay-
roll, communications, policies and programmes, are monitored and vetted centrally at our South African headquarter as a
risk management measure, as well as to manage strategic alignment.
Sales and marketing

We operate a variety of brands across a number of countries. Each region has its own customised marketing plan
that aligns with our Group’s marketing strategy, and is designed to ensure maximum reach. We make use of a strong mix
of traditional and digital marketing strategies in order to drive brand awareness, as well as tactical sales drivers to attract
customers. Once a customer is in our “ecosystem”, targeted marketing activities are designed to drive retention. By na-
ture of being a FinTech company, we place a big emphasis on digital marketing by deploying various tactics such as
Google AdWords (an online advertising service that enables advertisers to compete to display brief advertising copy to
web users, based in part on keywords, predefined by the advertisers, that might link the copy to the content of web pages
shown to users), digital banner advertising, digital mailers, affiliate partnerships as well as social media, all of which
drive traffic to our website. In addition, we constantly strive to optimise our website and Google expenditure through the
use of consistent and on-going search engine optimisation (SEO), as well as ensure a seamless customer experience
through the deployment of good user experience (UX) practices. Statistical data accumulated from our activities help in-

form changes to our strategy, which can be made in real-time, ensuring our agility, and that the money we spend has ma-
terial impact. Digital activities are far more prominent in digitally savvy, developed countries.

Within more traditionally focused markets across Africa, channels include television, radio, print and newspaper,
billboards as well as in branch posters and flyers, ensuring that we create and maintain a credible brand. Digital activities
are on the increase in these regions, where we push education to promote online adoption, to drive customers further into
the online space with confidence and assurance.

In addition to the above, we are currently in the process of applying for a certification by the Centre for Financial
Inclusions’ SMART campaign (www.smartcampaign.org), a global initiative of MFIs to promote full transparency in the
pricing, terms, and conditions of all financial products.

South Africa, which are our main premises. In Luxembourg, we currently use the premises of a provider of secretarial
administrative and domiciliary services (Orangefield, Luxembourg).

Share Purchase Agreement regarding the Opportunity Banks

On 27 October 2015, GetBucks Mauritius as purchaser entered into a share purchase agreement with Opportunity
Transformation Investments, Inc. and Opportunity Microfinance Investments Limited as sellers (collectively, the
“Sellers”), as well as Opportunity, Inc. as warrantor (the “Warrantor”, and together with the Sellers and GetBucks Mau-
ritius, the “Parties”) concerning the acquisition of the Sellers’ majority shareholdings (the “Opportunity Shares”) in a
Pan-African group of companies consisting of:

   three banks in Malawi, Mozambique and Uganda (Opportunity International Bank Malawi Limited (“Op-
    portunity Bank Malawi”), Banco Oportunidade de Moçambique, SA (“Opportunity Bank Mozam-
    bique”), and Opportunity Bank Uganda Limited (“Opportunity Bank Uganda”));
   one savings and loans company in Ghana (Opportunity International Savings and Loans Limited (“Oppor-
    tunity Bank Ghana”)); and
   two non-bank financial institutions (“NBFIs”) in Kenya and Tanzania (Opportunity Kenya Limited (“Op-
    portunity Bank Kenya”) and Opportunity Tanzania Limited (“Opportunity Bank Tanzania”)),

for a purchase price of approximately €12.55 million, subject to potential purchase price adjustments at closing. The
agreed purchase price shall be paid partly as a cash consideration and partly as consideration in kind, consisting of an ag-
gregate of up to 250,000 Shares to be issued for the benefit of the Warrantor at closing.

Pursuant to the Opportunity SPA, the Group shall be entitled to use the “Opportunity” trade name and trademarks
and all related trade names and trademarks currently used by the Opportunity Banks (the “Opportunity IP”) in connec-
tion with the Opportunity Banks for a period of six months following the final closing date subject to certain notification
requirements. According to the Opportunity SPA, the Warrantor shall also be entitled, but not obliged, to appoint, inter
alia, one non-executive director of the Board and of each board of directors of each of the Opportunity Banks, as long as
the Warrantor’s shareholding in the Company remains above a certain threshold.

The Opportunity SPA contains customary representations and warranties that the Sellers on the one hand, and
GetBucks Mauritius on the other hand, have made to one another. The assertions embodied in those representations and
warranties were made solely for purposes of the Opportunity SPA, and are subject to important qualifications and limita-
tions agreed to by the Parties in connection with negotiating the terms of the Opportunity SPA.

The Opportunity SPA also contains certain termination rights for GetBucks Mauritius, including the right to ter-
minate the Opportunity SPA, in respect of an Opportunity Bank, in the event of a material adverse change at such Oppor-
tunity Bank, and, in respect of the whole Opportunity SPA, upon any material breach of either the Sellers or the Warran-
tor of any of their material obligations under the Opportunity SPA.

The Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including regulatory approval for the transfer of shares
of each of the Opportunity Bank and the operation of business of each Opportunity Bank by GetBucks Mauritius follow-
ing the closing in all countries concerned. The Parties agreed on separate closings for each of the Opportunity Banks. If
the closing in respect of any Opportunity Bank has not occurred on or before 30 June 2016 (the “Long Stop Date”), or
such later date at GetBucks Mauritius and the Warrantor may agree (as they did with respect to Opportunity Bank Ugan-
da), GetBucks Mauritius shall not be obliged to acquire and the Sellers shall not be required to sell, the Opportunity
Shares in respect of such Opportunity Bank.

As of the date of the Prospectus, the Acquisition has not been consummated with respect to any of the acquired
Opportunity Banks. While the Company expects to be able to consummate most of the closings by 30 June 2016, the
closing for the Opportunity Bank in Uganda has been delayed and may not occur. Opportunity International as seller is
currently pursuing an investigation concerning a potential misconduct of certain individuals of Opportunity Bank Ugan-
da’s management, including the CEO, which is unrelated to the Acquisition. Based on the initial findings of the investi-
gation, the Central Bank of Uganda decided to remove the CEO of Opportunity Bank Uganda with immediate effect as of
22 March 2016. It is the Parties common understanding that such event entitles GetBucks Mauritius to refrain from clos-
ing the Acquisition with respect to Opportunity Bank Uganda. However, as GetBucks Mauritius reserved its right to de-
termine whether to close the Acquisition with respect to Opportunity Bank Uganda depending on the outcome of the in-
vestigation and the final reporting on the audited financial statements for Opportunity Bank Uganda as of and for the year
ending 31 December 2015, the Parties entered into a side letter to the Opportunity SPA on 6 April 2016, according to
which the long stop date (i.e. the date after which the obligations to close will terminate) with respect to the Opportunity
Bank Uganda shall be postponed to 31 December 2016. As of the date of the Prospectus, the result of the investigation at

Opportunity Bank Uganda, and in turn the decision of GetBucks Mauritius whether to close the Acquisition for such
bank, remains unclear. Moreover, the audit of the annual financial statements for the Opportunity Bank Uganda has not
been completed due to the internal investigation. For that reason, the pro forma financial information included elsewhere
in the Prospectus does not cover the Opportunity Bank Uganda. Accordingly, the financial information regarding Oppor-
tunity Bank Uganda is not part of the pro forma financial information included elsewhere in the Prospectus, see “Pro
Forma Financial Information”.
Acquisition of Komo Finance Portfolio

With effect as of 1 June 2015, GetBucks South Africa acquired from Ecsponent Credit Services Proprietary Lim-
ited (“Ecsponent Credit Services”) the existing payroll lending business of Komo Finance Proprietary Limited (“Komo
Finance”) and Ecsponent Credit Services (the “Komo Finance Portfolio”), consisting of all current performing loans,
customer names and the sole right to service such customers, the corresponding payroll-deduction contracts with the cus-
tomers’ employers, as well as the relevant marketing and IP rights. The purchase price for the Komo Finance Portfolio
amounts to €3.9 million plus additional interest of 11% per annum thereon, to be paid in monthly instalments with the
final payment due on 30 June 2016. GetBucks South Africa has ceded and pledged its debtors book to continually cover
the value of one and a half times the outstanding balance of the purchase price as security. GetBucks South Africa also
took over the service contracts with the key management, including the service contract with the managing director of the
business unit, to continue managing the relationship. Following this acquisition, Komo Finance and Ecsponent Credit
Services ceased to offer any consumer finance services in South Africa.

proceedings (including any such proceedings which are pending or threatened of which we are aware) which may have, or
have had in the recent past, significant effects on the Company’s and/or our Group’s financial position or profitability.

During the ordinary course of our business activities, we are, from time to time, involved in, or may be threatened
with, legal proceedings, both as a claimant and as a defendant, claims or accusations, none of which is, either individual-
ly or as a whole, material with regard to our Group’s financial position or profitability.

The outcome of legal proceedings and other legal matters is always difficult to accurately predict and outcomes
that are not consistent with our view of the merits can occur. We regularly analyze current information, including our de-
fenses and insurance coverage and, as we deem necessary, provide accruals for probable liabilities for the eventual dispo-
sition of these matters.

The following matter summarized below represents the only legal and regulatory proceedings that we currently
believe could have a material adverse effect on our financial position and profitability.
Application of the National Credit Regulator in South Africa

GetBucks South Africa is currently in dispute with the National Credit Regulator (NCR), an administrative body
established by the National Credit Act which is responsible for the regulation of the South African credit industry.

Based on its findings in a routine inspection on GetBucks South Africa in September 2014, the NCR made an ap-
plication with the National Consumer Tribunal (NCT), an independent adjudicative entity in South Africa, in November
2014. Therein, due to the public awareness of this matter the NCR accuses GetBucks South Africa of various breaches of
the National Credit Act, including granting credit recklessly and without assessing or keeping records of the consumers’
debt repayment history, financial obligations or proof of income, as well as overcharging and wrongfully levying fees on
consumers. On the basis of these allegations, the NCR has applied for an order of the NCT against GetBucks South Afri-
ca to either (i) refund consumers and cancel GetBucks South Africa’s registration as a credit provider in South Africa, or,
alternatively, (ii) impose a fine of 1 million ZAR (corresponding to approximately €59 thousand) or 10% of its annual
turnover and to suspend GetBucks South Africa’s registration as a credit provider in South Africa for a period of 5 years.

As collateral defense to the charges brought against it, GetBucks South Africa has approached the High Court of
South Africa in March 2015 for a declaratory order declining the validity and enforceability of certain regulations that
were promulgated under the National Credit Act and which form the legal basis of the alleged accusations. Other South
African credit providers facing similar accusations by the NCR, have also disputed the contested regulations in front of
the High Court which already led to subsequent amendments of the contested regulations. However, none of these
amendments brought an end to the GetBucks South Africa’s legal proceedings before the High Court. A hearing at the
High Court has not yet taken place but is expected for the first half of 2016. NCR’s application with the NCT will stay
pending until a decision by the High Court is reached.

In addition, the following description contains another legal matter which we do not consider material but worth men-
tioning for other reasons:
Investigations relating to the 2017 Notes

On 3 February 2014, GetBucks Invest, our Austrian finance subsidiary, issued a single tranche of €5.2 million
11.0% fixed rate notes due 3 February 2017, secured by a corporate guarantee of GetBucks Mauritius. The public offer-
ing of the 2017 Notes was made pursuant to a securities prospectus which had been approved by the CSSF on 9 December
2013. Following the listing of the 2017 Notes on the Vienna Stock Exchange (Wiener Börse), GetBucks Invest placed adver-
tisements in an Austrian magazine and some of the Austrian newspapers in April 2014 to create awareness for secondary trad-
ing in the 2017 Notes and test the waters for further fundraising.

Due to these advertisements, GetBucks Invest was confronted with allegations that it tried to advertise another offer to
the public without having a respective approved prospectus. Based on these allegations, the Austrian Financial Market Au-
thority (“FMA”) contacted the CSSF, which confirmed that the subscription period for the 2017 Notes had ended and pub-
lished a warning to the public stating that (i) the CSSF had only approved the Bond Prospectus, (ii) no offer of securities to

the public conducted by GetBucks Invest after 1 February 2014 and/or outside these jurisdictions was be covered by the Bond
Prospectus or by any other prospectus approved by the CSSF, and (iii) neither GetBucks Invest itself, nor its economic and
financial soundness of the operation or the quality or solvency, had been subject to any examination, an authorisation or the
prudential supervision by the CSSF. In addition, the FMA published a press release and decided to bring the case to the atten-
tion of the Central Public Prosecution Authority responsible for Criminal Cases and Corruption (“WKStA”) in Vienna which
initiated an investigation procedure against GetBucks Invest and pressed criminal charges against its managing director
Mr. Lutz Seebacher. As reaction to the warning of the CSSF, also BaFin initiated a preliminary investigation and requested
information on the matter in May 2014.

In March 2015, the WKStA stopped its investigation and dropped all criminal charges with final and binding effect. In
addition, also BaFin confirmed the termination of its preliminary investigation after having receiving the requested infor-
mation on the facts. To the date of the Prospectus, neither the FMA nor the CSSF did initiate any further administrative pro-
ceedings against GetBucks Invest.
Insurance

Our Group does not hold many insurable assets. We do not own any real estate and use third-party provider data
centres. We utilize cost-efficient approaches and, where reasonable, apply business-safe processes instead of insurance,
such as IT systems that provide for replication of our databases and consumer information through cloud-computing to
avoid data loss. For more information on our IT systems, see “—Information Technology” above. We continually review
our insurance policies and may in the future decide to obtain new insurance policies, such as cloud servers insurance, as
our business expands operationally and geographically.
Currently, we only maintain customary Directors & Officers (“D&O”) insurance policies.
THE ACQUISITION OF THE OPPORTUNITY BANKS AND THE FUTURE GROUP

On 27 October 2015, we entered into the Opportunity SPA with subsidiaries of Opportunity International,
a microfinance organization headquartered in Chicago, United States, concerning the acquisition of their majority share-
holdings in the Opportunity Banks, a Pan-African group of companies consisting of three banks in Malawi, Mozambique
and Uganda, one savings and loans company in Ghana, and two NBFIs in Kenya and Tanzania. For more information on
the Acquisition see “Business―Our Business―Material Contracts― Share Purchase Agreement regarding the Oppor-
tunity Banks”.

As of the date of the Prospectus, the Acquisition has not been consummated with respect to any of the acquired
Opportunity Banks. While the Company expects to be able to consummate most of the closings by 30 June 2016, the
closing for the Opportunity Bank in Uganda has been delayed and may not occur. Opportunity International as seller is
currently pursuing an investigation concerning a potential misconduct of certain individuals of Opportunity Bank Ugan-
da’s management, including the CEO, which is unrelated to the Acquisition. Based on the initial findings of the investi-
gation, the Central Bank of Uganda decided to remove the CEO of Opportunity Bank Uganda with immediate effect as of
22 March 2016. It is the Parties common understanding that such event entitles GetBucks Mauritius to refrain from clos-
ing the Acquisition with respect to Opportunity Bank Uganda. However, as GetBucks Mauritius reserved its right to de-
termine whether to close the Acquisition with respect to Opportunity Bank Uganda depending on the outcome of the in-
vestigation and the final reporting on the audited financial statements for Opportunity Bank Uganda as of and for the year
ending 31 December 2015, the Parties entered into a side letter to the Opportunity SPA on 6 April 2016, according to
which the long stop date (i.e. the date after which the obligations to close will terminate) with respect to the Opportunity
Bank Uganda shall be postponed to 31 December 2016. As of the date of the Prospectus, the result of the investigation at
Opportunity Bank Uganda, and in turn the decision of GetBucks Mauritius whether to close the Acquisition for such
bank, remains unclear. Moreover, the audit of the annual financial statements for the Opportunity Bank Uganda has not
been completed due to the internal investigation. Accordingly, the financial information regarding Opportunity Bank
Uganda is not part of the pro forma financial information included elsewhere in the Prospectus, see “Pro Forma Finan-
cial Information”.
Rationale for the Acquisition

Our ultimate goal is to deliver a basket of financial products and series that meet the financial needs of our cus-
tomers, whilst breaking the paradigm of customers having to visit a branch location to access services. We aim to “serve”
the customer through their entire lifetime revenue cycle, effectively evolving the customer over-time and guiding them
throughout the product range. In order to effectively serve a customer throughout their life-cycle, we intend to acquire
further deposit taking and banking licenses in the markets in which we currently operate to expand our product portfolio
both in terms of diversity and reach by addressing new customers beyond the formally employed sector, and by offering
banking products and services, such as savings products and overdraft facilities. The advantage of having our customers
bank directly with us lies in the access to the high volume of additional information which helps us to better understand
our customers’ cash flow and cash requirements and will allow us to better determine risk and affordability of our prod-
ucts and services to ultimately improve our offering. This will also enable us to expand our offering to the informal sector
or the Small and Medium Enterprises (“SME”) sector. In addition, direct access to our customers bank accounts will also
allow for more effective collection mechanisms.

We believe that the Acquisition represents a unique opportunity to accelerate our current growth strategy and to
grow our loan book while implementing our concept of integrated processes and procedures in online and mobile bank-
ing technology to improve service delivery and turnaround time at the Opportunity Banks. Being able to bridge the gap
between the virtual and traditional worlds of banking will provide us with a faster, more efficient and less expensive ac-
cess to our customers and will grant us the advantage to operate at more cost effective competitive credit rates, whilst
maintaining the current interest spread.

By integrating the Opportunity Banks, we aim to combine our products, credit expertise and technology with Op-
portunity International’s global network, customer base and expertise in using financial services. The effects and syner-
gies we expect from the Acquisition include:

   to improve the efficiency of our collection methods by being able to directly debit our customers’ bank ac-
    counts from within our own institutions; and
   to enhance operational efficiency and profitability of the Opportunity Banks due to our experience.
The Future Group
Overview

Following the closing of the Acquisition, we will facilitate the Opportunity Banks’ transformation towards profit-
ability through the deployment of our AI and proprietary technology in order to serve our growth strategy to ‘bank’ the
large number of potential customers in Sub-Saharan Africa. The in-country management of the Opportunity Banks will
continue to review alternative models to the traditional shop front infrastructure to improve collections and reduce opera-
tional costs. Thereby, the implementation of our proprietary technology will serve as an enabler in a bid to improve oper-
ational sustainability (for information on the historical operations of the Opportunity Banks see
“Pro Forma Financial Information”).

To realize the synergies mentioned above, we particularly intend to take several post merger integration steps, in-
cluding:
New Geographic Reach

By way of the Acquisition, we intend to expand our geographic reach by adding Ghana, Mozambique, and Tanza-
nia to our African footprint, enhance our competitive position in Kenya, Malawi, and Uganda, and increase our customer
base to more than 1.5 million customers.

New Group Structure

In the course of intended reorganisation of the Group following the Acquisition, the Company envisages the con-
centration of certain Group managerial and administrative functions, such as controlling, legal, tax, treasury, public rela-
tions, information technology and human resources, at the level of the Company. In doing so, the Company would enter
into service agreements with all or some of the Group companies.

The following diagram sets forth a summary (in simplified form) of the Group’s organisational structure following
the Acquisition and subsequent reorganisation:

Enhanced Product Portfolio

The Opportunity Banks’ current product offering is comprised of two main tiers, namely “Individual” and
“Group” loans. These are further broken down into four main tiers,

We intend to maintain these products and to add these products to our current product offering. However, a rea-
lignment of the existing product portfolio and credit scoring methodologies will be required in order to maximize the
product offering and performance of the new Group.

PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Introduction

On 27 October 2015, we entered into the Opportunity SPA with certain subsidiaries of Opportunity International,
a microfinance organization headquartered in Chicago, United States, concerning the acquisition of their majority share-
holdings in the Opportunity Banks, a Pan-African group of companies consisting of three banks in Malawi, Mozambique
and Uganda, one savings and loans company in Ghana, and two non-bank financial institutions in Kenya and Tanzania.
For more information on the Acquisition, see “Business―Our Business―Material Contracts―Share Purchase Agree-
ment regarding the Opportunity Banks”).

ment regarding the Opportunity Banks”).
       The parties to the Opportunity SPA agreed on separate closings for each of the Opportunity Banks. As of the date
of the Prospectus, the Acquisition has not been consummated with respect to any of the acquired Opportunity Banks.
While the Company expects to be able to consummate most of the closings by 30 June 2016, we have not determined
whether we will close the Acquisition with respect to Opportunity Bank Uganda. For that reason, the following pro forma
financial information does not cover the Acquisition with respect to Opportunity Bank Uganda.
Basis of Preparation

The following pro forma financial information of the Company as of and for the twelve-month period ended
31 December 2015 (the “Pro Forma Financial Information”) has been prepared in accordance with the notes below to
illustrate the effect of the Acquisition (excluding Opportunity Bank Uganda) (the “Transaction”), as if this occurred on
1 January 2015, as further explained in note (7) below, and has been derived by applying pro forma adjustments to the
financial information of the Company as of and for the twelve-month period ended 31 December 2015.

(1) below, included elsewhere in the Prospectus.

The combined consolidated statement of profit or loss of the Company for the twelve-month period ended 31 De-
cember 2015 is derived without material adjustments from the audited combined financial statements of the Company as
of and for the years ended 30 June 2015, 2014 and 2013, and from the audited interim combined consolidated financial
statements of the Company as of and for the six-month period ended 31 December 2015, as further discussed in note (1)
below, all of which are included elsewhere in the Prospectus.

The Pro Forma Financial Information reflects the application of pro forma adjustments that are based upon availa-
ble information and certain assumptions, described in the accompanying notes hereto, that the Company believes are rea-
sonable under the given circumstances. Actual results may differ materially from the assumptions made for the presenta-
tion of the Pro Forma Financial Information. The Pro Forma Financial Information has been prepared by the Company
and is not necessarily indicative of the financial position or results of operations that would have been realized had the
Transaction occurred as of the dates indicated, nor is it meant to be indicative of any anticipated financial position or fu-
ture results of operations of the Group. In addition, the pro forma statement of profit or loss for the twelve-month period
ended 31 December 2015 presented below does not reflect any expected cost savings, synergies, restructuring actions,
non-recurring items or one-time transaction related costs that the Company expects to incur or generate.

The Pro Forma Financial Information is based upon, derived from and should be read in conjunction with: (i) the
audited interim combined consolidated financial statements of the Company (prepared in accordance with IAS 34 as
adopted by the EU) as of and for the six-month period ended 31 December 2015; (ii) the audited combined financial
statements of the Company (prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the EU) as of and for the years ended 30
June 2015, 2014 and 2013; and (iii) the audited financial statements of the Opportunity Banks (excluding Opportunity
Bank Uganda) (all prepared in accordance with IFRS) as of and for the years ended 31 December 2015 and 2014, as well
as the information set forth in “Capitalization and Indebtedness; Statement on Working Capital”, “Selected Financial
and Other Information”, “The Acquisition of the Opportunity Banks and the Future Group”, and “Business―Material
Contracts―Share Purchase Agreement regarding the Opportunity Banks”.

The Pro Forma Financial Information, which has been prepared for illustrative purpose only, addresses by its na-
ture a hypothetical situation and, therefore, does not represent the Group’s actual financial position or results. The
Pro Forma Financial Information does not constitute financial statements within the meaning of the Luxembourg Law of
19 December 2002, as amended.

Rounding adjustments to the nearest whole number have been made, therefore figures shown as total may not be
exact arithmetic aggregation of the figures that precede them.
Investors should read the Prospectus as a whole and not rely solely on the summarised financial information con-

tained in this section. The report of PricewaterhouseCoopers, Société coopérative on the Pro Forma Financial Infor-
mation as required by the Directive 2003/71/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 4 November 2003 on
the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading, as amended (the “Pro-
spectus Directive”) and its implementing measures is set out on pages 109 and 110 of the Prospectus.

In the audited financial statements of Opportunity Bank Malawi as of and for the year ended 31 December 2015,

principles applied by the Company, such values would have been measured at cost. The following table shows the ad-
justments made to the values presented in the audited financial statements of Opportunity Bank Malawi as of and for the

b: Estimated purchase price consideration and allocation for the Transaction

On 27 October 2015, the Company entered into the Opportunity SPA with certain subsidiaries of Opportunity In-
ternational. For more information on the Acquisition, see “Business―Our Business―Material Contracts― Share Pur-
chase Agreement regarding the Opportunity Banks”.

The Acquisition will be accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting under the provisions of IFRS 3
relating to business combinations (“IFRS 3”) with the Company being considered as acquirer. The IFRS 3 acquisition
method of accounting applies the fair value concepts defined in IFRS 13 relating to fair value measurement (“IFRS 13”)
and requires, among other things, that the identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination
are recognized at the fair values as of the acquisition date with any excess of the purchase consideration over the fair val-
ue of identifiable net assets acquired recognized as goodwill. The purchase price calculation and purchase price alloca-
tion presented herein were made solely for the purpose of preparing the Pro Forma Financial Information.
